QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TRANSPORT OF NUCLEAR MATERIALS IN AUSTRALIA

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Byrne Sen The Hon J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to a question I asked him a month ago, on 10 March, about an accident near Port Macquarie which involved radioactive material. The Minister will have noted that today two Sydney newspapers carry front-page stories on the subsequent illness of policemen and journalists who were on duty during the clean-up after the road accident. I refer to the Daily Telegraph which states:

QUESTION.PARA: The township of Laurieton, with a population of 8000, could be poisoned through its water after a truck accident last December, says Dr John Mackay, of Port Macquarie.

Another article which appeared in the Sun Herald refers to policemen being exposed to radiation. As the Minister undertook to provide me with further information about the lines of communication between police headquarters and the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, I ask whether any attempt has been made to trace the food which was on the truck. I further ask whether his Department has now provided him with this information. Has the Minister looked at the State laws and regulations and decided whether they are as comprehensive as he would desire?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I read with some concern the reports in the newspapers today. As Senator O'Byrne will know, I sought to find the best expert advice on the matter when he raised it with me. He will recall that the incident happened on the day I left Australia to go abroad, so I did not have personal and immediate information. I do not have any reason to change the information I gave him at the time. As a result of this morning's newspaper articles I have been in touch with my officers. I have asked them to ask the Health Commission of New South Wales, which is the body to which the doctor apparently refers, whether it has done any sampling of the water supply, which can be done very readily, and also whether it has done any medical tests. Indeed, I asked my officers to request the Commission to carry out such tests if it has not already done so. The advice we received was, as the honourable senator may know, that there was an accident. Blood tests were carried out on two policemen who were at the site and who reportedly showed radiation illness. Tests showed that reported symptoms could not have been caused by exposure to radiation.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a need, I think, to clean up a few matters of detail. The accident happened on 4 December 1980. The Atomic Energy Commission has advised that its records show that the State police telephoned at 8.20 a.m., not 7.30 a.m. as has been suggested, seeking answers to two specific questions. There was confirmation that an Atomic Energy Commission officer who was already at the scene of the accident was competent to advise on safety measures, and that was so. The officer was on vacation at Port Macquarie and had responded to news reports of the accident. There was a determination of the likely nature of the material in the drums. These questions were referred to safety officers at 8.40 a.m. who initiated appropriate action including consultation with the State Health Commission which requested that the Atomic Energy Commission officer at the accident site undertake an investigation on its behalf. The State police did not seek emergency assistance from the Atomic Energy Commission. There was no breach of procedures.

Regarding the foodstuffs involved in the accident, all damaged items were buried while undamaged items were forwarded to consignees after notification to the State health authorities. The goods were in transit to Queensland. So those damaged items would have been buried. I note that it is reported in the News Digest this morning that the New South Wales Minister for Health, Mr Kevin Stewart, denied claims of a massive cover-up over an accident involving a truck carrying highly dangerous radioactive material. Whilst I believe that to be true, because of the public responsibility for all these matters, I will pursue the matter further.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Byrne Sen The Hon J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I refer the Minister to the basic contradiction that exists somewhere along the line. Dr John Mackay of Port Macquarie said:

QUESTION.PARA: I am seeing eight patients, four of them journalists and two of them policemen, who have the symptoms of radiation poisoning.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they don't have radiation poisoning.
—They have the symptoms.
—Very non-specific.

—This doctor is one of the honourable senator's colleagues. Perhaps the honourable senator is prepared to obtain some evidence that would refute this positive statement by Dr John Mackay. He elaborated by saying:

QUESTION.PARA: There has been a massive cover-up of what exactly was in those containers.
Will the Minister undertake to have one of his officers interview Dr John Mackay to see where this basic contradiction lies and inform the Senate in due course?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say this: I want to get the full truth of the matter. Let me make that perfectly clear.
—That is refreshing.
—Commendable zeal, however rare.

—I find that it is desirable to allow time for interjections because often they assist in the journey. The fact of the matter is that the Australian Atomic Energy Commission had diagnosed the nature of the radioactive material. That information has been made available. I understand that also on the truck were some herbicidal and fungicidal materials, I think DDT and other materials. They in themselves could be contaminants. That has to be recognised. All of these matters are essentially and primarily matters for the Health Commission of New South Wales, which accepts its responsibility. I will pose the questions to it.

ANSWER.PARA: Earlier in my answer today I indicated that I would ask my officers to get in touch with the Health Commission to pursue the matter and to check whether a sampling of water has been carried out. We will consult the New South Wales Health Commission about what steps it has taken to determine, in conjunction with the local doctor, the possible nature of the illnesses involved. The important thing is that the correct diagnosis be made. It is possible that the symptoms are from other causes. If they are caused by radiation we want to know as much as any other Australian.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It relates to South Africa. I ask whether the Minister saw the article in yesterday's Canberra Times by Mr Bremer Hofmeyr, a former South African Rhodes Scholar, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: But there is a deeper strategy in the minds of the real ideologists of boycott. For them economic development that improves the lot of the blacks is not to be supported but to be blocked.

The article goes on further to impress that an effective boycott would contribute to mass misery and unemployment, mainly amongst the blacks, and therefore would help to create a climate for all-out black violence.

Does the Government recognise that trade between South Africa and some of the black African states increased by about 60 per cent last year, to about $1,120m? Does the Government recognise that nine black African states, including some Commonwealth countries, now fly their aircraft regularly into South Africa; and that the Mauritius Government, which frequently in the past led attacks on South Africa at the United Nations, is considering exchanging ambassadors with South Africa as well as allowing its aircraft to fly into the country, after a break of some four years? Finally, in the light of these matters, is the Minister aware that the only people really missing out by our boycott and by Qantas Airways Ltd not resuming flights between Australia and South Africa are the non-whites in South Africa and the Australian people? When will the Government cease allowing itself to be blackmailed by some African states, many of whom are flying in to and increasingly trading with South Africa?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I did notice the article referred to by Senator Townley, but I am not able to provide answers to the several questions which he asked. Perhaps it is appropriate to state in a more general way that there have been increased calls for the application of sanctions against South Africa. The United Nations Security Council is scheduled to meet later this month to consider the question. If the Security Council decides to implement sanctions under chapter VII of its Charter, these would be mandatory and all members of the United Nations would be obliged to observe them. In considering the issue, members of the Security Council will obviously assess carefully the full implications of sanctions for the black majority population of South Africa and for the states which neighbour South Africa. The number of questions raised will be referred to the Minister for Foreign Affairs for appropriate information.

—I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate or to whoever the appropriate Minister may be. Has the Minister seen the latest survey of international trade prospects by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade which points out that a key factor in the present international malaise is the widely held belief in industrialised countries that the problems of adjustment in problem industries such as the textile industry should be left until their economies achieve a higher growth rate? The GATT report points out that because the future of these industries is inherently doubtful they cannot generate a decisive investment momentum, even behind increased protection, and that at the same time protection lowers the prospects of more promising national industries. The report goes on to comment that protection inhibits industrial investment opportunities in the less developed countries and their export potential. Does the Government accept the views of GATT? If so, why do we continue to afford high levels of protection for labour intensive industries accepted as being unsuitable for developed economies, thereby reducing the capacity of less developed countries to generate export income essential to meet the problem of high oil prices and to develop economies essential to a stable world economic situation?

—I have not seen the summary by GATT and I would be interested if Senator Sim would bring it to my attention. Because I have not seen it, I cannot comment on it. I will refer it to the responsible Ministers, mainly the Minister for Trade and Resources and the Minister for Industry and Commerce, for their study.

—Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware that Mr Vincent Matthews and Mr Jim Hall, senior officers of the Government Information Unit, attended what was described as a monitoring meeting for Liberal Party campaign purposes on 25 August 1980, in company with officers of the party such as Mr Eggleton and Mr Baudino, and members of the Prime Minister's staff such as Mr David Barnett? Were they on duty as members of the Unit at the time or had they taken leave? What was their function and their role at that meeting?
—I am not aware of the matters raised by Senator Grimes. I will endeavour to seek the information and will communicate with Senator Grimes.

—Is the Minister for National Development and Energy aware that the Murray Valley League, Region 6, whose address is at Murray Bridge in South Australia, has expressed deep concern about the issuing of any further water licences within the State of New South Wales because, as it states, such action could adversely affect the future quality of water in South Australia? Is the Minister also aware that this section of the Murray Valley League, whose motto is 'For Development and Conservation', has also asked for earnest support in bringing about a moratorium on the issuing of any further water licences in New South Wales until a resources management study has been prepared?
—Doesn't it know that each State has sovereign rights?
—I would have thought Senator Young's question would have attracted warm support from Senator McLaren instead of an expression of anger.
—The suggestion is impracticable, and you know it.
—Anyway you represent New South Wales.
—I represent Australia. I am aware that the Murray Valley League, Region 6, has expressed grave concern about future licences.
—How come you are not aware of what goes on in your own party?

—Mr President, we will accept Senator Grimes' help; it is always useful indeed. The fact is that there is a very real reason for concern about the quality and quantity of water flowing to South Australia. It is because of that that the Commonwealth Government has been expediting the new agreement for the River Murray waters. It is also because of that that the Commonwealth Government has been looking not only to quantity but also to quality and has been consulting all States, and specifically New South Wales, in that regard. Yes, we are aware of the situation. It is a very important problem indeed. The Government believes a proper finalisation of that agreement will go a very considerable distance towards the regulation of quality and quantity of water in the River Murray.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services or, if he prefers, to the Attorney-General, because it is about the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. With the appointment now announced of the new Director of the Bureau, and with its operations due to commence this month, will the Minister table all the papers relating to the formation of the Bureau which was announced on 6 February? Does the Government still claim, as it was certainly claiming last year, that the establishment of the Bureau is in accordance with the recommendation of the Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs, chaired by Mr Justice Williams, when it knows, or it ought to know, that such recommendations of that royal commission related only to intelligence associated with drug offences and not to criminal intelligence generally? What steps have been taken to ensure that the Bureau will be responsible and accountable to at least one elected government and parliament in the Federation, given the notorious difficulties which have been associated with other such exercises in co-operative federalism?

—The Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence will be one of the initiatives to flow from the report of the Williams royal commission, as the honourable senator says. He asks: Will the Minister table certain documents? Can the Government claim that the establishment is in line with the recommendations of the royal commission? Can we give information on certain safeguards? Can we give some assurances about accountability? They are all matters which will have to be referred to the Minister under whose direct responsibility the matter comes. I will get that information for Senator Evans.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and concerns the present danger of the Soviet Union invading Poland and three reported statements of the Prime Minister, the first being that the clock of the Polish crisis is ticking towards midnight, the second being that any military response by the West to a Soviet invasion of Poland would lead to a third world war, and the third being that a Soviet invasion would immediately be met by the free world with massive trade and other sanctions. Is the Minister in a position to confirm these statements attributed to the Prime Minister and in any event to confirm that the Australian Government would not and could not tolerate Soviet military intervention in Poland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not in a position to comment on the three statements that Senator Teague attributed to the Prime Minister, but I am able to say that the Foreign Minister called in the Soviet Ambassador today and drew his attention officially to the text of the Prime Minister's statement of 6 April concerning the situation in and around Poland, underlining the need for restraint now and in the future with a view to the statement being transmitted to the Soviet Government. The Ambassador for his part referred to the speech made by Mr Brezhnev in Prague, particularly that part of it which dealt with the capacity of Poland to find its own solutions to its problem. The Foreign Minister has stated that he hopes that that turns out to be right. For the record, the Foreign Minister stated that he re-emphasised what the Government has already said about the grave consequences that any intervention would have for the world. That, as I have said, is a statement from the Foreign Minister following his calling in of the Soviet Ambassador today.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport aware that the Department of Main Roads in Tasmania has a competent work force and the necessary equipment to carry out road work and that it offers permanent employment in many of the smaller towns in Tasmania? QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FRENCH NUCLEAR TESTS IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It seems that the prolonged program of atomic testing by the French in the South Pacific is continuing. Will the Minister indicate Australia's current attitude to this continued French atomic testing? Does she have any details as to the number of French atomic tests that have been occurring in recent years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have some information on this matter. I am in a position to say that Australia is opposed to France's continued nuclear testing in the South Pacific. This opposition has been frequently stated and the French Government is well aware of the Government's position on this matter. However, it is not our practice to lodge a protest with the country concerned whenever a nuclear weapons state carries out an underground explosion. Since 1975 all the French tests at Mururoa Atoll have been conducted underground. The Government does, however, make formal approaches to the country concerned whenever an atmospheric test is conducted. The last such occasion was when approaches were made to China in October of 1980. Our information is that in recent years France has conducted about 10 underground tests each year. Australia has long been committed to the conclusion of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty which would bring about an end to nuclear testing by all states in all environments. Such a treaty would clearly increase international pressure for an end to all testing and leave those states which continued to test in an isolated and exposed position.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It refers to spies who come out of the cold and apparently come to Australia as migrants. I refer to the recent British security upheaval and one John Bennett who served with the Canadian and British security agencies. It is alleged on one side that he was tinged with KGB links and on the other that he was just mentally unstable. I ask the Minister: If every other migrant to Australia has to have an Australian Security Intelligence Organisation clearance or at least a medical clearance, how did this man circumvent all these hurdles in view of his background overseas? Do the British or Canadian governments regard Australia as a latter-day Botany Bay?
—I think some of the conclusions that Senator Mulvihill has drawn in his question go well beyond the information that is in the public arena with regard to this--
—It is in the Australian.
—The honourable senator is assuming all sorts of things about Mr Bennett from a report which I understand appeared in the Australian newspaper.
—It appeared in the London Guardian too.

—It originated from the London Guardian, yes. No matter how authoritative these newspapers may be, I still think the conclusions that Senator Mulvihill has drawn are beyond what is established even in the articles. The fact of the matter is that Mr Bennett, who was apparently employed in the intelligence section of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police some years ago and who was retired on medical grounds, came to Australia, as far as we know, in 1973. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs informs me that it has no record of his arrival. The position is that in 1973 a British or Canadian citizen was not required to have prior approval to enter Australia. The visa requirements and other requirements that Senator Mulvihill has mentioned did not come into force until 1 January 1975. Now, of course, the checks required to be made on anybody from Britain or the United States who wishes to come to Australia are the same as those made on people from other countries. I do not think there is any real support for Senator Mulvihill's concern that Australia is likely to become some new twentieth century Botany Bay to which people can come without having any checks at all made on them. I hope that anything I have said in this answer will not be taken to indicate any reflection on Mr Bennett.

—I ask a supplementary question. In view of the happenings this year on which I am basing my argument, has the Prime Minister shown any alertness by speaking to our security people and checking with British security to find out just what this gentleman's track record is? If the current law was not in force in 1973, why was it good enough for the authorities to check on people from the Left but not to check on people from the Right?
—I think I made it clear in my answer that this issue would not have arisen in 1973. I will take note of the question as it applies to the present situation.

—I have pleasure in drawing the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery to my left of a congressional delegation from the Mexican Republic led by Dr Alejandro Sobarzo. On behalf of all honourable senators I extend to you a very warm welcome to this chamber and to Australia.

In fact, in an election policy commitment it was proposed that Australian Capital Territory resident pensioners eligible for pensioner fringe benefits be eligible for that concession as stated by Senator Primmer. As to the broader issue, that is a matter which I think might be more properly addressed to another Minister in this place. —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry advise what information is available in Australia on, and what consideration has been given to, the growing of guayule, which I understand is a desert shrub, a native of Mexio and south-western Texas, and which has the qualities of rubber? Has any consideration been given to running trials involving this shrub in Australia, or does the Government in fact have any programs involving it at present under way?

—I do have some information about guayule. I am advised that it is a wild, perennial plant from Mexico and Texas. It is a source of natural rubber and in fact there has been interest in it in Australia for some years. At various times it has been under study in some of the States. My State of Western Australia, for example, in 1959 and in the early 1960s investigated in a number of places the possibility of establishing the plant for commercial production of rubber. Some States are understood to be continuing to monitor the possibilities of the plant under various conditions. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is currently conducting a program of guayule research, including the evaluation of its growing potential in various locations under Australian conditions. I commend the honourable senator for his interest in this matter and I will see that he is further advised of the results of CSIRO's inquiries.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Is the delay caused by the Government's intention to transfer the funding of Aboriginal health services from the Federal Department of Aboriginal Affairs to State Health authorities?

—The response due to the Senate and to the Parliament is the response to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs report on Aboriginal health. That is the report to which a response is due. In making that response, the program effectiveness review, the officials' report, will be taken into account. That document is an internal government document to which no response is required publicly. There has been no unexplained delay. It has been a question of getting an appropriate response through the processes of government, and that will come. I know of no intention by this Government to carry out the kind of transfer to the States of funding for Aboriginal medical services which the honourable senator has suggested. I think that kind of suggestion can do nothing to increase the confidence of the Aboriginal medical services. We are funding them, and I know of no reason why we should not continue to fund them. As to the service at Broome, I hope to be able to take appropriate action in relation to that service in the early future.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. In the light of the successful conclusion of the meeting in New Delhi of the parties to the Convention on International Trade and Endangered Species and the active participation in that meeting of the Australian delegation, will the Government now consider bringing forward an endangered species Act to replace the current confusion of international treaty obligations, domestic laws and customs regulations, which currently seek to cover this important field?

—Any consideration by the Government of a new Act obviously would involve a decision of the Cabinet and would include an approach to the Government by the Minister. I will undertake to pass on the honourable senator's suggestion to my colleague for such action and response as he considers appropriate.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for National Development and Energy and follows on the question raised at the beginning of Question Time by Senator O'Byrne. As I recall, both he and I raised the matter of radioactive material spilled on the road as a result of a semi-trailer accident near Port Macquarie last December. Inquiries I have made since then indicate that the material spilled from that drum, an isotope of americium 241, is regarded by experts as highly dangerous material. Whatever the facts of the incident involving the lorry turn out to be, whether people have radiation sickness or not, will the Government consider introducing legislation, in consultation with State governments, to establish a register to record imports of radioactive material and the movement of that material within Australia? Could such legislation also provide for clear labelling of containers of radioactive material to avoid risk of injury or contamination of persons or property and so that people can assess containers and the message on them from some distance away? Could such legislation include, and I regard this as being most important, provisions for the nuclear industry itself to pay for the cost of such regulation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the nature of the radioactive materials, it is acknowledged that they were of significant radioactive quality. It has never been suggested otherwise. I also mentioned today that two other toxic materials, DDT and fungicide, were involved, and perhaps there is some misunderstanding as to the material spilled. The understanding I have, based on advice both from the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, bearing in mind that that would be from a technical officer on the spot, and from the New South Wales Health Commission, is that no radioactive material escaped. That is the advice I have been given and I see no reason to quarrel with it. It ought to be possible to determine whether the drums were secure. The honourable senator will know that there are State health regulations on radioactivity to cover the nature and protection of the packaging of materials. I have not determined what was the packaging, but the Commission has not advised me of any infringement of regulations in any way.

ANSWER.PARA: I direct myself to the substantive nature of the question having put the matter in perspective, as I understand it. If there is any more information on the incident which would alter what I have said, I am eager to know it. Having said that, there are very strong rules regarding the packaging and movement of containers, and I think-I would need to check it-there is some registration within the States. For my part, as a responsible Minister, I certainly have responsibility for the maintenance of a register of radioactive materials in the wider sense. The Australian Safeguards Office, of course, exists in the wider sense. One of the problems that we have-and Senator Mason would understand this-is that with the growing industrial use of radioactive isotopes and materials there is much more movement of them and therefore much more likelihood of some accident.

As to the specifics, such as the nature of the materials being printed clearly, my understanding is that warnings are printed. If they are not large enough, I will look into the matter. As to the owner bearing the cost, which I think is the latter element of the question, I will look at that again. Let me say that whenever an accident occurs-one or two have happened at Mascot in the last few years-we have looked very closely at the regulations that exist, both State and Federal. It is our sole goal to try to eliminate or, if not, to mitigate to the ultimate degree any kind of accident.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that life offices are currently investing millions of dollars each day on securities which are listed on Australian stock exchanges? Is there any way that a portion of these moneys could be redirected to overcome housing construction problems and to provide finance to small businesses? Would not such a redirection lead to a reduction in interest rates, thereby lessening pressures on the demand for money?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under existing legislation the Government would not have the power to direct the form of investment of life offices in the way that might have been suggested in the question by Senator Watson. Apart from the provisions of the Income Tax Act relating to the 30-20 provisions for holdings of government securities, the life offices are presently free to make investments in the interests of their own policy holders on the basis of their own best judgments commercially. To require the redirection of these funds would accordingly cut across the responsibilities of the offices to their policy holders and to their shareholders. In any case, I do not see advantage flowing from a direction of the kind that was implied in the question from Senator Watson. Such a direction would not ease the demand for finance or the pressure on interest rates. If finance from one source, the life offices, is forcibly directed away from companies such as those listed on stock exchanges, then those companies will simply have to compete more forcibly for funds from other sources, with consequent upward pressure on interest rates.

ANSWER.PARA: If there is a concern about the availability of finance for home building and small business, that concern can be answered in the end only by ensuring that the relevant interest rates reasonably reflect market realities. This factor was instrumental in the Government's decision last December to remove the restrictions on interest rates applying to bank deposits. Alternatively, if there is concern about the level of interest rates, that concern can be answered in the end only by a policy which reduces inflation and hence reduces interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question: Would not a continuation of such a policy by the life assurance companies lead eventually to a situation in which a high proportion of stocks in Australia would be owned essentially by life assurance companies and, with an alternative government, would this not make nationalisation of the whole of industry a relatively simple matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr President, I think that extends considerably the matters that I was outlining in my answer to the question. The capital formation market is one that is heavily influenced by the investment of life offices and other large institutions, but I refrain from comment on the suggestion that an extension of any policy that may have been discussed would necessarily lead to an opportunity for nationalisation of all industries. I think it is fair to say that the portfolio investments of the large life houses and other large lending institutions is very influential in capital formation in this country, but as far as further legislation from this Government is concerned, that is not in contemplation.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, refers to merchant seamen, the Repatriation Act and, in particular, the case of Mr Meredith who has for some years made important submissions to Ministers, including the present Minister, claiming entitlement under the Repatriation Act for disabilities incurred while he was a prisoner of war in Japan from 1942 to 1945. Is he likely to make some announcement in the near future?

—I am sorry that I am unable to recall exactly the circumstances of Mr Meredith's case. The situation is that if Mr Meredith was a merchant seaman and a prisoner of war in Japan, I understand that he would be eligible for treatment benefits in the normal way. On the other hand, if he was a merchant seaman who does not so qualify he would perhaps be seeking a Service pension in the same way as a number of other merchant seaman are at present. If he is in that circumstance he does fall into the general category. That is a Budget matter and something which the Government will be taking into account in the lead-up to the Budget this year.
—The delegation from the Republic of Mexico is about to retire. We thank you for coming into our chamber. We wish you well as you move around Australia.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Is it a fact that the World Heritage Committee will be holding its annual international conference in Sydney in October this year? Is it likely that the chairman of the conference will be an Australian? Is it true that the Australian Heritage Commission has taken a leading part in organising this conference? Is it also true that the Register of the National Estate, which is a monumental task undertaken by the Heritage Commission and the most important record ever produced in Australia of our natural and cultural heritage, will be published as an illustrated 1,200-page volume in time for the conference as the world's first comprehensive record of this kind? Does the Government regard the Heritage Commission as a vital arm in the preservation of our National Estate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator has sought information on several matters relating to the World Heritage Committee and the Australian Heritage Commission. The fifth session of the World Committee will be held in Sydney on 26-30 October this year. I understand that it has been the practice at previous meetings for the host country to provide the chairman, but a final decision will be made at the meeting. So it is not possible at this stage to give a definite answer to that first part of the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: The meeting in Australia is being organised by a local committee which is chaired by the Chairman of the Australian Heritage Commission and which also includes the Director of the Commission as a member. Four places have been nominated by Australia for the world heritage list and the nominations will be considered by that meeting to be held in October. The four places are the Kakadu National Park, the Great Barrier Reef region, the Willandra Lakes region and the Sydney Opera House in its setting with the Harbour Bridge and surrounding waterways.

By coincidence, as the honourable senator advises, the Macmillan company plans to publish in late August 1981 a book entitled The Heritage of Australia-The Illustrated Register of the National Estate. The Australian Heritage Commission has supplied much of the material on which the entries have been based. I believe the events of this year and the publication of this book reflect great credit upon the Australian Heritage Commission.

—The Minister for National Development and Energy will recall that during Question Time yesterday he stated that it was on 18 February in Gladstone that he was first alerted to the difficulties which might affect Government and community expectations that development of the Rundle shale oil deposit would be contributing to Australia's liquid fuel needs at the end of the 1980s. —It is a fact that the first occasion on which it came to my knowledge that there was a significant and major reappraisal, both of the engineering difficulties and the costs of the Rundle project, was 18 February. Prior to that I had no knowledge of any such reappraisal.
—That is only because you were not listening to the people in your Department.

—That interjection was made yesterday. I suggest that if Senator Walsh had any such information and believed it to be correct he should have given it in this place, or he should have told me and I would have investigated the matter. Anyone would be recreant in his public duty if he did not do so. I want to make it perfectly clear--
—You didn't want to know. You were too busy talking up the shares.

—There have been interjections to the effect that we were talking up the shares. Neither my permanent head nor any other officer in my Department gave me any specific information about a significant reappraisal of Rundle prior to 18 February when my permanent head, the Director of the National Energy Office and I, of our volition and of our own seeking, went to Rundle. Let me make that clear. If there was knowledge in the Department, it was certainly not knowledge in the possession of the senior officers of the Department; and no one was talking up shares. Indeed, my Senate comments and public comments stand as a record of that. As to the details of an amendment, I think, although I would need to check it, that it was a printing error. May I take that matter on board and at the first opportunity give the honourable senator some information. But if there is any suggestion that I had prior knowledge then, the answer is no, emphatically I did not.
—The same as Patrick Partners. You are just the same.

—I find that completely offensive. The interjection was: 'You are the same as Patrick Partners'. It implies that I, as a Minister, undertook some improper action or activity. That is simply not true. On the very first occasion that it came to my knowledge that there was any kind of reappraisal, I reported it within 24 hours in writing to the Government. The Government contacted the partners concerned and the Government ascertained from the partners concerned--
—What about the shareholders who lost their money? What about the people who bought shares? That is what Patrick Partners did and that is what you did.
—I find that utterly offensive.
—When you had your finger in the till.
—Mr President, did you hear: 'When you had your finger in the till'? I ask that that comment from Senator Keeffe be recorded. I find it utterly offensive.
—When was that?
—Mr President, may I say that the derisive 'When was that?' meaning when did I have my finger in the till--
—Oh, stop it. The President is on his feet, with respect. Sit down.
—Order! The Minister has taken great offence at Senator Grimes's reflection on him.
—Senator Grimes?
—Yes.
—I didn't say anything about a finger in the till.
—Mr President, I have not asked for a withdrawal. I have asked you to note the offensive remarks. I do not ask for a withdrawal.

—All honourable senators know that under Standing Order 418 any reflection on or any offensive words used towards any other member of parliament are utterly out of order. The decencies of this place have to be observed and honourable senators will not reflect on any member of parliament in an offensive way in unparliamentary language. By that sort of attitude and that sort of conduct here we lose absolute acceptance by the electorate as a whole and the institution of Parliament is damaged greatly. I ask each honourable senator to observe the decencies and correct conduct of this place.

—Mr President, may I continue, because I think it is important. Let me make it perfectly clear what happened. On 18 February I, accompanied by my permanent head and by the Director of the National Energy Office, made a trip to Gladstone for the day to look at the totality of the Gladstone situation because I had received a delegation from Gladstone concerning the pressures upon it with respect to housing, sewerage and water and because I had had talks with the housing construction authorities there, with the alumina people and with others. While I was there I asked to look at Rundle and to get a briefing. The general manager on the spot, an engineer named Mr Findlay, gave me such a briefing. During that briefing it became clear to me that there was in process a major reappraisal of the engineering problems and the costs at Gladstone. That was made very clear to me. I believe that that was a--
—Why didn't you tell us about that before yesterday?

—I will tell Senator Button. Primarily, the statement was made because of the urging of the Government and me that it should be made as soon as possible. I came back to Canberra and I wrote in detail to the Prime Minister setting out my understanding of the matter. As a result of that, separately, the partners were invited to Canberra, discussions occurred with them and we made it abundantly clear that we believed that they had a duty to the people of Australia to reveal the position of Rundle as quickly as possible. They explained that they had technical matters still under discussion but that they were getting expert advice. We took advice of the Solicitor-General, the Crown Solicitor and the Attorney-General's office as to whether it was competent on our part for us to advise the public and not the responsibility of the two partners. We were advised and we took the advice of the Government legal officers in this regard.
—Did you ask whether any Ministers have shares?
—Our sole purpose was to get the disclosure of what were the true facts as fast as possible.
—Yes, we would like that too. We would like that.
—Order! Senator Walsh, you will cease interjecting.

—We urged those partners to do that. They pointed out that they needed some little time to reach conclusions in their technical facilities, and as soon as they reached those conclusions so indeed that announcement was made. I do not know that there was any movement of shares. I think in fact the reverse is true. As it happens, since greatly offensive remarks have been made about me, I repeat that I hold no interest in any shares or stocks, nor does my family, nor does any relative of mine. I have nothing to gain whatsoever. Therefore, I have no finger in the till and have not been talking up shares. I have just one desire and that is to get the information to the Australian people as fast as possible, and the record shows that.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Button proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to support and foster the development of Australia's major public enterprises.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The subject of this matter of public importance is:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to support and foster the development of Australia's major public enterprises.

In a sense that is an understatement of the sorts of matters with which we wish to deal. In the past few weeks and months the situation regarding Australian public enterprises, or government enterprises, has become worse and worse. A variety of attacks on government enterprises have been made. The attacks have been based not on any sound principles of government but on knee-jerk ideological rhetoric. It is because of that that we raise this matter today, in the sense that we hope to flush out some debate on these issues rather than our having just the sort of blinkered approach which has been apparent in statements made by Ministers.

I refer at the beginning of my remarks to a number of quite hare-brained propositions which have been floated around on the Government side of this Parliament. They have been propositions of the utmost banality, if I may so describe them. The first of these propositions is that government enterprises are, almost by definition, inefficient. The second proposition is that the cure for inefficiency is, in all cases, competition or, alternatively, turning government enterprises into private enterprises. All that is based on a number of ideological cliches to which I shall refer in the course of my remarks.

At the beginning I want to examine some of the fundamental weaknesses in those sorts of arguments, if they can be described as arguments, which have been put forward on the Government side of this Parliament. As I said, there has been a lot of talk about inefficiency in government enterprises. From the suggestion that government enterprises are inefficient, the conceptual leap is taken to saying that, conversely, the opposite of government enterprises-that is, private enterprises-are necessarily efficient. I find that an extraordinarily strange argument to come from a government which feather-beds inefficient private enterprises by imposing high tariffs and by providing an across-the-board investment allowance, all funded out of taxpayers' moneys, and applied irrespective of the efficiency or otherwise of those private enterprises. The Government does that as a matter of policy.

We do not find people such as Senator Lewis raising their little social consciousness and screaming their heads off about that aspect of private enterprise, many inefficient sectors of which are totally dependent upon government support, provided either by tariffs or allowances such as the investment allowance, in which millions of dollars of taxpayers' money are spent.

TALK.START.PARA: —About $25m to Fibremakers in Victoria for 1,200 employees, which is more than the freight equalisation scheme provides for the whole of Tasmania.
—I thank Senator Rae. Of course, Senator Lewis does not raise many questions about that sort of thing.
—Doesn't he?

—No, he does not. He asks about alleged errors in the telephone bills of peope in Warrnambool. The second point I make-it is a simple point-is that government enterprises report to this Parliament. Their reports are made available to the Parliament, but they are not very frequently debated in a detailed way. I pay a tribute to Senator Rae because he is one of those honourable senators who are prepared to debate the reports of government enterprises in a detailed and, in many senses, a constructive way. I do not always agree with him in the approach he adopts. That is the sort of thing that this Parliament ought to do. Also, the accounts of government enterprises are always audited. The audited accounts are available for constructive comment in the course of debates on those matters. Those reports provide an opportunity for us to see where inefficiencies lie in those public enterprises. When inefficiencies are alleged and revealed it should be the Government's business and the business of this Parliament to do something about them.

SPEECH.PARA: The third point which often is raised is the suggestion that competition is the great virtue. Competition is said to be the virtue which ensures efficiency. Need I remind honourable senators that this is the Government which says that it believes in that great virtue but has watered down the provisions of the trade practices legislation which encourages competition. It has done that as a matter of conscious policy. It is also a government which talks about competition but does not allow competition where it does not suit its friends in private industry. I refer, for example, to the airlines and the broadcasting system. Senator Lewis will have his opportunity, when that legislation comes into the Senate, to show his colours and how much he believes in competition in that area. These are the sorts of areas in which the debate has been pitched at an absurdly banal, ideological level.

TALK.START.PARA: —What were those words again?

—They were 'banal' and 'ideological'. I will provide the honourable senator with a children's dictionary if he wants one. Both words would appear in a children's dictionary. I come to the details of some of these propositions which are bandied about in this glib way. Let us look at some of the facts. I assert, quite frankly, that public enterprises, under governments of all political persuasions, have served Australia well. I use as examples institutions such as Telecom Australia, Australia Post, Trans-Australia Airlines, the Australian Broadcasting Commission and the Australian National Line. We can deal with some of them in greater detail later. All these public enterprises-great Australian enterprises-were developed for two basic reasons: Firstly, private enterprise capital was generally not available to go into the areas in respect of which these government enterprises were developed; and, secondly, public enterprises were seen by all governments in this country and in other countries to be appropriate in these areas. I give an example of recent origin in West Germany. West Germany set up a razor gang-I do not know how to say that in German-which looked at some of the public enterprises in West Germany. One of its recommendations was that the Bundespost, or sections of it, be hived off to private enterprise. The West German Government said no, that as a matter of policy the postal services of the Federal Republic of Germany were appropriately in the hands of the Government and the public sector. That Government, of course, is much admired in many ways for its efficiency by people on both sides of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The futures of these great public enterprises are at risk because of an unhappy conjunction of two bizarre events. The first is the fact that some of these enterprises which operate for the Australian people are now operating in areas of high profitability. The entrepreneurs, who at all times are concerned to get their hands on profits, look with their beady eyes at the profitable government enterprises such as Telecom and say: 'Aha! Just a minute; that looks a little profitable for a government enterprise. We should have that'. They say that not in the interests of the Australian people but in their own interests. I think it is very important to point out the levels of profitability which some of these government enterprises have attained.

The second unhappy event is the crude ideology of the Fraser Government, the sort of thing to which I referred earlier-sloganeering about the private sector's taking up the slack from the public sector and so on. That is supported by a series of petty complaints, dripping complaints about telephone bills being wrong and things like that. The inference that we are supposed to draw from all of that is that if the Myer organisation or the Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd had a monopoly in the telephone business in Australia such errors would not occur. That is bunkum. Monopolies of government and private enterprise have many of the same charateristics. It is about time that we in this Parliament looked at the efficiencies or otherwise of the great private monopolies in Australia which benefit greatly from government moneys-taxpayers' moneys.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think there is a case for saying that if people receive a benefit from taxpayers' money, they subject themselves, as a quid pro quo, to greater investigation of accountability than they would otherwise have?

—Of course there is, but I ask the honourable senator not to interrupt me. Let us deal with that matter on another occasion. I have said frequently in this chamber-I will say it again and again-that we ought to be debating not these petty, ideological issues but the nature of the mixed economy which would best serve the interests of the Australian people. When I refer to the Australian people, I mean all the Australian people. I take those words from the 1975 policy speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). He said that this was to be a government for all the people. I illustrate that point and the pettiness of some of these attacks on public enterprise by quoting Hugh Stretton. He describes a situation in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Day after day I sat around coffee tables and conference tables with public servants and private consultants who banked Commonwealth, flew Qantas, British Airways and TAA, enjoyed high speed trains and geometrically designed super highways, trusted the radio beams in the sky and the admiralty charts at sea and the ordinance maps in the bush, used Government loans to buy Government houses, framed and lined with government softwood, preferred public to private superannuation, shot their children with Salk and Sabin, smoked gauloise, and fuelled their Leylands and Renaults with BP, but still knew in their bones as a fact of life beyond any rational dispute whatever, that the private sector is the only productive sector, and that public ownership and management are always, everywhere, incurably inefficient.

Of course, as I said a minute ago, I am concerned about enterprises which serve the whole of this nation. I refer the Senate to a few brief facts about some of those enterprises. For example, Telecom is the largest enterprise in Australia. It has enormous fixed assets of over $7 billion. In 1979-80 it added $1,003 million to those fixed assets. It installed more than half a million telephones. In that year the telephone network grew by 66 per cent, telexes by 14.8 per cent and the data networks by 34.3 per cent. It has a total full time staff of 88,000 people and a great research capacity. It made a return on assets of 2.8 per cent after payment of interest and 7.7 per cent before payment of interest. It has not raised telephone or telex charges since September 1975. There is no other enterprise in Australia, public or private, which can say that. If, after looking at that situation in a corporation such as Telecom, we say that it should improve its performance then there are all sorts of processes that can be set up to see that it does that. I will point to one of the factors in Telecom's incapacity to provide the services that it would like to provide. It is mentioned in the last report of the Chairman of Telecom. He states:

Despite these record connections to match consumer demand, there are some high growth areas where the number of people waiting for a telephone service is unfortunately increasing. This trend has been commented on in recent Annual Reports. It flows from having to balance the Capital Investment Program too finely to match the Government's desire for a limitation on investment in the public sector.
The report goes on to state:
Generally we have a good standard of service-

But Telecom cannot deal with the peak load problems until that limitation on investment, imposed by the Government, is dealt with in a satisfactory way. So the Telecom report simply says that the inhibitions on its capacity to deliver are dictated by the Fraser Government. The Fraser Government says: 'Telecom is not operating as efficiently as it might and for that reason it ought to have some of its activities hived off and that will make it more efficient'. We have heard that silly argument from some honourable senators also. The defects in Telecom are basically those of Government policy.
The sort of problem which the Government is creating for public enterprises is illustrated by the new Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh), who in a recent speech said:
. . . the public sector has grown too large to the detriment of the private sector.

The public sector is fulfilling roles and meeting needs in areas where the private sector could assume the responsibility. In addition, it could do so at a reduced overall cost in a way which would be more sensitive to the needs that have to be met and which would encourage one of the enduring principles which I feel should always be uppermost in any consideration of the performance of both the private and public sectors-the principle of choice.
That is the sort of off the top of the head, hare-brained remark of a man in the Government who recently has been appointed a Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did he say that?

—He said that on 6 April. What choice are we talking about? Is he suggesting that in respect of Telecom people in the one street should have a choice between private enterprise and Government sector telephone services? If we did that has he any idea what it would cost? What choice is he talking about in relation to airlines, telecommunications and matters of that kind? There is no choice available. This is doctrinaire rubbish and if consideration is to be given to these questions it should be done case by case on the basis of social policy. The next matter I want to point out to senators is this.
—Economic policy.

—Senator Lewis, as a senator from the country, has all the properties of raw sugar-crude and unrefined-in his interjections in this place. If he went back to his country electors and espoused in detail some of the policies of bunkum that he elaborates on here in interjections, he would have a very interesting reaction. I refer honourable senators to TAA, which the Government proposes to sell. What did the Chairman of TAA say the day after the TAA decision was announced? He said: Beaut! It will be a public company so we will be able to cut out our Fokker Friendship service. That means no air services for the people in the outback of north Queensland, parts of Tasmania and so on. Sir Peter Abeles will not run unprofitable services if he does not have to. Private enterprise will not run unprofitable services if it does not have to.

SPEECH.PARA: Telecom, has not increased its charges since 1975. Telecom, on a year by year basis, finances the development of the country network of telephone services to the extent of in excess of $200m. If we take away the profitable areas of Telecom-take the cream off the cake-it will surely go bad and some of the friends who donate to the Liberal Party will go well because they will get the profitable business of Telecom. But what will be left for all the citizens of this country? What will be left in the provision of services to the outback and the country areas which Telecom subsidises at this time, day after day, week after week and month after month? If we are to talk about the inefficiencies of Telecom and the need to make Telecom competitive in some way by pinching its more profitable services on which the beady eyes of entrepreneurs have already been fixed, it will be to the detriment of a vast majority of the Australian people. The argument about choice in this context is pure rubbish.

The essential argument for public ownership of these basic services is the same as it has always been-that there is a social, public and national interest imperative in many areas of their operations. Cross-subsidisation is an essential element of the Australian telecommunications service. It benefits country people enormously. The situation is similar with air services. In the United States of America no government television services were provided for years and years and country communities there went without television. It was only recently, after the coming of community aerial television, that these communities were served. In Australia there has been a deliberate policy of serving all Australians through instrumentalities such as the Australian Broadcasting Commission, Telecom, Trans-Australia Airlines, Australia Post and so on. Of course what is happening now, as I said, is that the beady eyes are fixed on the profitable areas of Australia Post, which is denied the right to compete in a real way with its courier services. Yet these people talk about competition. The beady eyes are fixed on the profitable areas of Telecom, which is denied the right to compete in the installation of PABX terminal facilities. Telecom has been denied the rights to compete by this Government-the great protagonist of competition. Why is this so? This is so because funds have been donated to the Liberal Party by companies which have an interest in getting into this profitable area of Telecom.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense.

—That is not nonsense at all, Senator. We will take this up another time if the honourable senator wants. The fact is that services cannot be imported to compete with a body such as Telecom. If there is to be any sort of monopoly at all it must be a social monopoly which is prepared to serve the needs of the community across the board. The same sorts of comments could be made about the other instrumentalities as well. The same sorts of comments could be made about the decision to sell TAA.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again I acknowledge the silver tongued oratory of my colleague from Tasmania, Senator Button. I am running out of words in praise of his dextrous use of language. It is a pity I cannot say the same about the substance of his oratory though. He talked about inefficiency in private enterprise and referred to my ideology. Let me make it perfectly clear to Senator Button and to anyone who happens to be listening to the debate that one of my philosophies is a belief that the larger the enterprise the more inefficient it is. In my book that applies to governments and to public enterprises-by which I understand Senator Button to mean statutory authorities or quasi-autonomous national government organisations-and to private enterprise. It has been my experience that the larger the enterprise the more inefficiencies in it. I do not mind publicly proclaiming that as far as I am concerned the smaller the better for Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite Senator Button's oratory today he is clearly running into difficulty because he failed to apply his speech to the substance of the matter which he submitted for discussion, namely:
The failure of the Government to support and foster the development of Australia's major public enterprises.

The first point I make is that public enterprises-these quangos-are still part of government. In another form they are the taxpayers of Australia. Just because they are separate entities there is no reason to treat them separately. Their expenditure is government expenditure; their losses are the losses of the Australian taxpayer. These losses may be hidden in the initial stages but ultimately they have to be borne by the taxpayers of Australia. Consequently, they are treated in a way similar to that of all other government expenditures. One of the reasons that this Government was returned to office in 1980 was that the people of Australia wanted us to cut back government expenditure. Public enterprises have shared in this process as have other public sector activities. I indicate to Senator Button that I hope that this cutting back will occur even more, following the so-called razor gang report. On the other hand, let it be openly acknowledged that the Government has endeavoured to make this public sector of Australia much more efficient. For example, we have had the Dix inquiry into the Australian Broadcasting Commission, the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Airfares, the proposed inquiry into the deregulation of the air transport industry, the formulation of the Australian National Railways corporate plan, the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council, the Myers committee and currently, the Cabinet Review of Commonwealth Functions, which is the correct name of the razor gang which is expected to report in the near future.

In relation to the subject under discussion-the so-called 'failure' of my Government to 'support and foster the development of Australia's major public enterprises'-let us also look at the innovative use of public enterprises by this Government. I refer in particular to multicultural television, which seems to upset so many members of the Australian Labor Party but which has certainly been welcomed by Australians whose origins are in other lands. The national communications satellite will also be another public enterprise. I cannot say that I am greatly keen on these public enterprises being expanded but certainly, where the Government will operate in these fields, I recognise the need for the creation of such authorities. Let me look at some of the public authorities spoken about by Senator Button. Let us look, for example, at Trans-Australia Airlines. In its thirty-fifth annual report it speaks of one of its major problems. The report states:
Until 1972 the regular evaluations by the Australian Government Actuary of the fund maintained by the Commission revealed surpluses; for example at 1972 the surplus was $3.124m.
This situation was drastically changed by amendments to the Commonwealth legislation relating to Commonwealth Superannuation, particularly a change in 1973-
This was change clearly brought about by the Australian Labor Party when it was in government-
providing for annual pension adjustments, which is believed to have made the Commonwealth Scheme the most expensive retirement benefits scheme in Australia.

That scheme, described as the most expensive retirement benefits scheme in Australia, was a scheme imposed on TAA by the Labor Government in 1973. Let us recognise that my Government is financing TAA's expansion into wide-bodied jet aircraft through government backed funds. The Government is going to review its opportunities for deregulation of the industry, as it should, and until the airlines agreement has been renegotiated TAA will continue to operate in a protected market. Let us look at Telecom Australia which was heavily praised by Senator Button. I will cite some of the figures from its 1979-80 annual report. I will cite the highlights. The report states:
The volume of business as measured by earnings at constant prices rose by 11 per cent.
Compare that statement with the following:
Costs rose sharply with payroll up by $130.3m.

That represents an increase of 12.5 per cent. Here is an Australian Government authority which is increasing its payroll faster than its earnings. No private enterprise can be involved in that area and last very long. But, of course, a government backed authority is able to do so. The suggestion in the matter being debated at present is that this Government is not helping these authorities. I will cite further highlights from the report. It states:
More than $1,003.1m was spent on the capital program and more than half-a-million new telephone services were connected.
Profit increased from $190.5m to $211.5m and was re-invested to finance network expansion.

Let me make it perfectly clear that I am not suggesting that efficiency brought about this profit. What has brought the profit about is the monopoly market situation, because Telecom has no competitor and is able to impose the charges it believes necessary to make these sorts of profits.

Let me relate to the Senate just one of the sorts of stories I have heard-and I have heard countless stories along these lines: After waiting weeks and weeks for our new line to be put in, one Friday morning about 9 o'clock six people in four vehicles arrived. They lighted a fire and made tea. I found out later that officially they start at 8 a.m. but that is at their depot, about 12 miles away. About 9.30 a man driving a trench digger arrived. After he had his morning tea, he started to dig the trench. All others stood watching. When he had finished, two men laid a line in the trench-that was their job. All others stood watching. At some stage they broke for lunch and afternoon tea, the fire with the billy on was kept going all day. Two other men joined the wire to the main line and to my house. Everyone else stood around watching. Then they packed up to go home. I asked why they were leaving when the job was so close to being finished; I was told that it was 4 o'clock and it would take them an hour to get back to the depot and clean up and they had to be finished by 5 o'clock. Needless to say, some of them came back next day, Saturday morning, at time and a half and finished it off.

That story was told to me some years ago by a farmer who was struggling at the time. He was running his whole property without any hired labour. He told me that he had no doubt that with that trench digger he would have been able to do all the work that those people performed by himself in the same number of hours that it took the seven of them to do the job. I especially ask all listeners today not-I repeat, not-to send me similar stories because I know that if I asked them to send me stories I would be absolutely inundated with such stories of inefficiency. Having asked them not to send me such stories, I will probably still end up with a desk full of them. This is the sort of inefficiency which socialised monopolies bring us. I hope that I do not have my telephone cut off as a result of telling this story. I will hold my breath.

If Telecom had even one competitor in the field does anyone think that we would have to suffer this sort of nonsense? Of course we would not. What keeps Telecom going is its ability to fix its own prices and to persuade governments that the prices fixed are the sorts of prices that it needs to charge. What other aid would the Labor Party give Telecom within this monopoly situation which, unfortunately, it is able to have under our operations?

Let us look at the Australian National Railways Commission. The Government continues to subsidise the Australian National Railways' operating losses. I repeat that that is an actual out of pocket cost to the taxpayers of Australia. They may not see it in the initial stages but somewhere along the line they will undoubtedly have to pay for these losses.

TALK.START.PARA: —They pay annually at the moment.
—Senator Rae informs me that they pay annually at the moment. The Chairman's Review states:

SPEECH.PARA: This year saw revenue fall short of expenditure by $64.8 million, an improvement of $7.6 million over last year.

I acknowledge that the railways throughout Australia run at a loss and I recognise that the Australian National Railways, under the encouragement of this Government, is improving its performance. Again, the Chairman's Review states:
Revenue increased by 20 per cent whilst expenditure increased by nine per cent.

I congratulate ANR for doing that. It has increased its revenue by 20 per cent and has managed to hold its expenditure increase to only 9 per cent which is, of course, about the same increase as that of the consumer price index. The Chairman continued:

The result was more than satisfactory when viewed in the light of wage and salary increases flowing from Arbitration Commission awards and National Wage Case decisions which will cost almost $16 million in a full year.

I certainly congratulate ANR for that report. But I point out that that is happening under my Government and the policies of encouragement that it has been able to introduce. I turn now to another statutory authority-the Australian Shipping Commission, the Australian National Line. In its annual report for 1980 the Chairman's Review states:

The consolidated result of the Australian Shipping Commission for the financial year ended 30 June 1980 was a loss of $7,989,000. Whilst this was a very unsatisfactory result it must be looked at against the background of international trading which continues to be depressed in volume and freight rate terms, reflecting the general world scene.
I come now to what I consider to be a most important matter. The Chairman goes on to say:

In addition, the Line sustained crippling losses from the unusually high incidence of Australian industrial stoppages throughout the year. In fact, 793 ship days, at an estimated cost of $11.50 million, were lost in 247 individual delays to the Line's vessels arising directly from industrial disputation.
This point is then made:
Of these losses, 76.8% were through disputes in which the Line had no direct employer/employee relationship, . . .

That is a cost to all Australians. This body is wholly owned by us, the people of Australia. If it makes such a loss, we have lost. No matter that it does not appear directly to come out of our pockets during that year, indirectly it will ultimately come out of our pockets. So individual disputation in which the Commission had no direct employer-employee relationship has cost the people of Australia almost $9m in this one enterprise alone. I hope that even senators opposite might be prepared to acknowledge that these figures are not insignificant. Would anyone in this place argue that this Line could not exist without Government support or guarantees? It is carrying these substantial losses and it is many years since it paid any dividend to the people of Australia in relation to its activities. I come back to the subject of the debate today. The Opposition alleges that this Government has failed to support and foster the development of Australia's major public enterprises. I have another case that I will mention towards the conclusion of my remarks. I refer to the annual report of the Australian Tourist Commission. I am delighted to be able to read Captain Ritchie's letter to the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) dated 20 October 1980. It reads:

My dear Minister, The year was a satisfying one for the Commission with a number of major achievements. These included Australia's first major tourist promotion film for eight years, our first International Visitor Survey for five years, our largest advertising budget ever, the launch of our domestic tourism campaign, production of our Travel Planner in six languages, the most extensive research program in our history, completion of a regional promotional film with Colleen McCullough as its star and Australia's participation in the International Tourism Bourse, Berlin. All of this was made possible by the 92% increase in our appropriation for the year.
I repeat that it states:
All of this was made possible by the 92% increase in our appropriation for the year.

This is reported by a statutory authority and I refer to it in a debate about whether my Government has supported Australia's statutory authorities. What a lot of nonsense this debate is. This report went on to state:
As a result,-
That is, as a result of the increase in appropriation-
the Commission enters 1980-81 better prepared than it has been for many years to undertake well-planned and effective promotions in all markets.
The Chairman goes on to tell us the reason for the Government funding of this body. He says:
For 1979, short term visitor arrivals in Australia increased by 163,000-
An increase of 26 per cent-
to 793,300. The resulting revenue to the economy from overseas visitors may be estimated at more than $650m.
Captain Ritchie goes on to state:
The Government is to be congratulated for the substantial progress Australia has made in tourism promotion and development through new initiatives in the 1979-80 Budget.
I am not saying this; this is what Captain Ritchie says and he is the Chairman of a statutory authority in Australia. He continued:
Much greater activity on the part of the industry in overseas markets is noticeable, both in conjunction with and independent of the ATC.
Included among these initiatives were-
He is talking about Government initiatives in assisting this industry-

Export Market Development Grants, increased funding for the Australian Tourist Commission, Bureau of Industry Economics research, development grants, depreciation allowance and International Civil Aviation Policy new International air fares and domestic air fares.

I have not the slightest doubt in utterly and completely refuting the proposal put by Senator Button that this Government is not supporting and fostering the development of Australia's major public enterprises.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is quite happy to take issue with the Liberal-Country Party Government on our public enterprises. One would have thought that Senator Lewis, leading for the Government in the debate, would have put forward a stronger defence of the Government's attitude to our public enterprises. One would have thought that in this debate Senator Lewis would have defended the Government's ideological and philosophical reasons for ignoring the great problem that faces public enterprise in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators should be aware of the fact that there is great unease, great uncertainty and great concern in the enterprises known as Trans-Australia Airlines, Australia Post, Telecom Australia, the Australian Broadcasting Commission, the Australian National Line, and the Australian National Railways Commission. They would be aware also that the Government announced, in an offhand and stealthy sort of way, its decision to sell off TAA. It was not done after any careful analysis or informed discussion in the party room, or even in the Parliament itself. The Government agreed to take this step as a result of the relentless pressure and prodding by a particularly rabid section of the Government's own back bench-the hardliners, the twentieth century Adam Smiths, the extreme Right of the Liberal Party-who want to hive off those profitable public sectors of our economy that are performing a very valuable service to the Australian community. This group of free-for-all enterprise fanatics have achieved a rare coup in establishing this uncertainty. In respect of TAA, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) made a pre-election promise not to interfere with that organisation. It was also the avowed intention of the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) and the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) that there would be no decision to sell off this important enterprise.
