The reasons for the change are simple. First of all, the owners of capital are interested in getting their hot little hands on those sectors of our economy that are profitable. The economy is not in a healthy state; something has to be done, and that means we have to con the Australian public into believing that this Government is acting effectively and positively and that action will be taken to rectify the concern felt in the Australian community. The threat, therefore, is to be seen as a counter move to the Government's inept responsibilities in governing this country. Suddenly phrases have appeared in so many quarters to the effect that we have to relieve business of regulation burdens, that there has to be deregulation, that there have to be new approaches so that we can establish the revitalisation and regeneration of our economy. We recognise that businesses are going bankrupt in their thousands and, believe it or not, this Government suggests that somehow it is the fault of enterprises such as TAA that that is taking place. So TAA is to be sold. Who suggested that TAA should be sold? Certainly the proposition was put forward some time ago by Senator Rae but, in respect of the current propositions, it was the Murdoch and Abeles submissions to the Ansett organisation that set about the movement to close down this important public instrumentality. We have already seen the reaction that that has caused. It means, of course, that those sectors of the TAA enterprise which are unprofitable obviously are in for the axe.

Trans-Australia Airlines will be sold out to the major corporations so that this Government, through the communications unit it has established, can conduct a public relations exercise to reassure the Australian people, or to reassure the back bench, that this Liberal-National Country Party Government is really committed to the principles of free enterprise. In fact, what is happening is that it is steadily becoming socialist. It is socialising the costs of business, giving it cheap power, lower taxes, cheap roads, infrastructure, whatever it can give, as well as the incentives and subsidies so ably referred to by Senator Button in introducing this matter of public importance. At the same time, the dogs of big business are barking at the heels of this Government, asking for more offerings, and they have their eyes on all the public enterprises. Telecom is forbidden to compete with private enterprise in areas where it has an advantage. What a joke that is. First the Government sells off operations because they are hindering free enterprise; then it does the same thing when those operations are competing too well. The conclusion is obvious. The private sector is sacred. It can do no wrong in the eyes of so many members of the Government, and no one can transgress this holy, if poorly ploughed, ground. Free enterprise may rip off consumers, sabotage economic policy, sack workers, damage the environment, and generally harm the community, but on no account can the Government intervene. That is the philosophy of so many members of this Government.

Are we to draw the conclusion from the decision about TAA that the ANL the ABC, and all the other organisations referred to are also in for the chop? We listened to what Senator Lewis had to say about the Australian National Railways, the criticism he made of that organisation. Who would want to buy the Australian National Railways? It provides a service. It is not a profitable enterprise, it is an organisation deliberately designed to provide services to very many sections of our community.

Let us look closely at the specifics of the Government's treatment of public enterprises. The mentality and philosophy which is producing today's reactions could be seen at work many years ago when the conservative government of the day sold off the publicly owned Commonwealth Oil Refineries, which was part of the Menzies madness of the 1950s. The extent of that shortsightedness can be seen today when we have so little control over determining our own energy policies through the lack of expertise and leverage which public ownership of COR would have brought forward. Since the advent of the Fraser Government we have seen a further steady undermining of community ownership of key enterprises. In September 1979, for example, the Commonwealth brickworks in Canberra was sold off to its only competitor. So much for the posturing of Senator Lewis. The brickworks was not permitted to compete with the private sector. It was sold for a song and in circumstances which can only be called corrupt and scandalous. The justification for that sale was simply that it was uneconomic. Yet when the divestment of the highly profitable public Housing Loans Insurance Corporation was mooted last year, the argument was quite the opposite, namely, that the enterprise had been so successful there was no further need for it. We know that the Government backed off only because there was an outcry within the community, and even amongst sections of the insurance industry. Here we have a situation in which one enterpirse is sold off because it is not profitable, and yet justification is sought for the proposal to sell off another enterprise that is too profitable. Selling off the community's properties and wealth is part of the philosophical position of this Government. It is contradictory, it is illogical, it is unnecessary, and it is unnerving to those important public enterprises that have been and are performing a public function.

Two more of the people's investments were quick to follow the proposals to which I have already referred. The Ranger uranium stake went, despite reluctance and even opposition from the private enterpreneurs who make up the other Ranger partners. They opposed the Government's abandonment of this project. That most highly contentious area of energy resource is now completely in the hands of multinational private capital. The one stake we had there was sold off to suit the mental gymnastics of the Liberal and National Country parties. Simultaneously, the coalition handed back on a platter to the overseas multinationals the monopoly of the lucrative pharmaceutical industry by selling off Fawnmac the pharmaceutical group bought for the Australian people by Dr Everingham during the period of the Whitlam Government in 1975. In the four years after the purchase, that company had consolidated its position and was preparing for a major expansion in that industry. Its profitability had therefore dropped temporarily, and its sale at the time was a gift to those forces which control the pharmaceutical industry in this country.

In the fields of energy, building, insurance, communication, and pharmaceuticals, the Australian people are being sold short. They are being sold down the drain, but worse is to come. The growing confidence of those free-for-all enterprisers in the coalition is getting to the stage of overreaching itself. The more rational, logical and reasonable Liberals who can admit the value of public enterprises and can perceive the advantages of such enterprises for the people are now coming under major attack. The public's most valuable and powerful enterprises are now being eyed off by the elitists in the private sector of the Australian economy. In January of this year the Chairman of Qantas Airways Ltd, Jim Leslie, a corporate soul if ever there was one, accused the Government of so weakening the airline, which we all know and have been told too often is the one we all own, that the way was open for an easy takeover. He outlined nine steps that could weaken an airline and pointed out that six steps had already been taken by this Government. We had the spectacle of the Qantas board of directors traipsing to the Government to plead for Qantas' survival only to be pushed off with an assurance from the Minister for Transport that Qantas would not be sold. We know what happens if Mr Hunt's assurances are put to the test because he gave us the same assurance in respect of TAA.

Since then, of course, we have heard nothing from Mr Leslie and his fellow directors. They have been put in cold storage; they have been silenced. But we have seen a confrontational and bloody-minded attitude from the Government towards Qantas and the role of Mr Hunt over the sale of TAA. Not content with half measures, the Government's attitude towards Telecom Australia and Australia Post reflects its general attitude towards public ownership. Last year the responsible Minister refused to allow Telecom to expand into new fields of technology and at the same time permitted private companies into the profitable areas of Telecom's business. Now there are pressures from within the Liberal Party to continue to strip Telecom and Australia Post of their major operating assets and to reassign the profitable aspects of their operations so that the greedy, the big corporations in our society and the very wealthy can reap enormous profits.

Additionally, the Government increased its pressure on Telecom by restricting its ability to borrow sufficient funds to provide essentials such as telephone connections-it did that because of what it said was the inefficiency of the organisations-while it is the Government which is wilfully and carefully planning and causing the problems. A prime example of the Government's determination under factional pressure to undermine Telecom is the proposed communications satellite due to begin operating by 1985. We all know how the Packers, the Murdochs, the Abeles and the other big tycoons of Australia will try to get their hands on that important new technology. Telecom's major trade union, the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association, is aware of those threats to the statutory body and has organised a reasoned and sensible defence. Can we expect to see the same confrontational policies that the Government has adopted towards Qantas and TAA turned towards Telecom as well?

We come now to the latest of these misappropriations, one which obviously demonstrates the conflict which has developed in the coalition's own philosophy. Despite explicit assurances that TAA would not be sold off, the Minister last week bowed before the pressures in the party room and announced its future sale. No doubt Lynch's razor gang has much to do with that also, as it will with so many public enterprises. Is the razor gang so powerful that it can cut the throat of our public enterprises? Other pressures are evident as well, and we need do no more than think about the pressures that are obviously being exerted by the tycoons in the Australian private sector. The Government has given no valid reasons for creating this unease in the public enterprises of Australia. It has given no valid reasons for the sale of TAA. In fact, there is every commercial reason to suggest that TAA has been more successful in every way than its private counterpart. The fact is that the Government has no reasons and no excuse. It is merely reacting to those forces within the party which are becoming irresistible, too vocal, too strong and too tied to the big corporations in this country.

In conclusion let me say that the Australian Labor Party and the Australian community will be happy to take up the challenge in defence of our public enterprises. We will be happy to go to the hustings. We will be happy to go everywhere throughout our country to indicate to the Australian people that our public enterprises are profitable and are efficient as long as we remove the restraints that so obviously are placed upon them by the Government's own philosophical position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — We are debating a matter of public importance raised by Senator John Button, the Leader of the Opposition, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to support and foster the development of Australia's major public enterprises.

I have taken part in many discussions on matters of public importance here previously and usually I have had some idea of what they were all about. But this would be one of the most nebulous subjects we have ever had before us. I thought if I listened to the Opposition I would have some idea of what it was about. Having listened already to two Opposition speakers, I still do not know what it is about. Senator Gietzelt spent most of his time either talking shares up or down or talking of the morale in some of our public enterprises. At Question Time in this chamber we heard allegations of Ministers talking up and down the shares of private enterprise. We have just heard some fairly outrageous statements from Senator Gietzelt. As a matter of fact, recently I followed him in a debate on transport when he growled about how little time he had to speak but spent half of his speech talking about what the Government has said it is not going to do, namely, sell off Trans-Australia Airlines.

The sooner we nail that furphy, the better it will be for everybody. The Government has not said that it will sell TAA. Indeed, even the proposition put some time ago by Senator Peter Rae was not to sell TAA. There has been talk of making it a public company. As I mentioned recently, this is now the Government's intention. Indeed, Qantas Airways Ltd is a public company. Senator Rae's proposition, as I understand his previous statements, was along the line that some shares may be sold to some of its staff. I think I am correct in that assumption. Indeed, there is much merit in that. It would give the staff a fair bit of interest in the company for which they work. I think Senator Gietzelt referred three or four times to the selling of TAA. Of course, the Australian airline industry has gone through enough trauma in the last few weeks as a result of our trying to sort out a report on it and as a result of pressure on some of our Western Australian colleagues from a body in that State which thinks it knows more about how to run an airline than anybody else does. The talk now about selling TAA is certainly doing nothing for the morale of the staff of TAA which, to my way of thinking, operates one of the best airlines in one of the best airline systems in the world. I say here and now that the Government's whole intention is that TAA be made into a public company so that it can become more competitive and thus take a better place in the market place. I do not think there has been any failure on the part of the Government to support and foster the development of Australia's major public enterprises. As a matter of fact, many honourable senators on this side would argue that there has probably been too much support.

Public enterprises were basically set up to fulfil a purpose. I guess that the purpose of setting up TAA was a little different from that. It was the child of a Labor government and was run in what was possibly a most unreasonable atmosphere vis-a-vis competition with the then struggling private enterprise sector. The two-airline agreement was brought about so that there could not be that sort of government support for its own entity and so that private enterprise would be able to compete on equal grounds. For instance, all members of parliament travel on government warrants and are quite at liberty to travel with whichever airline they want to. Many of the other public enterprises were set up to do a particular job and they are doing that job.

In times past I have had cause to speak about Telecom Australia and Australia Post, and it is quite significant that those two instrumentalities once came under the umbrella of the old Postmaster-General's Department. My recollection is that the last Labor Government set them up as two separate statutory authorities. I make no complaint about that and have no argument with that. Indeed, since then they have done a fairly good job, but it would be the utmost folly and irresponsible for any government to say 'there you are, away you go', and not keep an eye on them. We have a responsibility to ensure that our public bodies operate in an efficient manner. After all, they belong to the taxpayers and the taxpayers have helped to set them up. The taxpayers, I think, have every right to get a dividend, if possible, whether it be in the form of a good service, or Consolidated Revenue.

Bodies such as Telecom and Australia Post obviously still need to expand their networks-particularly Telecom. Far too many people are still without telephone communications. It is obviously necessary that Telecom, instead of paying a dividend into the Government coffers, plough that money back into new services. I have no quarrel with that proposition and I doubt whether anybody in this chamber would. The more money we can plough back the more we can extend service and provide communications to those people who need them most.

I think Senator Lewis referred to Telecom's profits. He said that one reason for that profit was the fact that it is a monopoly; it does not have any opposition. That may be so, but I think the records would also show that right down the line since it became a statutory authority, with astute businessmen on its board, Telecom has been attempting, quite successfully, to apply business principles to its operations. Men have to account for their time and for the use of machinery and that sort of thing. There is obviously still a lot of work to be done in that regard. We owe it to the people of Australia to insist that it be done. The fact that it is being done with some success and that there is an increase in productivity means that Telecom has been able to reduce some charges and to hold other charges at a time when increased costs in private enterprise have been passed on to customers. The Government has that responsibility to consumers-that is, the telephone subscribers and the taxpayers-to ensure efficiency.

Senator Gietzelt spoke at length about selling Telecom. He did not mention Australia Post so much. There is no doubt that they have profitable areas. Once again, I think it would be the utmost folly of a government to sell off the profitable areas of Telecom or Australia Post. There is a fair bit of cross-subsidisation. Dare I mention that word which has caused so much discussion over the last few weeks in regard to airlines? There is massive cross-subsidisation in Telecom and Australia Post. Why should there not be? It is working quite well and it is providing for services and the expansion of services in rural areas. If we sold these instrumentalities-not that I have heard Government senators talk about it; it is mainly in the mind of Senator Gietzelt-there is no way in the world that anybody would want to buy the country services. It is not the Government's intention to sell them. It is the Government's intention to make them as efficient as it can. Anyone looking at buying an airline-for instance, Trans-Australia Airlines-could see from the profitability or return on invested capital that he could do much better with his money elsewhere. He would probably buy it for reasons other than sheer return on invested capital. That proposition applies to domestic and international airlines.

Senator Lewis mentioned the fact that the Commonwealth Government has imposed certain criteria on the running of Australian National Railways and that its board is applying business principles. It is meeting certain goals. The Commonwealth Government, as I recall, about two years ago suggested to ANR that within 10 years its revenue should exceed its operating expenditure. My last discussion with its General Manager revealed that he thinks it will achieve that. I think it will be quite some achievement if it can do that. It is a pity the State railway systems could not do the same thing. Last year-I may be wrong-we probably went pretty close to the railways of Australia losing $1 billion. We really cannot put our finger on any of that money. We do not know where it goes; the taxpayers continually pick up the tab. It is only the Commonwealth instrumentality, ANR, which is giving any credence to business principles. It is only ANR's governing body-that is, the Parliament of Australia-which has said: 'You have to meet certain criteria,' and ANR is attempting to do that. That shows that we are serious when we say that our public enterprises not only have a job to do but also should be efficient.

The same principle applies to the Australian National Line. As I understand the situation, ANL certainly has not paid a dividend to the Commonwealth for some considerable time and it has some mounting losses. But by the same token it also has been told how to operate. ANL hopes that it can turn the corner pretty quickly. One of the problems with ANL-this relates to what I said about the railways-is that we as the Parliament have to ask it to operate in a business-like manner, and yet it is competing with railways around the coastline of Australia which make fare or freight decisions without any commercial consideration. I think that some of the State governments have to look at their own operations and have to recognise that they owe to the taxpayers of Australia an accounting for where that money is going. I have no quarrel with subsidising a public utility-such as a railway if there is a social need for it. But let us identify the need. Let us get the system on a commercial basis, as we are doing with our public enterprises. If there is a loss let us identify whether there is a social need for the service being provided before we subsidise it.

I was quite interested to hear Senator Gietzelt criticise Government assistance to new industries in private enterprise. He referred to cheap electricity, cheap water and those sorts of things. The members of the Australian Labor Party seem to be pretty short-sighted if that is their total philosophy. I am not so sure that it is. Quite often, if we can guarantee a certain amount of electricity usage a new power station can be established, albeit at a contract rate. That ultimately means more work. It means that the industry is developed, and that means more work. There is more work in the associated industries, for instance, the fabrication and construction industries. I think the Opposition has a very short-sighted attitude. As a matter of fact, I think Senator Gietzelt is probably out of line with his own government in New South Wales and what it is doing in regard to aluminium smelters. I do not think there has been any failure by the Government to support and foster the development of Australia's major public enterprises.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have created more qangos than they have.

—I do not think that is something that Senator Rae likes to boast about. By the same token, we are making all efforts to make sure that they operate efficiently, that there is a minimal burden on the taxpayer. Because of our efficiency in that regard and the lower tax which is paid by the taxpayer, we can keep our deficit lower and, as a result, keep the consumer price index and our interest rates lower. At the same time we can provide more jobs than have ever been provided in Australia before. I reject the assumption implicit in the Opposition's matter of public importance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collard, in opening his remarks by dealing with Trans-Australia Airlines, of course hit on the point which is the immediate reason for this general matter of public importance being brought before the Senate today. It was only a couple of weeks ago that the Government announced that it intended to make TAA a public company. The Opposition and members of TAA with good reason, suspected and in fact are now sure that what the Government in fact intends to do is to sell TAA. Senator Collard denied this today. He said that the Government has no intention of doing that. We may, of course, do what Senator Rae wants to do and hand over control of TAA's shares to its employees under the Kelso plan. We really cannot rely on Senator Rae and we cannot rely on Senator Collard in this matter. I suggest we can rely on the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser).

SPEECH.PARA: The day after the announcement was made that TAA was to be made a public company Mr Fraser did an unusual thing: He held a Press conference. At that conference a well known journalist in this town, Mr Laurie Oakes, asked him a question. He said to the Prime Minister: 'Several times during the election campaign recently held you promised you would not sell TAA'. The Prime Minister's reply was not to say: 'We are not going to sell TAA. We are just going to make it a public company like Senator Rae wants us to do or we are just going to make it a public company with all government shares as Senator Collard wants us to do'. He did not deny that. In fact he said: 'Sometimes we have to make promises which we have to break under different circumstances'. He did not deny after several questions that in fact the Government's intention is to sell off TAA to private interests. Of course that is the intention of the Government and it is the view of what should happen of so many members of the Government parties.

I am always reminded in debates on this subject of some years ago when I was a member of the Senate select committee looking at a national compensation scheme. The evidence given to that committee by the head of the Life Officers Association was that his principle and his company's principles were that if a business is profitable it should be in private hands and if it is not profitable it should be in government hands. It seems to me that that is the attitude of so many members of the Government parties in this place. It is the attitude they take to the great public enterprise that Senator Button spoke about earlier. If they do not make a profit, they are condemned as inefficient by people like Senator Lewis. If they do make a profit, the first effort made is in fact to restrict their activities because profits made by private enterprises are so foreign and so much against government philosophy. If they continue to make profits every attempt is made in the long run to flog them off-something that has been advocated for TAA by Senator Rae and others for a long time.

I initially mention some of the public enterprises that have been so important to this country and the attitude of the predecessors of the present Government. For instance, one remembers that after the war there was a great need for the development of power and, secondary to that, irrigation facilities. The government of the day decided to develop the Snowy Mountains scheme, a scheme which incidentally since then has been praised by Government supporters for its imagination, for the efficiency with which it was built and for the efficiency with which it has been operated. That project was opposed vigorously by the Liberal-Country Party Government of the day. It was opposed to the extent that when the Snowy Mountains scheme was started every member of the Government parties, with the exception of Senator George Rankin from Victoria, boycotted the opening. They condemned it as an evil socialist enterprise which should never have been started. We never hear that sort of thing from the people who were in government at the time or who were the logical successors to that Government. We do not hear that sort of thing now and we have not heard it since then. But it was a typical demonstration of the attitude of the Government parties then and of the Government parties now.

Not only was that a great power scheme developed by public enterprise in that country but also one must remember that the development of the aluminium smelting industry in my own State of Tasmania started off as a public enterprise by a combined effort of Commonwealth-State governments, which held the majority of the shares, and private companies. As soon as the Liberal-Country parties took government they sold out with obscene haste the Commonwealth's share of the Commonwealth Aluminium Corporation. At roughly the same time they sold out the Commonwealth's share in the Commonwealth Oil Refineries. In doing so those parties did us a great disservice and they did the people of this country a great disservice because I suggest that public enterprises of this type have very important functions to play in this country in the development and the maintenance of our high standards of living. Firstly, such public enterprises are used to develop our resources which otherwise would not be developed. A typical example of that, I suggest, is the Snowy Mountains scheme. Another example, of course, is the Commonwealth Aluminium Corporation.

The second reason for developing such enterprises is to provide services which otherwise would not be able to be provided in this country. Of course the classic example of that-Senator Collard, being a Country Party member in this place, quite clearly alluded to it-was the effort of Trans-Australia Airlines in keeping, developing and maintaining what otherwise would be unprofitable air routes, particularly those in north Queensland, as a function of its operations, which function incidentally is vigorously defended by Senator Collard's party colleagues in Queensland in a most unusual way. Similarly the development of the Australian Broadcasting Commission has provided radio and in more recent years television services for areas of this country which otherwise would not have been provided by private enterprise.

The other important function, I suggest, of public enterprises like these is to give the people, through the Government of this country, a say in and a knowledge of what is happening in the development of some of our own crucial industries. I think it is a great tragedy that we have no direct knowledge, no direct idea of what is going on. For instance, one such industry in this country is the oil industry in which we would have been involved through our own Commonwealth instrumentality. The same thing could have happened if in fact we had a direct knowledge of what was happening in the aluminium smelting industry. We would have had that if the government of the day had not in fact sold off the Commonwealth Government's share.

The reason Senator Button has raised this discussion as a matter of public importance is that in the public eye, in the Opposition's eye, in the eye of the Press and certainly in the view of those people who are involved, those enterprises are seen to be under threat. In the case of TAA, we have the obvious threat to sell that public enterprise, a threat that was admitted by implication by Mr Fraser at his Press conference soon after the announcement was made. As Senator Gietzelt has said, in the case of Telecom, that most successful and most efficient organisation, there has been a limitation on its expansion in various areas of communication into which it would like to have moved and at the same time other organisations have been allowed into those areas. This has restricted Telecom's ability to develop in those areas. In the area of the pharmaceutical industry the Government sold off the Fawnmac group which was involved in the non-biological pharmaceutical area, an area which it was terribly important to develop. It was sold off for no reason other than that the previous Labor Government had bought it. Senator Gietzelt also mentioned the fact that the Government sold off the local brick works in Canberra merely because it was in fact a public enterprise. There is also the less publicised factor that the present Government is refusing to fund national roads in the various States if those roads are built by public authorities such as the Department of Main Roads in my own State of Tasmania.

There is in the Government's actions an attitude against the development of public enterprises. It is an attitude which has continued since the Government came to power. If we add to that attitude the sort of rhetoric that we hear particularly from people like the new Minister for Home Affairs and the Environment, Mr Wilson, from the Prime Minister himself, and from other Government members, on both the front and back benches, about the need for the public sector to keep out of areas like this and the need for the Government to develop only those areas which are controlled by private enterprise, there is set up an atmosphere in which the public enterprises of this country are in danger. One would think from hearing the rhetoric that comes from the other side of the chamber that public enterprise always had been bad for this country, yet we know that in so many areas-in hospitals, in health, in education, in communications, in the development of transport through the railways and through the national shipping line-the development of this country would have been greatly impeded; it would have been less efficient and the standard of living and the lifestyle of people in this country would have been greatly restricted if we had not had these efficient public enterprises operated by public servants who had the good of this country at heart.

It is disappointing in a debate on a general subject such as this to find that the best Senator Lewis can do is to give an anecdotal story about a group of people employed by Telecom-he admits he heard it some years ago-about how they were apparently relatively inefficient in laying the telephone wires at one farm that he had heard about. One can repeat anecdotal tales such as that over and over about public and private enterprises, but it gets us nowhere. No one on this side of the chamber is suggesting that we should in fact allow our public enterprises to be inefficient. We believe that enterprises, both public and private, should be efficient, that they should be carefully controlled and that they should do the job as economically and efficiently as they can. We will hear similar stories later on, I suppose, as we have heard in the past. We heard one from Senator Lewis about how nationalised industries are inherently inefficient. I am surprised that we have not heard about the losses made by, say, British Leyland in Britain; but, at the same time, we never hear about the losses made by General Motors-Holdens Ltd, for instance, in this country because it is not done to criticise private enterprise in that way.

We hear from the Prime Minister of this country that it is wrong for the Government, and the Government through public utilities, to enter into the development of the resources of this country. Therefore the Government sold off its share of the Ranger uranium mining enterprise. But, at the same time, the Government welcomes, and particularly our friend Senator Carrick welcomes, the investment in and the development of resources in this country by BP Australia Ltd, itself 46 per cent owned by the British Government, admittedly by Mrs Thatcher's conservative government. But it seems to us that to this Government Australian public enterprise is bad; public enterprise which comes from overseas is good and welcome. It is for this reason that Senator Button brought up this matter of public importance, first of all to try to get from the Government-and I am afraid we are not going to get it today-some clear idea of its attitude to the immediate problems which we see facing us. I refer to the immediate problem of Trans-Australia Airlines and the threat of selling it off, a threat which, as I say, was confirmed by the Prime Minister. We hoped to get some sort of answer to that problem and some sort of rational defence of the Government's general attitude to all our large public enterprises. It seems that we are not going to get this. I suppose it was a bit much of Senator Button to expect that we would get a response such as this.

In bringing up this motion we are confirming our belief that public enterprise has a place in this community, has had a place in the development of this country and in making it what it was in the past, and will have a place in the future. A future Labor government will not take part in the destruction of these efficient organisations which have done so much to make our standard of living what it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have spent some time now on a debate of a matter of public importance, the topic of which, given by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Button, is:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to support and foster the development of Australia's major public enterprises.

We were treated to the quite usual picture of Senator Button stridulating away as he is wont to do without really getting down to telling us what it was that we had not done or what it was that we had done wrongly. In fact we had to wait until Senator Grimes was speaking before we really found out what was the main concern of the Opposition in raising this matter as a matter of urgent public importance. I will therefore try to reply by putting the matter in context. What it really boils down to is that the Government has, it is alleged, failed to support and foster the development of major public enterprises because one or two of them have been sold. Some of the others, it has been suggested, should be restructured to make them more efficient and more effective. It is also alleged that in some other ways the Government is responsible for some loss of confidence among the employees and those associated with these operations.

If that is the complaint, let us look at the facts. The fact is that since the Second World War, that is, 35 years ago, there has been a Liberal-National Country Party Government for 29 years. A cynic could say, looking at Australia today, that the reason that the Australian Labor Party cannot get into office to implement its policy is that the Liberal-National Country Party coalition has been too busy getting in there first. So many areas of activity can be demonstrated, I think, by a story which used to be told by a former Prime Minister, Sir John Gorton. He used to tell the story of his having attended an international conference where he sat down to dinner with one of the leaders of one of the new socialist developing states. That gentleman endeavoured to persuade John Gorton that Australia was foolish in not adopting and applying socialism to all its industry and its basic economy. John Gorton said: 'Well, what sorts of things do you think should be nationalised? What sorts of things should be socialised? Transport?' The other fellow said 'Yes, of course', and John Gorton said: 'Well, we've already done that'. And we have. We have nationalised rail and shipping and two-thirds of our air transport-the other third is only operated under a big brother arrangement. Then John Gorton said: 'What about things like power and water supply and the distribution of them, and atomic energy and those sorts of matters?' The head of the new socialist state said 'Yes, of course', and John Gorton said: 'Well, we've already done those'. He finished up by going through the list-our sea ports, our airports, our communications, Telecom Australia, Australia Post, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission, Australia Post Courier and the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Our banks are effectively nationalised, law and order is conducted on a State basis, which one would expect it to be, and our primary industry is substantially socialised, shall I say, through primary industry marketing schemes. If we go on to look at what has happened in relation to insurance, housing, scientific development, in fact almost any area, we see there is either a significant, a major or a total government involvement when one takes the Commonwealth, State and local government levels and adds them together. The fellow said to John Gorton: 'But you are already so far ahead of us'. And we are.

What this country needs to be doing is reviewing whether that is really the stage that we wish to reach or whether some of those things which were desirable and which were important for the reasons outlined by various speakers are still appropriate to be conducted on a public enterprise basis today, or whether the stage has been reached at which we should be saying: 'No, the case for that being conducted on a monopolistic public enterprise basis no longer exists'. This is what the Government is doing today. It is reviewing, as it should review from time to time, the operation of public enterprise in Australia to determine whether it is the most appropriate, most efficient and most cost effective way of providing the types of services that are required in this country.

It might be taken that when I was saying that we had already done the job for the Australian Labor Party in socialising this country, I was saying that it was a disastrous thing to have happened. I am not saying that. I am saying that the coalition Government believes in a mixed economy and has practised a mixed economy effectively and with a recognition that nothing is permanent and that no aspect of public enterprise should be regarded as forever embedded irretriev- ably into one section, using one method for the performance of that function. It believes that, rather, we should ensure that questions are continually raised as to the efficiency and effectiveness of that enterprise and whether it is warranted.

I think one of the important points to make is that the more resources which we as a nation devote to public enterprise the more accountable we must ensure that public enterprise is. We must ensure that it is accountable, that it continues to be efficient and competitive and that its performance can be understood and compared with other means of achieving its objectives. I believe that each of the Opposition speakers in this debate has overlooked and mixed up two separate questions. One is: Should we have any government enterprises at all and if so, how many and in what areas? The second question is: Insofar as we have government enterprises, how should they be structured and funded, how should they be accountable and what performance indexes ought to be applied? I believe that Opposition speakers have been confusing two separate questions, endeavouring to paint some examples of what the Government has done in relation to the second question as if they were part of the answer to the first question.

I agree that in principle the Government parties espouse the cause of a private enterprise-based economy, but the record of the last 35 years shows that that cause is espoused, or perhaps honoured, more in the breach than in the observance. I think it would be very difficult to show that this Government-or its predecessor governments of the same parties-has not been very solicitous of the interests of public enterprise in Australia. In fact, the more attention that has been paid to this area by this Government, the more safe have been the positions of some public enterprises.

I refer again briefly to the Australian National Railways Commission which, as a result of the encouragement, enthusiasm and push it has received from this Government, has done what I believe to be an excellent job in restructuring and reorganising to the stage where it is far more efficient and far more cost effective for the provision of a necessary service in Australia than it appeared would be the case or, on the worst of projections, it looked almost certain would be the case. Its losses have not mounted as have the losses of British Rail whose losses have mounted because of the way in which that organisation is structured and managed and the lack of encouragement it has received. I think British Rail lost $1,000m last year. It might have lost a little more. That is a massive loss and it is increasing. But the Australian National Railways Commission has reduced its projected loss of over $100m for next year to $58m. That trend line is certainly encouraging for the sort of management approach which has been supported by this Government in relation to one or two public enterprises. I name just ANR as one example.

We have as a major question: What sort of structure is appropriate for public enterprise? Do we adopt the bureaucratic Public Service approach to a commercial or quasi-commercial enterprise, or do we give it a structure which is appropriate to the commercial environment in which it is expected to operate? I suggest that the second alternative is the answer. If we want public enterprise to engage in a commercial area of activity we should give it a structure which will enable it to operate in a way which is appropriate to the area in which it is to operate. Some of the bureaucratically minded socialists on the other side-I am not suggesting that that description applies to every Opposition member; I refer to some of the people who make noises on this issue-want to see a huge bureaucracy which the Government directly controls and manages, rather than public enterprise conducted through an appropriate structure in the most efficient way possible. Public enterprise should not have the dead hand of bureaucracy bearing down on its operation, but should have some opportunity to deliver the services or goods which it has been established to deliver in a competitive and efficient manner which can be regarded by everyone as an example.

I do not have the time to go into as much detail as I would like. I am glad that we have had an opportunity, and I hope that we will have further opportunities, to debate what I regard as a most important issue; that is, the continuing review to determine whether public enterprise is an appropriate means of achieving a national objective or whether it would be better for that service or function, at the current stage of development, to be carried out in some other way. The type of public enterprise which runs unchecked and the structure of which is inappropriate for its performance can create economic distortions-distortions of demand, distortions of cost and the remainder of the economic distortions which are the subject of a great deal of examination and writing. There is no need to argue as to whether they exist. The only question is whether they exist in each of the enterprises or only in some of them.

Let us take the problems of British Leyland and the British Steel Corporation. Last year over $2 billion was lost in the United Kingdom through what I believe is very largely a structures problem. That is one of the reasons why recently in this chamber I defended the idea of the Australian National Railways Commission changing its image, calling itself Australian National in the same way as the Myer Emporium became Myer and the Shell oil company became Shell in order to have a corporate identity with which people, the public and employees identify-an identity of which employees are proud and which can help to boost the confidence and enthusiasm with which people apply themselves to an enterprise. This is the sort of step which this Government has been encouraging so that we do not have the problems of British Steel, British Leyland and British Rail. I believe that far from being criticised for the steps the Government has taken it should be congratulated for recognising that in some areas of activity in Australia it is necessary to preserve public enterprise and that in other areas it may be possible and necessary to review and to sell. Where the case for public enterprise no longer exists, such as in the examples that have been given, a decision was taken that no public purpose was being served by continuing to have a particular undertaking carried out on a public enterprise basis.

In summary, the Government has done a great deal to lift morale, the competitive capacity and the competitive enthusiasm of public enterprises. It has done a great deal to lift the dead hand of bureaucracy from public enterprise at the same time as ensuring that public enterprise is fully accountable-as it must be-for what it does. I move:
That the business of the day be brought on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
