SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Freedom of Information Bill is a profound disappointment to those of us who hoped, perhaps naively, that at last after nine years of trying we were on the threshold of producing effective freedom of information legislation. The case for such legislation is overwhelming, and indeed it has been documented in overwhelming detail in the 1979 report on freedom of information by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, one of the most substantial and comprehensive reports ever presented by any committee to this Parliament. Stripped to its essentials, the argument for freedom of information is simply this: On the one hand, effective freedom of information legislation is necessary to improve the quality of decision-making on both policy and administrative matters in the public sector.

SPEECH.PARA: It is necessary to remove the unnecessary secrecy which can be used to conceal weak or inappropriate or sometimes even improper grounds for decision-making. It is necessary to enable groups and individuals to be kept informed of the workings of the decision-making process as it affects them and to have access to that process so far as that is appropriate and possible. It is necessary to enable groups and individuals who are affected by Government decisions, for example in the welfare and the legal aid areas, to know the kinds of criteria that will be applied by government departments and agencies in making those decisions. And not least, freedom of information legislation is necessary to maintain and improve the quality of our political democracy. That is the point the Senate Committee made very succinctly in a very early paragraph of its report. Paragraph 3.7 states:

The essence of democratic government lies in the ability of people to make choices: about who shall govern; or about which policies they support or reject. Such choices cannot be properly made unless adequate information is available. It cannot be accepted that it is the Government itself which should determine what level of information is to be regarded as adequate.

It is true that the quality of democracy ought not to depend, as it tends to at the moment, on the quantity of leaks. The leaks system, as it presently operates in the political process, might be very satisfactory for the insiders in that particular political process, including the Press, but it is not satisfactory as a basic operating rule for everybody else in the community, who all too often is unable to penetrate the barriers posed by that decision-making process. One of the nicest descriptions of the general public policy role of freedom of information legislation is that its object is to make the outsiders in the political process insiders, to put them, in effect, in the same position as those who have access to this system by virtue of privilege, commercial position or things of that kind.

The other quite different rationale for freedom of information legislation-it has little, on the face of it, to do with general public policy considerations but is an equally important consideration-is that it is necessary to enable individuals, except in very limited and exceptional circumstances, to have access to information which is held about them on government files: So that they know the basis on which decisions which can fundamentally affect their lives are made and so that they can have an opportunity to correct those files where the information contained is untrue or, as is equally often the case, misleadingly half-true. So freedom of information legislation has far-reaching implications in a civil liberty sense, from the point of view of personal individual issues and interests. And it also has crucially far-reaching implications so far as the whole conduct of public administration and government is concerned. It is for these reasons that this Bill is among the most important pieces of legislation ever to have been introduced in this Parliament.

Good freedom of information legislation-legislation which is genuinely worthy of that name-must satisfy a number of characteristics. For a start, it must ensure that a maximum amount of publicity is made available as to what kind of information will actually be available under the Bill and how access to it can be obtained in practice. It is all very well to have elaborate procedures technically available, but if at the very threshold considerations militate against a person knowing how to utilise those procedures, then they may not be worth having. Next, good freedom of information legislation is that which would set a minimum of procedural obstacles by way of delay or complexity or cost, and afford the maximum of practical assistance to those who are pressing requests for access to information. Again, such legislation would contain an absolute minimum of exceptions and exemptions.

A further characteristic of such legislation is that it would contain effective and easily utilised machinery for the review of and appeal against initially adverse decisions. It is also the case-I readily acknowledge this and I am sure that other members of the Senate Committee would do so-that, as a practical matter, good freedom of information legislation should not involve massive claims on the Public Service's or public sector's administrative resources, whether those resources be of time, personnel, or sheer dollars cost. It is also the case, and I and others, imagine, would readily accept it as a kind of combined practical and principle point, that good freedom of information legislation is that which is compatible with the basic principles of the Westminster or the parliamentary system of government we presently have, paying due regard to the role of Parliament and especially Parliament's relationship with the Executive branch and the Ministers who sit within the Parliament.

The trouble with the 1981 Bill now before us is that whilst it has had undoubted regard to the last two factors I have mentioned-the resource question and the question of compatability with the present system of government-in fact it has had a manifestly excessive regard to those sorts of considerations-it has fallen over so far backwards in its attempt to avoid placing any extra demands on the Public Service and to avoid intruding in any way on the present very cosy relationship that exists between Ministers and public servants that the Bill and those who have drafted it have simply lost sight of all the more basic and fundamental characteristics which have to be satisfied, before this kind of legislation is worthy of its name. The basic reasons that I for one am profoundly disappointed with this Bill now before us are essentially twofold.

In the first place, despite the very extensive and elaborate character of the report of the Senate Committee, to which I have referred, the Bill simply does not adopt more than a relative handful of the recommendations of that Committee. Those who presented it have not done the Parliament and the nation the courtesy of giving a fully argued, careful response to all the very detailed provisions and arguments in that report which have been rejected. The other ground for disappointment, to summarise it, is this: Not only is the new Bill not a really significant advance on its 1978 predecessor, despite the hopes which many of us had that the Committee's recommendations would be picked up in this way, but in fact it goes backwards in a number of significant respects, with a whole series of new exceptions and exemptions and procedural obstacles contained in it which were not contemplated, and certainly not contained, in the original version.

One can be left in no real doubt that all these problems-both the sins of omission and the sins of commission-have come about as a result of a continuing rearguard action fought by the Public Service, the senior echelons of which have fought this legislation in both its conception and execution every inch of the way. It is important to appreciate that the fight which lies ahead to improve this legislation is not really a struggle between the Government and the Opposition, in the traditional familiar sense that we are all used to. No doubt we, as an Opposition, will go on being critical about the way in which the Government, as a government, has handled some aspects of this matter. Indeed, one of the recurring themes in the whole history of freedom of information around the world is the way in which, for obvious reasons, it tends to be espoused as a concept rather more passionately by oppositions out of office than by governments sitting in office. The real battle that has to be fought out is between Parliament on the one hand and the Executive on the other-more particularly between Parliament and that arm of the Executive constituted by the Public Service. Many honourable senators on both sides of this chamber have been increasingly critical of the increased powers and perogatives of unelected bureaucrats in this country. Indeed, on the Government side of the chamber, we have heard a large number of speeches in the last couple of hours addressed to that theme. Freedom of information symbolises in a very graphic way the kinds of issues and principles at stake. If this battle is lost by the elected representatives of the people one can expect us to lose a great deal many more such battles in the future. These are the kinds of themes which are, in fact, picked up in the amendment which I have circulated. I move:
At end of motion, add
', but the Senate-

(a) expresses its concern at the failure of the Executive to explain adequately its rejection of most of the arguments and recommendations for legislative change contained in the unanimous 526-page report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs;

(b) regrets the excessive deference to bureaucratic influence that appears to have been involved in the rejection of significant Senate Committee recommendations and in the incorporation of significant new limitations on the scope and operation of the original 1978 Bill;

(c) expresses its hope that the Executive will in the course of the Committee stage debate give close and sympathetic consideration to the need for substantial amendment of the Bill if it is to be worthy of its name; and

(d) reaffirms its continuing commitment to the principle of effective freedom of information legislation, in the belief that such legislation is indispensable to both administrative justice and sound and effective public sector decision-making in the national interest'.

It will be noted that the reference in that amendment is to the Executive and not to the Government. That, of course, is to emphasise that my quarrel, our quarrel, in this debate is not so much with the Government as with the Executive arm of Government. That is to say, what this debate essentially is about is a parliamentary exercise rather than a partisan exercise, in the traditional, familiar sense. The other point I draw to honourable senators' attention is that the amendment does not, of course, oppose the second reading of the Bill in the sense of requiring that the Bill be withdrawn and redrafted or that it be sent off for yet another period of committee deliberation by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs or some other select committee. We have been there and we have done that. The task now simply is to improve the Bill that we have before us, and I for one look forward to getting on with the job.

Let me refer in a little more detail to the paragraphs of the amendment and draw attention to some of the themes contained within it. The first paragraph of the amendment draws attention to the failure of the Executive adequately to explain and argue for its position in rejecting significant numbers of Senate Committee recommendations for improvement of this Bill. The Government's explanations of its reaction to the Senate Committee report were contained primarily in a set of documents tabled in this place on 11 September last year. They are also contained now, I suppose, in the second reading speech of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) made last week accompanying the Bill. It has to be said that the arguments offered in these documents, at least when compared with the detail and scope of argumentation in the Committee report, are at best superficial and at worst derisory. They will need to be a whole lot more persuasive in the Committee stage of the debate if there is to be any legitimate ground for continuing to accept the Bill as it presently stands.

I will take as just one example the kind of argument which was made by the Senate Committee and which has clearly been rejected in nearly everything written by the Executive branch in responding to that Committee report. I take it also as an example because of its central character in underlining the whole thrust of the Executive reaction. The recurring theme in all this Executive response-is that there is something special about the Westminster system of responsible government that makes it inherently incompatible with far-reaching freedom of information legislation. It is suggested that a kind of transmission belt operates from public servants to Ministers, to Parliament and then to the public which it is absolutely wrong to bypass or to seek to intercept along the way; if we do this then the neutrality and anonymity of public servants and perhaps, even more importantly, the traditionally independent quality of the advice they offer will be put at risk and so too, it is argued, will be the responsibility, both individual and collective, of Ministers. What the Committee pointed out, indeed what it devoted a whole chapter to in its report and what indeed it was very concerned to do throughout the report, was to establish that this sort of sweeping preoccupation with the special character of the Westminster system as a bar to effective freedom of information legislation was totally misconceived. It is just not a good argument.

A number of points were made in support of the Committee's position. The first such point was that the traditional model of the transmission belt Westminster system is in fact idealised and bears very little relationship to what happens in the real world about us. In particular, the notion of individual ministerial responsibility is now, for all practical purposes, dead. Ministers simply do not resign on the basis of proven misbehaviour or proven maladministration within their own departments-although, of course, the traditional Westminster theory would have it that the responsibility of the Minister to Parliament for whatever happens in his department extends that far. Again, it is the case, as we all know, that senior public servants are no more anonymous than parliamentarians, some of them-John Stone of Treasury, I suppose, is the best current example-are much better known than most parliamentarians. Anonymity can remain a convenient shelter behind which to hide on occasion, but it is also something from behind which all too many public servants are all too happy to step as the particular occasion demands. Certainly, very few senior public servants these days-I do not criticise this in any way-feel any inhibitions at all about going public and putting propositions and statements down in the public arena.

As the Senate Committee argued in considerable detail, there is absolutely no reason to suppose, although some have continued to claim otherwise, or to suspect that freedom of information, and the prospect of ultimate disclosure that goes with it will affect the quality of the advice-the independent and professional quality of that advice-rendered by public servants to the ministry and to the public at large. I think the point was acknowledged by the Committee on the evidence before it that, if anything, the quality of that advice would be likely to improve. The point is simply that the overwhelming majority of public servants will go on being responsible, maintaining full and proper records and putting forward as best they can the best available information and advice. This is so simply because their own integrity and credibility and the efficiency of the whole public administrative system depend on it.

The adoption of the freedom of information legislation does not, of course, affect the basic element of responsible government, the presence of Ministers in the Parliament, in any way at all. It might be thought to have the potential for effecting the principle of collective responsibility or Cabinet solidarity if the freedom of information concept was taken into the Cabinet room to require the revelation of the details of Cabinet deliberations. But nobody, certainly not the members of the Committee, certainly not I and certainly not anyone on this side of the Parliament, is claiming that this Bill should extend that far. In other words-I think the point can be amply made at much greater length than I have time for now-there is nothing indispensable to the present parliamentary system of government which in any way is put at risk by the kind of effective, far-reaching legislation we are contemplating.

The real point that has to be made, which again is made very vigorously in the Senate Committee report, is that what matters when considering freedom of information is not whether a particular country has a United States of America style Presidential style of government or a United Kingdom style Westminster system of government, or anything in between; what matters is simply whether there is good government in that country. There is very little doubt that effective freedom of information legislation can contribute very substantially to that good government. Of course, nobody argues that all operations of government can or should ever be conducted in a goldfish bowl. Of course they cannot. Of course some matters must remain confidential at the time they are being discussed and negotiated. And of course it is true that some other matters-a lesser quantity-must remain, for practical governmental considerations, confidential for a good deal of time after that. But by and large there is not the case for maintaining confidentiality on anything like the scale that is contemplated in the terms of this Bill as it presently stands and in terms of the way in which the Executive has continually responded to the arguments that have been put forward by proponents of effective freedom of information legislation. There is very little in government that cannot be improved by letting a little bit of sunshine in. That is essentially the public policy motivation for this kind of legislation.

The failure to respond adequately to the arguments that have been put up for changes in the Bill has led in turn, of course, to a rejection-on occasion a cavalier rejection-of a very large number of specific Senate Committee recommendations. Of course I am not suggesting that everything recommended by the Senate Committee has been rejected. There were 93 specific recommendations with respect to this Bill, of which 71 sought specific legislative changes to the text of the Bill and another 22 sought administrative changes not requiring changes to this Bill. Of those 22 administrative changes the overwhelming majority of them, in fact, have been accepted. I think there is only one on which the Government is currently dragging its heels. So far, so good.

But when we turn to the 71 recommendations for legislative change-even if one gives the absolute benefit of the doubt to the Government in describing as an acceptance every merely partial acceptance of a Senate Committee recommendation-we find in this present Bill the adoption of only 21 of those 71 legislative recommendations and the explicit rejection, the non-appearance in the Bill, of another 50 of them. Of those accepted by no means all of them are or have been of an insignificant character. But it is clear that by and large the more important recommendations, the ones that really make a difference if we are to have effective freedom of information legislation, have been rejected.

In this area I am in complete agreement with what Senator Missen has been saying, particularly in his recently published list of 'seven deadly sins of omission'. I have no doubt that he will expand upon that in what he says. The main areas of the battleground clearly, in terms of the things that are out of the Bill but ought to be in it, are, for a start, those provisions recommended by the Senate Committee which would go to limit the practical effect of conclusive ministerial certificates, not least in the area of internal working documents-a description wide enough to include just about any piece of paper in government departments except that which comes in rolls, and perhaps even that as well.

There is also the question of the extension of the legislation to cover existing government records as well as those that are simply created in the future. There is the problem as to the overblown list of the grounds for exemption contained in the Bill as it now stands which needs to be much whittled back. There is the question of personal records and the necessity for there to be a right of individual correction where those records are wrong or misleading. There is the question of the multiplicity of specifically now exempt government agencies and classes of documents the number which needs to be drastically cut back if the Bill is to have any credibility. There is the question as to the role of the Commonwealth Ombudsman, the conciliatory, counselling and monitoring function, which ought certainly in the view of the Senate Committee, to be part of the Bill's explicit provisions. There is the question of secrecy provisions in the legislation. At the moment all other existing secrecy provisions are pretty well picked up and adopted in the explicit language of the Bill. They have in effect, an overriding role in making impossible, by virtue of their operation, access to documents which might otherwise be available but which are covered by those specific statutory provisions elsewhere.

In addition to those sins of omission the failure to correct deficiencies that were explored in the 1978 Bill, there is, as I have indicated, a rather more startling and unhappy list of sins of commission; that is, a whole series of new provisions which have appeared more or less from nowhere, certainly unexpected, and which have the role of imposing substantial additional limitations. I will simply list them for reference. They relate to clauses 32, 33, 38, 39, 35, 23 (2), 21 (1), 8 (6), 9 and the Schedule. I regret that I do not have the time to explore them fully. However, I can assure the Attorney that there will be ample time to do so at the Committee stage of this Bill. I will have no hesitation-and I imagine that many other senators in the chamber will not hesitate-in seeking explanation as to why, if anything, the Bill has not only not gone forwards but also gone backwards by the incorporation of new measures of this kind.

The main thrust of the second paragraph of the amendment which is now before the chamber is to draw attention-as in fact I have already done in general terms-to the sins, in particular, of the bureaucracy in producing the kind of Bill we have at the moment. There appears to have been undue deference to the whims and wishes of senior public servants. Indeed, that has extended all the way back with only a handful of honourable exceptions-and by and large I would put the Attorney-General's Department in that category-to the original conception of this Bill before 1972. The role of the Public Service was made very evident in the contents of the original interdepartmental committee reports of 1974 and 1976, which are the best demonstrations I have heard of the accuracy of that definition of committees generally as culs-de-sac into which good ideas are lured and quietly strangled.

That was made equally evident in the oral evidence given before the Committee by a number of senior officials from a number of senior departments-most memorably perhaps by John Stone of Treasury-and also in some of the extravagant and overblown claims about the resource implications of proposed amendments which were made by some departments and agencies in their written evidence. It has been evident again in the campaign which largely has been conducted not publicly but in back rooms and in the Commonwealth Club by a number of senior public servants and departments involving, in particular, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of Foreign Affairs, the Department of Finance and the Department of the Treasury, but with the leader of the pack undoubtedly being the Public Service Board and Sir William Cole, who I have described elsewhere in this context as being a kind of Gordon of Khartoum figure, determined that freedom of information will be won only over his dead bureaucratic body.

The third paragraph of the amendment makes obvious the point that substantial amendments are necessary if this legislation is to be worthy of its name. It has become a cliche to say that a more appropriate name for this Bill, like its 1978 predecessor, is not the Freedom of Information Bill but the Freedom from Information Bill. That cliche conceals a very real truth and that is the very real danger that this kind of legislation in practice will not become a gateway for giving access to information hitherto denied but rather will constitute a check list of reasons why information should, in fact, be refused. There is ample evidence of the way in which public servants are now-even before this Bill has any statutory force-in fact, using the formulae in the earlier drafts of this Bill to justify refusals to give information. Perhaps the most succinct, available list of such exercises is Senator Missen's collection of 35 responses to answers for questions which is contained in the appendix to the Senate Committee report.

The final paragraph of the amendment contains a reaffirmation of the basic principles of freedom of information which I-and certainly I believe a number of other senators all around this chamber-believe it is crucial to make at this time so that it will act as a kind of touchstone which we will not lose sight of in all the detailed debate which will undoubtedly follow in the next few weeks. It is the case that freedom of information legislation is, as the paragraph of the amendment states, indispensible to administrative justice for individuals. And it is the case that it is indispensible to sound and effective public sector decision making in the public interest.

The present Bill, despite all the time, effort and controversy that have gone into its preparation, is not a good, effective, Freedom of Information Bill. It is our task, not as an Opposition or as a collection of unhappy individuals around the chamber, but rather as a Senate, as a Parliament, as elected representatives of the people, to make it a good, effective, Freedom of Information Bill. The extent to which we succeed, as a co-operative legislative exercise, in improving this Bill will be an excellent measure of the seriousness with which we are entitled in the future to describe ourselves as legislators and as parliamentarians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One speaks on the Freedom of Information Bill for the first time with somewhat mixed feelings. After campaigning for nine years for a Bill such as this, one finds a Bill of which one must be very critical. It is a Bill which introduces into this Parliament, for the first time, the concept of freedom of information. This is the first debate on that concept. Unfortunately it is a Bill with many defects-many of them have been explained by Senator Evans and many will be touched on by other honourable senators-and one realises that there is a very big task ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been interested in this subject for many years. I have been overseas to study the success which freedom of information has brought in the United States. After certain false starts and after overriding the will of the President on occasions, the Americans have been able to make freedom of information a very important addition to the democratic system and really to transform the situation. I and others have seen that in this country and in other countries there has been a growing interest in the need for freedom of information-that is, the opening up of government documents and material, the making available to ordinary members of the public and to members of parliament and to others a lot of material which for a long time has been retained by the Public Service and in the executive domain and which has not been allowed to be seen by the ordinary members of the public.

That public interest has grown in this country. It was demonstrated by the great deal of interest shown by the people who gave evidence before the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. It was demonstrated also by the many organisations which have been campaigning for a genuine freedom of information Act in this country. We have seen this interest growing during the term of office of different governments. Freedom of information is not a party political question. I have been campaigning for this Bill during the term of office of governments of different complexions, and I must say that one finds that there is resistance-perhaps not so much by governments but by those in the top echelon of the Public Service who have a great deal to hide. By that I mean in the sense that they want to keep a comfortable situation continuing unchanged. Unfortunately, we seek to tear down that veil.

One significant factor is that the Public Service in this community-that is, the people who work for the Government and who produce and receive documents for the Government-has grown enormously in the 80 years of Federation. At the time of Federation, something like 5 per cent to 6 per cent of the work force worked for the Government. It is now near to one-third. This has translated itself into an enormous amount of material held by the Government in the form of reports, advice, specialist activity and correspondence. All of these documents remain in the Public Service. Consequently freedom of information becomes even more important in a community in which we recognise that government activity has so much involvement in the affairs of the country.

Today we are engaged in the second reading debate on this Bill. I will be supporting the motion for the second reading of the Bill. I believe taken all in all it is better to vote for the Bill. But I expect that when we consider the Bill in Committee we will need to do a great deal to make it worthwhile. We will need to ensure that in curing the defects in the Bill we avoid the situation where the public of this country will become cynical because they see no real results in relation to freedom of information. That is the danger with which we face and which we must overcome.

We also have this situation: There is something of a struggle so far as the committee system of this Parliament is concerned, in the handling of this matter. As Senator Evans has said, the Senate Committee, of which I have the honour to be the Chairman, spent some 15 months studying this question, calling evidence, travelling across the country, trying to find out what were the needs and worries of various people, what were the worries of public servants-and we had many public servants before us. I base my attitude on that Committee's report, which was unanimous and which stands unchallenged in the public debate in this country. I stand behind the recommendations that our Committee adopted. Some 93 of them refer to this Bill. I believe the recommendations were based upon fact and sound argument. I await any consideration and any argument that shows that any of our various representations and conclusions were unsound.

The Committee received 168 submissions and took evidence from 129 witnesses. As I say, it had many public servants before it, and it examined the various problems which were put to it as fundamental difficulties to be faced by a freedom of information system in this country. Reference has already been made by Senator Evans to the claims which were made-they were made repeatedly-that somehow the development of the concept of freedom of information was contrary to the fundamentals of the Westminster system of government. This has often been said but it has not been established. We heard a lot of evidence and had a lot of submissions to this effect. We concluded that there was nothing fundamental in the Westminster system which would in any way be harmed.
Indeed, we concluded that certain features of that system would be strengthened by the establishment of an effective freedom of information system.
I want to refer to the conclusions contained in paragraph 4.62 of the Senate Committee report. After hearing all the evidence the Committee said:

We value the Westminster system of government; we do not seek to change it; nor do we believe effective freedom of information legislation would change it. A great deal of the talk about the Westminster system and how it would be altered by freedom of information legislation has been obscure and misleading. To a great extent the term 'Westminster system' has been used as a smoke-screen behind which to hide, and with which to cover up existing practices of unnecessary secrecy. Very often people have alleged that the Westminster system is under attack by freedom of information legislation when what is actually under attack is their own traditional and convenient way of doing things, immune from public gaze and scrutiny. We are indeed seeking to put an end to that.

We are certainly aiming to put an end to that. That, I think, is the cause of the considerable background criticism and resistance to this Bill. It is not more than criticism in the background, because when we read the newspapers, or if we read the correspondence to the newspapers, if we listen to the radio and television commentaries and statements, if we listen to the public in the street, there is nowhere to be found any defence of the Government's very limited Bill. Indeed, there is a great deal of criticism of the Bill and a great deal of support for the recommendations of the Senate Committee. That is the strength which those of us who support the amendments to the Bill have.

I support the second reading of the Bill. I also support the amendment which Senator Evans has moved this afternoon. It is a very moderate and sensible amendment which calls upon the Executive to reconsider its decision, to look again at the recommendations of the Senate Committee, and, in the Committee stage, to adopt a sympathetic consideration for the need for substantial amendment to the Bill. I cannot imagine that people could oppose or object to that. I think it is very important that we not only complete this debate but also adopt that amendment. Let us hope that consideration will be given to improving the system.

I have said that one of the matters which we dealt with at great length in the report-we stand by that-was the Westminster system. Second to that was another matter which has also been mentioned to some degree by Senator Evans, and that is the resource implications of the Bill. It has constantly been put, either against any freedom of information Bill at all or against the proposals which we now espouse, that somehow there would be an enormous amount of demand on the resources of the community. When one looks at the situation in different countries, particularly the United States of America where there is considerable demand one finds that it is possible for countries to cope. People talk about the enormous expenditure involved. In the United States the costs involved over the last few years were something like $35m a year. But the cost of public relations activities by the United States Government totals about $1,000m a year. The same type of situation applies in this country, where a great deal of money is spent by government on public relations, including the presentation of glossy publications. All governments do that. But the amount that will need to be spent on freedom of information is unlikely to be anything like that amount.

We commented on that aspect in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. In the course of our hearing we heard a lot of evidence on claims that excessive costs and excessive demands would be involved in instituting freedom of information. In our report we pointed out, among other things, the following in paragraph 6.19:

Although the Government has not promised to provide specific resources for freedom of information legislation, it has approved the allocation of some of the resources of the public service to the reform. We believe that the public service has the capacity to use this mandate with vigour and with success, and that it can do so, by and large, at less cost than critics of the proposed legislation assume.

We saw areas in which existing resources in the public relations field could be used in providing freedom of information. It is true that there is a difference between the two fields: Whereas governments like to publicise matters which are pleasant and supportive, providing freedom of information tends to permit the exposure of matters which are awkward, untimely and embarasssing for governments. However, such information is needed by people who are desirous of entering into public debate and of being informed on issues covered in that debate.
On the matter of costs, the Committee stated further, in paragraph 6.46 of its report:

When this question was last publicly examined . . . the direct cost of the government information sections amounted in all to some $51 million: early in 1975, some 800 staff were employed in special information sections in departments, and further large numbers were employed in the statutory authorities. Agencies responding to our own question, asked in the Public Service Board Survey, as to the number of people employed at present in preparing manuals and supplying information to the public, confirmed that some hundreds of public servants are engaged in this work.
Further, we drew attention to the 1976 interdepartmental committee report, which observed:

. . . part of the apparent 'freedom of information' workload of departments could perhaps more properly be regarded as a continuation of existing departmental services of providing information to the public.
Those are the words of the government IDC which advised on the matter. In our report we went on to recommend:

. . . the task force to which we have referred should take our findings and recommendations into account so that the procedures associated with freedom of information and with the provision of governmental information can be properly brought together and savings made.

A great deal of consideration was given to the resource implications. We believed that our recommedations were moderate. We moderated them for the very reason of keeping costs down and keeping down the level of demand resulting, in the early years, from the implementation of freedom of information legislation. I believe that it is accepted not only here but also in Canada and other countries that it is possible, by phasing in certain elements, including time limits and matters of prior documentation, to take into account resource demands. Therefore, we believe that the Senate Committee's recommendations should have been accepted. In formulating them we took into account the very major considerations and objections which were raised by the people who came before us. Unfortunately, most of our recommendations have not been accepted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting I had traced to some extent the history of the effort which we in this country have made to obtain freedom of information. I have spoken of the support which I am giving to the second reading of the Bill and to the amendment moved by Senator Evans. I also said that the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs believed that its report really faced up to the real problems, the real questions that have been asked about freedom of information, and had contained recommendations which the Committee felt had covered those important questions. But we now find ourselves in a situation in which many of those most important recommendations have been rejected and are not in the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now, therefore, to the 1981 Bill which contains some minor changes made to the Bill which was introduced in 1978 but which was never debated. The new Bill has picked up some of the recommendations of the Senate Committee, but unfortunately, with one or two exceptions, they are relatively minor ones. Certainly the new Bill takes up the suggestion that commercial interests and commercial secrets should be protected and that people with genuine interests ought to have the right to be heard before the Tribunal and to appeal against decisions to release information. The new Bill incorporates other useful suggestions, but at the same time incorporates a number of other procedural hurdles, difficulties, for people to overcome to get information from government. All in all, it is very doubtful whether much improvement has come from the changes.

Recently I took the opportunity of writing what I have described as the seven deadly sins of omission in the Bill. In the document I set out what I consider to be the major defects of the Bill. For the sake of convenience-I have spoken to the responsible Minister and to the Leader of the Opposition about this matter-I seek leave to incorporate that document in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
THE SEVEN DEADLY SINS OF OMISSION
from the
Federal Government's 1981 Freedom of Information Bill

(1) Conclusive Ministerial Certificates The Government refuses to abandon the provisions which deny any right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against refusals to disclose government documents in many important areas and the Bill provides that the Minister's certificate is to be final and unchallengeable. The major areas affected are: documents relating to national security, defence, international relations, relations with States, cabinet and executive council documents and the determination of what is 'contrary to the public interest' in relation to 'internal working documents'. Internal working documents are widely defined as covering the 'deliberative processes' involved in the functions of an agency, Minister or Government and therefore are likely to cover a vast majority of government records. Any material marked by a State government or official as 'confidential' may be denied to the public without any right of challenge. One State Government has already indicated its intention to mark all its communications 'confidential'.

Compare the Canadian FOI Bill, now triumphantly passing through the Canadian House of Commons, where all parties insist on a right of appeal, in these areas, at least as wide as the Australian Senate Committee's proposals for a review on the proper categorization of the document.

(See Clauses 28, 29, 30, 31 and 48 of the FOI Bill and the Senate Constitutional and Legal Affairs Report on Freedom of Information '(Senate Committee Report)' Chapters 13, 16, 17, 18 and 19 and Paragraphs 5.10 to 19 and 27.9 to 22)

(2) Existing Government Records With one minor exception, the FOI Bill will not apply to or give access to prior or current documents in government hands but only to documents created after the Bill comes into operation. Thus the vast array of existing reports, correspondence and other records, compiled at the taxpayers expense, will remain secret. The Bill makes no provision for the phasing in of existing records (many of them of current significance) over a period of years as proposed by the Senate Committee Report. Compare, again, the Canadian Bill which provides for a phasing in of existing records over a period of five years.
(See Clause 11 (2) of the Bill and Paragraphs 6.34 to 38 and 14.1 to 19 of the Senate Committee Report).

(3) Grounds of Exemption of Documents The Senate Committee recommended substantial amendments to the grounds for rejection of access to documents that were set out in the 1978 FOI Bill. It proposed the deletion of three grounds and the clarification of the language of others. Experience has regrettably shown that senior bureaucrats will take advantage of vague powers and loose expressions to refuse access to documents. The 1981 Bill substantially rejects those Senate Committee proposals, adds a number of further grounds of exemption and, in redrafting exemptions, adds to the documents that may be withheld. Furthermore, new provisions increase the administrative powers of officials to deny access.
The 'right to know'-the access to government records-is thereby further reduced. The accompanying Archives Bill extends the same exemptions on access absurdly to documents more than thirty years old.
(See Clauses 8, 15, 20, 21, 23, 28 and 43 of the Bill and Chapters 15 to 26 and 33 of the Senate Committee Report)

(4) Personal Records The new Bill makes no provision for the Senate Committee recommendations that individuals should have a right to know what information is held in government records about them, to have access to and to inspect records and have them corrected, where the information is false or inaccurate. Protection of individual rights and privacy should go hand in hand with freedom of information.
(See Paragraphs 24.16 to 18 of the Senate Committee Report)

(5) Exempt Government Agencies The new Bill is improved by the inclusion, in the Schedules, of the various agencies which the Government proposes to exempt either entirely from the FOI requirements or to exempt as to specific classes of documents, for example 'documents in respect of its competitive commercial activities'. What is alarming is the number and range of exempt agencies proposed (and which can be added to by subsequent regulations).

Twenty-four agencies, including the intelligence agencies, banks, TAA and a miscellaneous selection, are to be totally exempt, and nineteen other agencies are to be exempt as to certain classes of documents.
The exemptions are excessive and some that are totally exempt should merely be exempt as to specific classes of documents. It is a further unnecessary inroad into the public's right to know.
(See Clause 6 and Schedules Part I and II of the Bill and Chapter 12 of the Senate Committee Report)

(6)Ombudsman's Conciliatory, Counselling and Monitoring Roles in FOI The Bill substantially rejects the Senate Committee's proposals for an effective involvement of the Ombudsman in the practical utilization of FOI. Since the right of successful applicants for reimbursement of costs incurred in enforcing their rights was rejected by the Government, there was even more reason to employ the Ombudsman to assist applicants, by negotiations with government agencies, by representing them before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and generally in monitoring the effective operation of the FOI Act. Those proposals are almost totally ignored in the 1981 Bill.

The Canadian Bill creates an equivalent office of Information Commissioner to assist the citizen in exercising his rights, and the same practical assistance, through the Ombudsman, is called for in Australia.
(See Clause 47 of the Bill and Paragraphs 6.42 and 3, 9.11 and 12, 13.8 and 9, 19.26, 27.4 and 5, 27.23-28, and generally Chapter 29 of the Senate Committee Report)

(7) Secrecy Provisions in Existing Legislation The Senate Committee drew attention to the vast array of secrecy provisions in existing Commonwealth legislation, prohibiting disclosure of information. These are contained in the Commonwealth Crimes Act, and in 109 Acts of Parliament, 85 other Commonwealth Rules, Ordinances and other legislation. (Listed in Appendix 6 of the Senate Committee Report).

Many existing provisions are inconsistent with FOI principles and the 1981 FOI Bill. The Senate Committee proposed that a list of the secrecy provisions that are to be retained, be prescribed in the FOI Bill that they be brought into line with the criteria contained in the exemptions in the Bill, and that other secrecy provisions be repealed.
The proposals have been rejected and apparently no action is to be taken to reconcile the new FOI rights with inconsistent existing laws.
(See Clause 33 of the Bill and Chapter 21 of the Senate Committee Report)
A Freedom of Information Attitude

Taken together, these deficiencies remove a very large part of government information from public use. Yet I have dealt only with some major objections to the Bill. A Freedom of Information law which contains these defects will make a nonsense of public expectations for the opening up of government documents, will provide ready weapons for senior bureaucrats in denying access to inconvenient facts and will add to public cynicism.
Two statements are worth repeating:
Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser said (22/9/1976)

'If the Australian electorate is to be able to make valid judgments on government policy it should have the greatest access to information possible. How can any community progress without continuing and informed and intelligent debate? How can there be debate without information?'

Parliament's duty now is to create a FOI Act that does make the greatest access possible and which accords with the true expectations of those to whom it has been promised in repeated election campaigns.
The second statement is that of the Canadian Progressive Conservative leader (Mr Clark) when, as Prime Minister, he introduced a Freedom of Information Bill.
'The starting point for a freedom of information law is a freedom of information attitude.'
This is the time to find out whether Australians have that attitude and whether they will insist on an appropriate FOI law.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In that document I have set out the seven major defects. Of course, I will not go into them in any detail, but I just want to repeat what they are, in my view. In the first place, the conclusive ministerial certificate stands out as probably the worst defect in the present Bill because it covers a great many of the documents that ought to be released and because it gives Ministers the absolute right, by certificate, to refuse to disclose documents, and thereby denies to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal any opportunity to investigate whether they are documents of the sort that should not be released or whether in any way the exemption claimed for them is justified. It covers a great many areas. It also covers such a wide area of 'internal working documents'-the deliberate processes of government or of a department-that it is my estimation that the great majority of documents in the Government's hands may well be covered by that one exemption alone.

SPEECH.PARA: It also covers documents which the State governments and their agencies sent to the Commonwealth and which they may claim are confidential. One of the problems which the Senate Committee faced in the evidence it took was that presented in the material placed before it by Sir Charles Court, the Premier of Western Australia. He claimed that by the Bill, which remains unaltered today, the State governments would be placed in a difficult situation. I want to read a small extract from his submission to the Committee. He said:

In all these appeals, there is no provision in the Bill for the State Government to be consulted or participate in the decision-making process leading to the disclosure or non-disclosure of State Government documents.
I firmly believe that the Bill should be amended to provide for State participation in decisions as to whether a certificate should be issued under Clause 23 (2)--
That is now clause 28 (2)-
and, in cases where such a certificate is not granted, as to whether State Government documents should be disclosed.
As the Bill is presently drafted, the State may have to mark all of its correspondence to the Commonwealth 'confidential' so as to bring its documents within Clause 23 (1) (b).
That is now clause 28.
I would hope that this need not occur and that the Bill can be amended as I have suggested.

The Bill has not been amended as Sir Charles Court suggested. So we may be in the ludicrous position in which all documents coming from some of the States will be marked 'confidential', will be confidential and will not be disclosed thereafter because of certificates given by the Commonwealth; and a great deal of information which ought to be within the public domain and which ought to be known by the citizens will not be available. Moreover, the States will not have the right to approach the Tribunal to suggest that there are good reasons for non-disclosure. The conclusive ministerial certificate is just one problem, and it is a very bad one indeed.

The second omission concerns existing government records; a great mass of material will not be made available to the public. Of course, that will mean that much of this legislation will not be in real and active operation for many years. Access will be denied to all existing records, many of them personally involving individuals. I come to the third omission. The grounds of exemption, which the Senate Committee claimed were much too wide, have been extended to some degree in the new Bill. There have been some redrafts and some improvements. At the same time the Committee's idea that three of the grounds were unnecessary has been ignored and three other grounds have been added. If we look at the lengthy exemptions, we find a very interesting situation. In the very excellent and successful United States Freedom of Information Act there is one page of grounds, but in Australia six pages are needed to describe the grounds for exemption.

I turn to the fourth omission. Personal records are not to be made available, nor will there be any right of correction of records which are ill-advised, wrong, false or just misleading. The fifth omission concerns the position of exempt government agencies, as described in the Schedules. I say little more than that there are too many of them, that some of them are given exemption far beyond the needs of the community and that we must examine them very closely. Next, the Ombudsman has been denied his conciliatory, counselling and monitoring roles which the Committee recommended. This is of great significance. In Canada there is to be an information commissioner with all the necessary powers. The Canadians, under their Bill, as I will tell the Senate, have managed to give powers which are denied to the Ombudsman here in Australia.

Finally, the secrecy provisions in the law-those that apply to 109 Acts of Parliament of the Commonwealth and to 85 pieces of legislation-are not to be reviewed or reduced. Many of them will stand there in contradistinction to the freedom of information law. This new legislation is analagous to a good looking apple from which four or five pieces have been eaten; it is only a core and is not of much use. I do not know that our job is to restore the apple, but our job is certainly to restore to the public the 'right to know'. I have said that the Canadians are doing it differently. The Canadians are in a parallel position to us. They live in a very similar federal democracy which regards the Westminster system as very important. In Canada all the parties are agreed on a very significant and important freedom of information Bill. On 29 January of this year they unanimously adopted the second reading of that Bill and are now considering it clause by clause in the Committee stage. Senator Durack, in his second reading speech, after discussing the various countries which are either passing or trying to pass freedom of information laws, said:
Each of the proposals I have mentioned has incorporated the same basic approach as is in the present Bill.

I have to say that I do not think that is so. I think there are great differences between the proposed laws in these other countries, and particularly in Canada, and this one which we have before us. Senator Durack went on:
In addition, there are differences in the nature of the parliamentary institutions in each country, which affect the relationships between Ministers and the Parliament.

I have to say again that I do not think there is any real difference at all between our country and the Canadian nation, which I think will have a very good freedom of information law in a little while. In addition, the Canadian provinces, as they are called, and the Canadian Government have an impetus towards freedom of information. The Ontario Government has in fact had an inquiry going into freedom of information for some years, and now has an excellent report and will soon have an Act on the statute book. When the report came down, the Government of Ontario gave the order that public servants were to obey it immediately as though the legislation were already in operation and that they were already to apply the spirit of the recommendations. In Australia we have not done so. Likewise, unfortunately, our States have not taken initiatives. They are waiting until the Commonwealth has finished dealing with its law. Unfortunately, there has been something of a different spirit in the governments of Australia compared with the governments of Canada which are prepared to experiment and to go forward. The present Leader of the Opposition in Canada, Mr Clark, when he was Prime Minister, referring to the freedom of information Bill which he introduced in the House at that time, said:
The starting point for a freedom of information law is a freedom of information attitude.

I think it is important that we develop-in the next few weeks I hope we develop this much more in this community-a freedom of information attitude not only by governments and by public servants but also by people and by organisations which really want to see this law operate. We have had a habit of secrecy in this country for a long time. Even people who have come to this country have noticed it. In 1969 the Canadian Government task force looked at Australia, among other countries, and concluded in these terms:
Totalitarian capitals apart, only official Canberra comes close to matching that special air of furtive reticence which marks the Ottawa mandarins off from other men.

I do not think there has been a great change since 1969. The rather successful efforts to date of the mandarins of Canberra have managed to keep this Bill from being very effective. It has been mentioned by Senator Evans already that a couple of years ago I put down some 35 parliamentary questions and got answers. An analysis of those questions and answers is to be found in our Senate Committee report, at pages 481 to 484. The report contains answers which public servants gave before the Bill was even tabled, to all these relatively minor requests for information. Of course, we see the answers some of them 'would be prejudicial to international relations' and others were 'internal working documents'. They used the very phrases which are in this Bill. We may be sure that if those phrases are loose and widely used as excuses for denial of documents they will also be used by public servants to deny access to much information after the Bill is passed.

We know also that in respect of the local scene there has not yet been a great deal of effort to get ready for freedom of information. The Australian Consumers Association, in a report which it made in the last few days, noted:

. . . there was great variation between the departments in their state of readiness for the implementation of FOI legislation and also, apparently, in the attitude adopted towards requests for information.
The Association further noted:
. . . the majority of Departments had not appointed staff to positions specifically dealing with the implementation of FOI legislation.

We must come to the conclusion, therefore, that we have a battle on our hands and that in fact we must prepare and complete a Bill and an Act which will be watertight and which will not allow loose ends. We cannot afford to have enormous sweeping exemptions. We cannot afford to cut a lot of people off from their rights. We cannot afford to have undue costs and undue requirements which will stop people or which cause them to lose enthusiasm in their attempt to improve the level of information and public debate in this country. It is for these reasons that we fight on in this battle. Though I hope this Bill will pass the second reading stage, I hope it will be enormously improved in the Committee stage and honourable senators on both sides of the chamber will do their best to ensure, with the help of the public and of organisations which see the value of having really informed public information and public spirit in this country, that this is a good Bill.

I therefore say that if open government is to mean something in this country, this is the one opportunity. It is not good enough to pass a weak Bill now and hope that it might be improved in ten years' time. The lack of enthusiasm, the crushing of the spirit of the people who have endeavoured to do something about the state of public discussion will be such that we will probably take a long time to improve it. I say that we must therefore ensure that today and in the weeks to come we create a good, strong Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I applaud Senator Missen for his closing remarks because I think they set the keynote for all those people in this country-there is an increasing number of them-to whom this has now become a vitally important issue. It is perhaps as important as any issue in the country, even to people who are concerned with the cost of health care, the cost of bringing up a family, inflation, unemployment. All those things are important, but I suggest they have an involvement with the Freedom of Information Bill. I should like to commence my comments in the second reading debate on the Bill with two quotations. The first is from the High Court judgment on the Fraser Government's application for an injunction regarding the book Documents on Australian Defence and Foreign Policy 1968-1975 which will be well known to honourable senators. In that judgment of 1 December 1980 Mr Justice Mason said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is unacceptable in our democratic society that there should be a restraint on the publication of information relating to the Government when the only vice of that information is that it enables the public to discuss, review and criticise Government action . . .

I should like to stress those final words 'the only vice of that information is that it enables the public to discuss, review and criticise government action'. So far as the Australian Democrats are concerned, those words could not put the situation better. That is what we want. We want a Freedom of Information Bill which will allow that to happen-continuous discussion, review and criticism of government action-because that is the only way in which a free and independent society can preserve itself. The second quotation I wish to give is from Mr Alan Renouf, former Australian Ambassador to the United Nations and now an almost passionate advocate of open government. He says that it is because of his experiences as a public servant that he is such an advocate of open government. On 3 December 1980 he said:

. . . the theory behind the classification of documents is often . . . the less you reveal to the public . . . the less opportunity the public has to review your actions. Keep them in the dark as much as possible and when there is any doubt, classify!

There I think we have Mr Justice Mason's cri de coeur of what should happen and then an experienced diplomat's view of what does happen. I think we ought to be guided by the views of those two men. The debate on the so-called Freedom of Information Bill presents me with an extraordinary temptation. I am almost tempted to move an amendment to the actual short title of the Bill. Maybe something like the Public Secrets (Preservation) Bill would be appropriate. If I wished to devise legislation which would make it as difficult as possible for journalists, researchers and the public to gain access to the vast bulk of official information in this country, I would regard this information as it now stands as a promising beginning. Indeed, that is the vast irony, the vast tragedy of the situation with this Bill which has been in gestation for so long-almost a decade one way or another-and which pretends to provide the Australian community with adequate freedom of information law in fact does exactly the opposite. Its almost constant preoccupation is with definitions of what information may not be given and what organisations are immune from the giving of information. As both Senator Evans and Senator Missen have said-I think this will come up time and time again during the Committee stage of the Bill-very few reasons are given for this. There is no rationalisation for a great deal of this. It is arbitrary. It is very important to note at this stage that the Government has not really tried to justify this Bill. It has said the Bill does a certain thing but it has not really explained the gaps and the holes in it and the reason why it is the way it is. The Australian Democrats suggest that this is because the Government has come under the strongest possible pressure from the bureaucracy and that it has yielded to that pressure. Not only has it yielded to that pressure but also it has done so in the teeth of a reasoned investigation by Senator Missen's committee of this matter with evidence being given by virtually everybody in this country who might have an important contribution to make and also in the face of a degree of public interest in the issue which has led not to one but to several organisations of citizens being founded purely to see that the Bill is changed as much as possible along the lines recommended by Senator Missen's committee.

It is an extraordinary fact-the fact that we become blase about these things in this place should not blind us to the fact that a strange thing is happening in a democratic country-that a government should allow this process to go ahead, knowing that virtually every person in this country who might have had an important input to this legislation and was motivated so to do has done so, and then look at the recommendations that have resulted from that inquiry, probably as heavy and as intensive a piece of community consultation as has ever taken place in this country and then largely ignore what the committee recommended. I think that indicates the degree to which the Government is under constraints. It has been told by someone in some place or some group of people that there is not to be effective freedom of information legislation in this country. The Bill in its present form, like the earlier one, if it is eloquent about any one thing it is eloquent about that.

I say that because the degree to which immunities have been given from giving of information, the degree of exceptions and exemptions on the types of documents, is so great, so extensive, such astounding overkill, that it is no joke at all to suggest that the real motivation of the Bill is to preserve the processes of secret government in Australia. Over the next few weeks, perhaps even months, the long battle over individual clauses in this Bill in the Committee stage will go on. Many thousands of words will be spoken. At many times those discussions will revolve around what might appear to be relatively minor and technical points but they will all be important points. The Democrats will play what part we can in the Committee stage.

But let me say at this point that I believe there is nobody in this country-certainly it is not I or anybody in the Democrats and probably it is no other senator-who could claim to have in his mind or at his finger tips the encyclopedic knowledge of the implications of this matter that Senator Missen has. That is why I was glad to hear him speak earlier in this debate and say the things he did say. I believe he spoke with a degree of integrity and a degree of devotion to the public cause which we in this place can only admire. I hope that Government senators will emulate him and see this matter as it truly is-a matter which should be beyond party politics, which is very close to the ideal we were elected to this place to preserve. That is, the idea that this country shall remain not only a democratic country with its shows and forms of democracy but also a country which is demonstrably so free and so open in its government as to be a good example to other countries around us.

We are seeing now that the democracies which were founded in former colonies in much of South East Asia and South Asia have not survived. A few have. In India democracy has survived. In Singapore it has survived after a fashion with grave constraints. But everywhere in the area around us, which is important to us, democracy is at threat. Every year the number of countries that have reasonable representative governments diminishes. Every year a country is taken over by military force or by its own military junta. Unfortunately after a while one becomes almost attuned to these things and one accepts them. I think it is terribly dangerous that one should accept this situation. I wonder too whether constant association with these things blunts one's own perception. In other words, we may be in danger of accepting that certain things should happen in this country because they are happening in other countries. This is a tendency of human beings, a sort of process of habituation. Perhaps we should look at ourselves more carefully and consider whether what I suggest is possible in this country. If it comes about it could be the beginning of the road which would lead this country in the direction those other countries have taken. Democracy, which all of us here should try to preserve because it is our business to preserve it and that is the reason for our being here, has been shown not to be all that strong. It is fragile. It is a growth which can be maintained and prosper in the community only if it is nurtured and only if those of us and the others who believe in it and who feel that it should be perpetuated make sure that at all times the conditions in which it can persevere continue.

I believe it is important in this second reading debate to define the broad importance of this legislation to the Australian community, what it will do for the Australian community and what it might be able to do if it were constructively amended. Honourable senators such as Senator Missen and Senator Evans who are lawyers have already got down to a degree of detail. I respect their reasons but perhaps that makes a more general overview a useful preliminary. I reiterate as a cardinal first point that the Bill is not what it pretends to be. The Australian public is being sold a pup. The Government, firmly under the control of its senior bureaucrats, will have to be carried kicking and screaming eventually into providing adequate freedom of information legislation, and it knows that full well. I cannot believe that honourable senators on the other side of the Senate are so unintelligent as not to appreciate at a glance, as most other people can, the inadequacies of this legislation. That is why the Australian Democrats believe that a proper public appreciation of this matter and its importance is absolutely vital to the future health and freedom of our society because I believe it will in the end be an enlightened and vociferous public opinion that will win this battle-and a long and notable battle it will be. In the end it will bring truly open government to Australia. This is a bench-mark type of situation. This Bill is of great importance. It will be historic. It will be looked back on. Perhaps the vote on this amendment will be looked back on as something of vital importance and something by which history will measure people's views and integrity. I say that to honourable senators opposite not in any spirit of criticism but because I honestly believe it to be a fact that this is an issue beyond politics and one which requires an enormous degree of courage on their part. I believe they will get their rewards for their courage if they are prepared to exert it.

This legislation is important to the ordinary person because governments create legislation, regulations and the whole fabric of law within which people must carry their day to day lives. People very much take this for granted. A law comes in, some new thing happens and people say: 'Yes, I have got to do this and I have got to do that'. But I wonder how many people understand that it is a constant process on a battlefield where many various groups in the community contend against one another to gain some sort of advantage, legal or financial. All honourable senators know this because we regularly come into contact with these pressure groups and we know how strong they can make their representations at times, how unfair those representations can be at times and how some will stop at nothing to press their point of view. These pressure groups are not necessarily dishonest in their view although they sometimes are in fact-and of course the two things are different. But in either case, whether or not they believe they are dishonest they do believe they deserve their advantage.

All of us are a little like that where our own interests are concerned. That granted, it becomes extremely important to know where and how influence is being exerted on the process of government. Just as those influences are continuous, so must the monitoring process also be continuous. That is why in recent years-perhaps recent decades would be a more accurate statement-in most of the larger free societies, the democracies, a major demand for good freedom of information legislation has built up in the community.

I believe it has been due, at least in part, to the growing complexity of government and the growing awareness of the community that it gets the kind of laws that it deserves, that more community involvement is required, that it is not good enough for members of parliament and representatives to be left merely to fight off pressure groups. For a variety of reasons, they cannot always do that effectively. They have things called elections which happen every three years in which unfair pressures can be brought to bear. I refer to such pressures as were exerted by the Right to Life movement on certain Victorian members of parliament in the last election. I believe such pressures ought not to be placed on members of parliament. I think it is essential that the community realises that they are exerted. Because of that the community must play its part in the process of government. To do that a community has to have information. Its line to information is normally the media.

I have not much sympathy with those honourable senators who have said in this place that the media people would like to see the Freedom of Information Bill go ahead as the sort of tame pussycat that we now see before us in the form of this draft legislation-I call it draft legislation for good reason-because they like the system of leaks and obtaining information secretly, something which falls off the back of a truck. I dispute that claim absolutely. I have many good friends in the media. I am an ex-journalist myself. I say that that is not the way in which these people like to work. They like to work in an ordinary, reasonable and open way, as does everybody else in pursuing a career. The fact that there have been so many leaks in our society and the fact that so many documents fall off the back of trucks is due to the refusal of the Government to provide the means whereby fair information can be obtained fairly. That situation will get worse-much worse-if this Bill is passed. There is no reason in the world for the Government to expect anything else.

I reject totally the claim that journalists do not support the concept of good freedom of information legislation. Those journalists I have met and discussed the matter with do support it. Those newspapers that I normally read have made it very plain in their editorials and elsewhere in the last week or so that they certainly are in favour of good freedom of information legislation. If injustices-perhaps injustices affecting thousands of people-are to be avoided, there is a need for a free flow of information about what government is doing. The media know that. At the moment I am personally involved in two or three issues which could be advanced much more quickly if freedom of information legislation existed in this country. I have been trying to investigate things that are going on at present and I have come up against a blank wall. The point was made earlier-I think it should be made again-that this situation is beginning to infiltrate Question Time in this place. Recently I have read a number of answers to questions on notice. There is no doubt that whoever drafts the answers-after all, there is a responsibility on the honourable senator or honourable member who signs or creates a reply to see that it is honest-is including a remarkable degree of double talk. Those people often resort to evasion, gibberish and anything at all to avoid giving an honest answer to a request for information.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's new?

—Does the honourable senator not agree that it is important that the public realises this? They will not know unless somebody tells them, will they? It is important that government and senior public servants know that at any time the basis on which they make decisions could become public. That would give them a healthy respect for public opinion which they lack at present. A Bill such as this, which contains a whole myriad of provisions allowing public servants to avoid disclosure of their methods, and even of their inadequacies, is against the general public interest. That may seem to some honourable senators to be a truism, but it is of the most fundamental importance. I refer to a Japanese proverb. It goes back a long time in history. It means: 'People despised, official exalted'. It epitomises the attitudes eventually engendered by the processes of secret government. It grew up through those long centuries during which Japan was under complete autocratic government. This tendency towards official concealment is notoriously part of human nature. Probably everybody listening to me tonight has had some experience of it in Australia. Indeed, as Senator Missen has said, secret government has become a habit at all levels of government.

SPEECH.PARA: Most Australians-I know this applies to many people to whom I have spoken-regard it as an inevitable evil, something with which we have to learn to live, and something with which we will have to go on living. I suggest that if that view is becoming current in the community it is most unfortunate because it is not the case. If we could get good freedom of information legislation it could never be the case.
