Another reason why I think the Government should be castigated-indeed, we do castigate it-is that it has come back to the Senate with this absurd, posturing imitation of a freedom of information Bill which differs, as Senator Missen said, so little from what was presented to us years ago. We are actually expected to have a continuation of the kind of Gilbertian situation in which it was the freedom of information law in another country-the United States of America-which made important revelations about Australian official activity, such as the circumstances in which we became involved in the Vietnam War. The truth, which had been a casualty within the Australian official scene on that subject, was revealed only by enlightened and adequate legislation in another country. It has been said in the United States-and indeed, it is true-that if good freedom of information legislation had not existed in the United States the Watergate situation would never have been revealed and probably Richard Nixon would still be President of the United States. What we are talking about has that degree of importance and significance.

What would be good enough, just good enough, would be legislation which could establish the truth as fully as possible while still being consistent with national security-the Australian Democrats see the need for that security-and fair and reasonable commercial and privacy considerations. Legislation based only on those considerations is something a healthy community needs as much as it needs schools, traffic regulations, a good police force and the means of ordinary justice. We should be able to take freedom of information about the processes of government as much for granted as the air we breathe. Why should we not be able to do so? After all, Australia is supposed to be a democracy. Sadly, tendencies in Australia are more and more towards secret government. Why is that so? I sincerely believe it is because we have a deeply entrenched secret government-a group of senior bureaucrats who believe they have the Government in their pockets. The tendency of parliaments to waste so much of their time on confrontation and inter-party bickering has given these bureaucrats the opportunity they needed to entrench themselves more and more. A Minister who regularly defends himself against attacks is inclined to leave most of the detail of the running of his department to his public servants.

It is a fact that most political parties are not able, for one reason or another-partly for financial reasons and because of the difficulties of research-to carry as much work into policy as they should. Perhaps it would be easier when a party came to government to have a well-researched policy group-a group of people who knew about a particular area and who followed developments in it regularly-which could test ideas that are put to a new Minister by the bureaucrats. I put that idea to the other parties as something that they might work towards. The Australian Democrats use that procedure as best we can. We do not say that we are uniformly successful but we do have these policy groups. We realise that in any government a new Minister is very much at the mercy of bureaucrats. He has a vested interest against him not to break with them. I think the nature of the Cabinet system tends to support and accentuate that situation. These people, the bureaucrats-here again, they probably have the best of intentions; they probably think they are doing a damn fine job for the country-want their actions, past, present and future, to remain secret. That is why this Bill is drafted in its present form. It is as simple as that.

This Freedom of Information Bill is not merely a legalistic academic Bill. Although many times during the debate it may appear to be that, in reality it deals very much with a gut issue connected closely with the daily lives and the welfare of the people. The Bill provides its refuges for the bureaucracy. It gives it several ways and means of ducking out on providing important and significant information. One of these ways is the ability to certify documents as being exempt. The way in which it may be done is quite simple. It will not be done with mirrors or anything like that. Under the legislation we can exempt as many documents as we feel might be embarrassing. We have enough blanket provisions to make sure that whole areas of documents, or virtually any document, can be made exempt if we wish to do so. Of course another way is to exempt whole organisations from the provisions of the Freedom of Information Bill 1981 so they will never be concerned with freedom of information. There is no question whatsoever of their having to account in any respect. That is a vital point because, as I will say later, a large number of organisations are exempted completely.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twenty-four.
—I agree with Senator Missen.
—And 19.

—And 19 in the other category. Of course, there is another method of exemption. The Minister, or even a public servant by delegation, if he thinks that it will take his department too much time and trouble to give information, can make a subjective judgment and say that he will not provide information. That is a provision under clause 8 (6) of the Bill, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . modify compliance with a request for information on the grounds that it represents too great a workload on staff of a government department.

One area of exempt papers that I will deal with in a little more detail is internal working documents. It is an intriguing example of the way the people who devised this Bill-I do not blame the draftsmen-the politicians, go about it. They have used the phrase 'internal working documents'. These are not available for disclosure in the terms of the Bill as it stands. What is an internal working document? I would have thought that in the broad sweep of the total business of government very few documents of any great basic importance would not be considered in one way or another by some area of government as matters to be taken into account in policy forming. But even that is not of great importance. It is not necessary that a document actually is an internal working document; it is enough that it can be said that it is. I think that that is one of the more serious aspects of this legislation. All that is required is a decision by an official not to make a certain document available and that somehow it can be presented as an internal working document at some stage, at some time and in some sort of operation and it can be exempted for that reason. I suggest that that blanket provision would make it inevitable that very few documents of importance will be got through to the people who will use this Act, even if they are prepared to go through the incredible degrees of difficulty which will be involved in going through the process. A newspaper recently published a diagram which looks rather like Hampton Court maze. This is a flow chart for instruction drawn up by public servants on how they are to handle approaches on freedom of information from the public. One look at that chart would put off all but the most determined inquirer. But even when the most determined inquirer gets through, the government has got him or her in other ways.

I turn very briefly to a few other major flaws. The Bill will apply to documents created after its proclamation. Therefore everything that has happened in the past will remain secret. Conclusive decisions of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) on exempt documents are not subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal so it is in the Minister's hands to decide. This is supposed to be a freedom of information Bill. Regulations may be used to create-not legislation; it will not come before Parliament-more exempt agencies and classes of documents. Search and inspection fees could be so high as to deny reasonable access of people to documents. Most exemptions are so vague and broad, as I have said, they could encompass a whole range of innocuous information. There are grave procedural barriers, especially where a journalist tries to write a story, because 60 days may elapse before a request must be answered. This situation is absurd. If somebody wants something quickly he should be able to get it quickly and not have public servants say: 'Come back in two months time and you might get it'. There is no requirement that indexes of major types of documents be prepared in the publication of information from agencies.

I will look briefly at these exempt agencies. I think that anybody who listens will ask: Why should authorities such as the Aboriginal land councils and trusts, the Australian Industry Development Corporation, the Australian Overseas Projects Corporation, the Australian Shipping Commission, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Commission, the Pipeline Authority and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation be entirely exempt? In Schedule 1 they are exempted. The Australian Democrats say that those authorities should go to the second category at least in which people are exempt only in relation to particular documents. We will be looking very carefully at this whole area in the Committee stage of the Bill.

Finally, is a bad law to be regarded as better than a worse one? It is a question worth asking. Our view is that after almost a decade of preparation and detailed painstaking work of our Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, and the huge input from the public, this legislation is not good enough. We support the second reading amendment. We oppose a pious, minor cosmetic effort as not good enough. Once again, I exhort honourable senators opposite for once to use their consciences and exert their duty as members of parliament, rather than as politicians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Freedom of Information Bill 1981 and I rise to support the second reading amendment so ably moved by my colleague, Senator Evans. At this stage of the debate I would like to make some general remarks because our specific reservations about the Bill and our improvements to it will be dealt with in the Committee stage. This debate provides one of the most disappointing episodes that I have experienced in all my time in this Parliament. I am sure that when I say that I am speaking for many senators in this place. Why should this be? The importance of freedom of information legislation has never been disputed. The legislation has been long awaited and, unlike most other legislation that comes into this place, its introduction in this form has been preceded by long and thorough preparation. Through the work of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs the public has had a rarely extended opportunity to contribute to the preparation of this legislation. The general public took advantage of this opportunity in a most energetic and constructive manner.

SPEECH.PARA: As well as contributions from individual members of the public, there was a wide range of contributions from politicians, government departments, statutory authorities, professional associations, academics, trade unions, researchers, public interest groups and newspapers. The long and thorough preparation culminated in the Senate Standing Committee report on the Freedom of Information Bill 1978 and aspects of the Archives Bill 1978 printed on 6 November 1979. I congratulate all members of that Senate Committee for providing this chamber and this Parliament with such an excellent document. In the preparation of this document and in the debate on the freedom of information issue there was an unusually high level of unanimity about the importance of freedom of information and the form it should take, an unusually great degree of bipartisanship, yet the legislation in the form in which the Government has finally presented it is a total disappointment. In the debate and inquiry preceding the introduction of this Bill there was also widespread recognition of the fundamental importance of access to information to the proper workings of our democratic system. I quote from the Senate Standing Committee's report paragraph 3.7 which states:

The essence of democratic government lies in the ability of people to make choices: about who shall govern; or about which policies they support or reject. Such choices cannot be properly made unless adequate information is available.

It ought to have been a very heartening development that the essence of our democratic system was so clearly re-affirmed in relation to freedom of information legislation. After all, we ought not to take our democratic freedoms and our democratic system for granted. As other contributors to this debate have already pointed out, democracy is a relative concept and in Australia we enjoy a relatively high degree of democracy. In some places such as Russia, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Chile it has been totally destroyed. In El Salvador it is not even one of the issues at stake in the current violent struggle. In Poland democracy is trying, against hostile and enormous odds, to emerge. Here in Australia we do enjoy a relatively high degree of democracy, but there are dangers to our democratic system. Those dangers are not the threat of potential military invasion, civil war or the anarchy caused by widespread poverty and despair; the dangers are more like complacency and ignorance. We have a complacent electorate, a complacent bureaucracy, a complacent corporate sector and, it must be admitted, on many occasions a complacent parliament. We suffer from the widespread ignorance of the general public and indeed of all those elements of our system which I have just enumerated. Ignorance and complacency are the results of the difficulties of access to information about the workings of government. It was these dangers to our democratic system, the dangers of complacency and ignorance, that the Freedom of Information Bill was expected to counter.

When the 1978 legislation was examined by the Senate committee many inadequacies and weaknesses were exposed not only by the able contributions of my own colleagues such as Senator Evans and Senator Tate but also by the contribution of Government senators such as Senator Missen, the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. We expected that the legislation when reintroduced in its new form would be strengthened. As my colleague Senator Evans established in his opening speech in this debate, the legislation is actually a great deal worse in many significant ways than its predecessor. Those inadequacies have already been enumerated in the course of this debate. I will not go over that ground again. I want to say that there is no excuse for the inadequacies in the legislation. Although the new Bill has incorporated 21 recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee another 51 recommendations have been left out. Worse than this, there are at least 10 major new restrictions and prohibitions which the Government has produced.

I believe the Opposition is speaking in the interests of the entire Australian public when it says that it cannot accept the Bill in its present form. To do so would break faith with all those who have contributed to its preparation and would be to forgo a most significant opportunity to strengthen our democratic system. Hence the Opposition has moved a wide-ranging second reading amendment and, as has been foreshadowed by Senator Evans, has prepared some 51 amendments which we hope to have accepted during the Committee stage of this Bill. The three basic justifications for freedom of information legislation were spelt out in the report of the Senate Standing Committee. I would like to repeat them here. The first is the right of the individual-that is, the right to know what information is held in government records concerning that individual. The second is the accountability of the Government to the electorate. The third is public participation in the process of policy-making and the Government itself. In not one of these three criteria is the Bill before us satisfactory.

It is an accepted truism in our society that knowledge is power. Governments have a lot of power because they have a lot of information. If citizens could have access to that knowledge they would be able to share in the power. As I have said before, although Australia relatively speaking is an advanced democracy in the area of citizens' access to information Australia is peculiarly backward. Already the United States of America, Canada and Scandanavian countries have freedom of information legislation. I think every honourable senator and probably every person listening to the debate is aware of what advances in domocracy and freedom have been possible in the United States of America because of the action people have been able to take under freedom of information legislation. In other countries such as the United Kingdom and New Zealand there are moves to establish freedom of information legislation.

Alone among Western nations Australia had no fixed rules governing the release of official records for the purpose of historical study. Even now the 30-year rule prohibits altogether the release of material within that time span. I will not at this stage advert to the Archives Bill which the Senate will debate following the conclusion of the discussion on the Freedom of Information Bill. I simply wish to point out that the Government in that area is still obsessed with secrecy; the Government is placing an unjustifiable number of exclusions and restrictions, even after 30 years, on the material that will be available to the public. Current information is treated in an even more restricted way and those restrictions will not be eased in a significant way by the Bill in its present unamended form. Examples of Government documents withheld from the public over the last few years include the Bland report on the Public Service and large sections of reports such as the Hope Royal Commission on Intelligence and Security, the Holmes report on Medibank, recommendations of the aviation industry review committee and the Government's proposal to revise agreements for transferring some Tasmanian and South Australian railways to the Commonwealth. Very recent examples include the failure of the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) to release information concerning toxic shock syndrome and the use of tampons and most recently the failure of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to release information about the discovery of legionaires disease in the air conditioning service in Parliament House.

I believe every senator could add his or her own experiences to that list. I can give some examples of my own. For example, in recent weeks in my capacity as shadow Minister for that part of Home Affairs covering the Australian Government's involvement in the film industry I have continually sought information about the Government's announced decision to allow massive tax incentives for investors in Australian film. Seeing that that commitment was made during the last election campaign in October and since it has been followed by an absolute assurance from the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the previous Minister for Home Affairs that the legislation would be introduced and that it would apply-it has been costed at this stage at something up to $20m-I thought I would have been able to get some information from the bureaucracy as to how the system would work. I have not been able so far to get that information so I have not been able to answer adequately either the questions of my colleagues concerning the operation of this matter or the questions coming from all sections of the industry. It seems to me at this stage that I am complaining not only on my behalf but also on behalf of many people in the film industry who are not able to decide whether or how to take advantage of the Government's announced policy because the information is unavailable.

In other responsibilities within my shadow portfolios I experience similar on-going frustrations. Today the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) asserted that the report evaluating reports on Aboriginal health will not be made public. One would think that such information would be crucial for all those people developing and delivering Aboriginal health services or attempting, as I and my colleagues are doing, to support these services. Yet, the Minister blandly assured us that it was never his intention to make this information public. Presumably, at some date chosen at the Government's convenience a response to these reports will be available but not the information on which the Government's response is based. How are we, from this side of the chamber, to assess the value or relevance of the Government's response? As shadow Minister for women's affairs I have received repeated representations from women whose only source of income is the supporting mothers' benefit. From time to time, as every honourable senator in this place must know because I have often raised the matter, women living on the benefit have their entitlement withdrawn without explanation. They are then subjected to weeks or even months of investigation into their personal lives. The benefit may or may not be re-established. Such women are denied access to the reports on which decisions determining their livelihood are based.

Of the denials of information I have listed-it is only a random selection from an endless list-none can be justified in terms of the security of the nation, the rights of citizens or the stability of our society. None will be adequately redressed by the legislation in its present form. As well as the rights of individuals and the rights of members of the public to information that affects them there is another kind of right not dealt with in the Bill. This concerns the right of interested citizens such as business managers to get from the Public Service information beneficial to them. For example, there seems to be no reason why businesses should not have ready access to the vast amount of information on trade and commerce currently held within the bureaucracy. However, in the debate about access to government information it is important to stress-I must stress it at this stage-that we are arguing for the right of the public to know and not for the right of the Government to inflict information it has selected on citizens and on the Parliament. Let me be quite clear: I am not complaining that in quantitative terms there is a shortage of information coming from the Government.

In recent days in this place there has been serious criticism by the Opposition of the Government Information Unit. This outfit, honourable senators will know, has been set up by the Government to propagate to the media and to the public information or views which the Government wants people to have. This exercise has cost to date $276,000 and by the end of the financial year this figure will have risen to the order of $500,000. This is taxpayers' money which is being spent on information that nobody has asked for and, quite possibly, nobody wants. It is something of an irony that while we are being denied the right of access to information by the Fraser Government we are having such expensive unwanted items of government propaganda inflicted on us.

If we add to the expenditure on the Government Information Unit the cost of preparing, printing and distributing the avalanche of government papers that descends on us every week in this place-ministerial speeches, ministerial Press releases, ministerial statements and so on-we can see that our complaint is not that we are suffering from a lack of information but that we have no right to decide what will be available to us. It is the right of access that this legislation ought to provide and does not provide. It is that right of access that the Federal Opposition and other senators will seek to put into the Bill at the Committee stage.

Legislation guaranteeing the right of access is particularly important to the Australian Labor Party because of our egalitarian philosophy. We are strenuously opposed to the current prevailing, elitist practices concerning access to information. Because of the unequal nature of our society citizens at this stage are, in fact, unequal in their access to information which is of great importance to them. For example, much legislation consists of broad rules and citizens are not equally well placed to take advantage of broad rules. This is clearly seen, for example, in income tax legislation which permits the wealthy to engage in tax evasion procedures which are simply not relevant to the poor. Government senators might argue that the tax law applies equally to all citizens. Of course, we would point out, rightly, unarguably, that all citizens do not have access to tax accountants, tax lawyers and, most significantly, to the level of income that makes these schemes so extravagantly advantageous to the elite.

I am not suggesting that the inequities of the taxation system will be addressed by freedom of information legislation but it is very important to remind ourselves that even in the operation of legislation there is not equal access in this country. I raise that point at this stage in the debate to persuade Government senators that it is of the greatest necessity in the drafting of effective freedom of information legislation that the procedures for access are carefully formulated so as to place, for example, the unemployed person, the Aborigine, the migrant with little English or the supporting mother living on a pension, at the smallest possible disadvantage compared with other citizens. The legislation before us fails to meet this necessity but the Federal Opposition is committed to the view that freedom of information legislation should be drafted and should so operate as to help to create a more just and equal society.

In conclusion I must acknowledge that it is not possible to have freedom of information legislation that eliminates all secrecy entirely. That is not our view. We are not being idealistic and we are not being unrealistic on this point. We do not believe that even if all our amendments were accepted we would eliminate secrecy within the bureaucracy and we would establish absolute equality of access to information for all citizens. We are not aiming for an impossible objective. What we are aiming for is modest and reasonable. It is something which has had bipartisan support throughout this chamber since the earlier legislation was first introduced into this place. It is clearly supported throughout those sections of the community which have concerned themselves with this matter. We are asking for a modest, democratic measure, one that already exists in other countries with which we like to compare ourselves, one for which there is a very adequate model in the United States of America and one by which I believe this Parliament would distinguish itself if it would only support it.

As I said, even if all Opposition amendments are accepted, there will remain areas of secrecy within the Government and the bureaucracy. Some of these areas, such as those concerning defence, security and individual privacy, will properly remain secret. We have acknowledged this all along. Other areas, of course, will remain secret because of the nature of the bureaucracy. It is simply not possible to devise access machinery which will open up the bureaucracy entirely to the citizens or the Parliament. What we want, and what we believe is perfectly possible and most desirable, is freedom of information legislation which will reduce the amount of information currently kept secret and which, in doing so, will ensure a more democratic and egalitarian operation of our system of government. That modest but important objective will be achieved if the Senate supports our second reading amendment and if, in the Committee stage, this chamber accepts the amendments which will be moved in a spirit of bipartisanship and constructive co-operation. That is the course of action I urge on the Senate this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this Freedom of Information Bill. It is one of the most significant Bills ever to come before the Australian Parliament because it gives effect to one of the most important rights of a democratic society-the right to know. It also affects fundamentally the relationship between the Executive-that is the Ministry and the Public Service-and the Parliament. The right to information and the need for its legislative expression were well summarised by the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) when, in 1976, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: If the Australian electorate is to be able to make valid judgments on government policy it should have the greatest access to information possible. How can any community progress without continuing an informed and independent debate? How can there be debate without information?

Freedom of information, the right of the electorate to have access to information of its servants, is not a party matter. The Prime Minister has publicly committed the Liberal Party of Australia and the present Government to bringing in freedom of information laws. The Australian Labor Party by its platform of 1979 is also committed to:

the enactment of effective Freedom of Information legislation granting the public full entitlement to the disclosure of government and administrative decision-making, subject only to the requirements of essential security and individual privacy.

The Australian Democrats are committed to a Bill of Rights that 'will guarantee freedom of information' in a list of other freedoms. So there is no dispute about the need for freedom of information legislation, nor would there, I think, be any dispute about the objects of the present Bill as expressed in clause 3, though perhaps a little pompously. Clause 3 reads:
The object of this Act is to extend the right of the Australian community to access to official information in the possession of the Government of the Commonwealth by-

(a) making available to the public information about the operations of departments and public authorities and, in particular, ensuring that rules and practices affecting members of the public in their dealings with departments and public authorities are readily available to persons affected by those rules and practices; and
(b) creating a general right of access to official information in documentary form in the possession of Ministers, departments and public authorities, limited only by what is necessary . . .
(i) for the protection of essential public interests, and the private and business affairs of persons in respect of whom information is collected and held by departments and public authorities; and
(ii) for the proper conduct of public business by Ministers, departments and public authorities.

Clause 3 goes on to state that it is the intention of the Parliament that any discretions conferred by the Freedom of Information Act be interpreted, as far as possible, so as to facilitate and promote the disclosure of information. By the way, this provision was inserted on the recommendation of the all-party Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, though we did not recommend the use of quite such a long sentence. So far so good. What, then, is the trouble with the present Bill? The trouble is that this Bill as presented to us is a Public Service document. As far as I have been able to ascertain, every significant decision in it comes out of a series of Public Service interdepartmental committees. Although these decisions were of course endorsed by Cabinet, there was no political input at all in the sense of forcing the Public Service to go further than it wanted to-and it did not want to go very far.

In discussions before our Senate Committee, it became obvious that most senior public servants regard freedom of information as a peculiar political foible and that their duty is to limit the availability of information as far as they can get away with it. As an argument, they used a very self-serving concept of the Westminster system in relation to which some of them were astonishingly ill-informed and out of date. It is up to parliament-it is up to us and not the Public Service-to see that the Freedom of Information Act goes far enough. One of the main beneficiaries of a decent Freedom of Information Act will be members of parliament, and we can then get away from the situation whereby the Press Gallery, through selective departmental leaks, is better informed about what goes on in government than we are. That is why most of the members of the Press Gallery are not very keen on freedom of information. They prefer the present system of cosy leaks. Of course, if we are happy with that situation, we will not be too upset about the present Bill. But I am not happy with that situation.

The Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee made many recommendations to improve the Freedom of Information Bill 1978. Most of the important ones have been ignored in this present Bill. One that has been accepted in the present Bill overcame a glaring weakness which the original Bill had inherited from the American freedom of information Act on which it had been largely modelled. In America a high proportion of freedom of information requests are designed to gain confidential information about commercial rivals. We recommended-the Government, I am glad to say, has accepted our recommendations -a procedure to give protection to commercial information given in confidence to the Government.

There are five, or perhaps 5 1/2, areas in which I should like to see this freedom of information legislation strengthened so that it is internally compatible with its own clause 3, which I quoted earlier, and also matches the admirable statement made by the Prime Minister in 1976. The first of these concerns is the use of the so-called conclusive certificate by which a Minister or certain public servants can certify that a document is exempt from disclosure because its release would adversely affect national security or Commonwealth-State relations, or because it is a Cabinet document or an Executive Council document, or that it would not be in the public interest to release an internal working document. If such a certificate is given, that is the end of the matter; there is no appeal to anyone.

Let me make my position quite clear. I have no desire to see the release of documents which would harm national security. I do not think documents which are truly and exclusively Cabinet or Executive Council documents should be released. That would, in my view, seriously damage the working of our present system of government, which has been done enough harm already by self-serving Cabinet leaks. I am not for a moment advocating the release of internal working documents when their release would harm the public interest. Of course, no one in his right mind would do so.

The only question is: Who decides whether the documents should be released? The Bill says that the relevant Minister, or in certain cases the public servant, should decide. The Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee says that the decision should be reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which is the review body in other areas of dispute on freedom of information. I am not advocating, nor did the Committee advocate, an unrestricted right of review in all cases. In the case of Cabinet, Executive Council or national security documents, it is recommended that a single judge, a Federal Court judge who is a member of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, should have a strictly limited review role. He should merely check that the documents are as described, with no irrelevant attachments. If they are properly classified as national security documents, or if they are Cabinet documents, that is the end of the matter. No question of countervailing public interest arises. In the other cases-that is, documents affecting Federal-State relations and internal working documents-the review should concern whether the balance of public interest dictates disclosure. Federal Court judges are scarcely wild-eyed radicals. They can be trusted to give full weight to the Government's arguments against disclosure.

So far I have heard no sensible defence of the Government's position in this matter. The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) has said that Ministers are better qualified than judges to make such decisions. With respect-those words are an almost infallible sign that something most disrespectful is about to be said-that is utter rubbish. A Minister may well be closely involved and have a strong political interest in concealment. Party political interests are not necessarily identical with the public interest. Let us remember that President Nixon was prepared to certify that all the illegal Watergate actions were concerned with national security. To bring the matter closer to home, an Attorney-General-not the present one, admittedly-certified that the Khemlani loan was for temporary purposes.

I cannot understand the Government's attitude in this matter. We have set up elaborate procedures to review ministerial decisions in other areas; for instance, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Security Appeals Tribunal. Why has it not done so in this field? Information release is surely the most important area where justice must be seen to be done. Surely it would be in a Minister's interest, if he is challenged when his decision is right, to have it supported by an independent judicial review. If he is wrong-there is a hell of a lot of grossly over-classified material in the Department of Defence and the Department of Foreign Affairs-it would be a good thing to have the material released, and the possibility of an appeal would make departments much more careful about what they slap security classifications on.

I think the Government's refusal to allow appeals against conclusive ministerial certificates, as the Canadians do in their recent freedom of information Bill, is indefensible-or at least I have heard no sensible defence of it yet. I shall be moving an amendment in the Committee stage to put this part of the Bill in better shape.

My second concern is the width of the exemptions by which whole classes of documents are excluded from release. We all accept that some types of documents-for instance, documents containing information about proposed changes in the exchange rate-would have to be exempt. But the exemptions in the Bill as it stands are far too wide. The Bill leans well over the far side of reasonable caution and shows obvious evidence of its Public Service origin. The Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee made some sensible suggestions for the responsible narrowing of these exemptions so that what should be released will be released. In Committee I will support amendments to give effect to these suggestions.

My third concern is the Government's rejection of the role of the Ombudsman as proposed by the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee. As the Bill stands, if a person is refused access to a document he may appeal for an internal review. This is carried out by a separate group of public servants in the department that refused access in the first place. If the refusal of access is confirmed, he may then appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The trouble is that for the average citizen the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is an intimidating and possibly expensive place. It is supposed to be an informal, inquisitorial body. But there have been suggestions that sometimes it is more formal than the High Court of Australia. In any case, as a matter of principle, should not conciliation precede arbitration? The Ombudsman, with his prestige and his power to examine documents, is admirably placed to sort out these matters and to see that the applicant is not given the well known bureaucratic run around. In appropriate cases, if conciliation fails, the Ombudsman should exercise the general counsel role that was originally intended for him, and should represent the mistreated applicant before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I shall support amendments in Committee that will give an effective role to the Ombudsman in freedom of information matters, as is done, by the way, in equivalent Canadian legislation.

My fourth concern is the handling of the secrecy provisions which are in existing legislation. There are such secrecy provisions in the Commonwealth Crimes Act and in 109 other Acts of Parliament and 85 rules and ordinances. The Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee recommended that the existing secrecy provisions which should be continued should be listed in a Schedule to the Bill and amendments to the Schedule should be made only after affirmative resolutions of both Houses. The Government has rejected this and has maintained the present mishmash of security provisions in other legislation, much of which is quite incompatible with the principles of this Freedom of Information Bill. I shall support amendments to correct this chaotic situation.

My fifth concern is the way in which new agencies may be exempted from the operation of the Freedom of Information Act by prescribing them in regulations. The trouble is that they would then not come before Parliament but come only before the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, whose criteria are limited to matters such as whether the regulations trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties or unduly delegate parliamentary authority. It would be difficult for the Regulations and Ordinances Committee to refer the exemption of an agency from freedom of information back to the Senate on the grounds that the power should not have been delegated when the Parliament had passed an Act specifically directing it to be done by regulation. The Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee recommended, in order to bring these important matters of the exemption of new agencies from the freedom of information legislation automatically before Parliament, that such exemptions should be done by affirmative resolutions of both Houses of Parliament. The Government has stuck to doing it by regulation. I am sure that the Government is wrong in this and I will support in Committee an amendment to bring in the recommendation of the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee.

The final issue is the question of documents that exist at the time the Freedom of Information Bill comes into force. By the present Bill, with relatively trivial exceptions, they will not be eligible for release. The Attorney-General has said that he will look again at the situation after three years' experience of the Act. I think everyone agrees that estimates of the Public Service work load which would be imposed by the Freedom of Information Act are pure guesswork, and most of us sympathise with the Government's desire, staff ceilings being what they are, not to promise more than it can perform. We, the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee, proposed a gradual phasing in of these prior documents, with the timing laid down in the Act. I can sympathise with the Government's dilemma in this and if I could get an unequivocal assurance from the Attorney-General that he would genuinely tackle prior documents within a reasonable time, I would not press for inclusion of the timetable in the Act. Three years is far too long though. The pattern of the effort imposed on the Public Service by freedom of information will be clear within a few months of the implementation of the Freedom of Information Act.

Finally, I mention two security matters. The Committee recommended that a system for automatic declassification of national security documents should be instituted on an administrative basis. We had in mind the American model, which seems to work very well. Under the American system, most classified documents are automatically declassified after a maximum period of six years unless a specific decision is made to continue with a security classification. In November 1979 we recommended the adoption of a similar system in Australia. On 11 September 1980 the Government replied that it would be the subject of further study. Seven months later nothing has happened. We also recommended that Cabinet documents should be distinctively marked but should not carry a national security classification unless such classification were justified by their contents. Here, too, nothing has been done. Cabinet documents, even over dealings on matters such as the slaughter of pigs, are still classified 'Confidential', and I remind the Senate that the Government's own test for assigning the classification 'Confidential' is whether the disclosure of the document could reasonably be expected to cause damage to the national security. Slaughter may cause damage to the pigs but scarcely to the national security. Some departments which have nothing to do with national security also seem to be equipped with 'Confidential' stamps which they use freely on quite inappropriate documents. If freedom of information is to work properly, the Public Service will have to tighten up its thoroughly sloppy administration in this area.

What we are seeking is information that will make our Parliament and our democratic system work better. Public servants are cautious and have a vested interest in secrecy. They really think, or most of them seem to think, that what the public should be told is what they, the bureaucracy, think they ought to be told. It is up the the Parliament to press for the best balance between the right of the public to know and the requirements of efficient administration. We are the ones who must do it, not least because members of parliament will be among the principal beneficiaries of effective freedom of information. It is worth remembering that the American Freedom of Information Act, on which ours is largely modelled, was not an act of grace by the Executive to make information more freely available but was imposed by the Congress over a Presidential veto. Everyone in our Parliament-Government, Opposition, Ministers, back benchers-must work together to create effective freedom of information legislation. I appeal to Ministers to recognise that, so far, all their advice has come from the Public Service, which could hardly be said to be disinterested. Now look at it from the other side-after all, you are parliamentarians as well as Ministers-and join with us in creating a Freedom of Information Bill of which we can be justly proud and which will meet the desire of the Prime Minister:
That the Australian electorate should have the greatest access to information possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hearn Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to speak briefly in support of the amendment to the Freedom of Information Bill. I think many honourable senators who have spoken have made the points necessary in their criticism of the Bill as it stands. My concern is for the quality of democracy in this country. I think secrecy belittles the intelligence, the rights and the human dignity of the people of a nation. It produces apathy in the community and citizens are deprived of information. If they are deprived of information, they lose interest in government. They become apathetic and they necessarily then lose their rights of participation. A better informed public can examine the problems of funding for various community services with a better understanding and critical judgment.

SPEECH.PARA: If people are to participate democratically in the affairs of their nation they have a right to the information which is presently withheld from them in many cases to enable them to make responsible judgments and wise decisions. Why should public servants and government have more knowledge than the people's representatives in the Parliament and the people themselves? Why should matters which affect the lives of the men, women and children in our community be kept secret? Why should people not participate and have their intelligence and their concerns broadened so that they can feel a part of the nation and the community?

Throughout history the withholding of knowledge has been an indication of dictatorial regimes because governments and rulers have considered that an informed public could be dangerous to their power and unsettling for the population. It is indeed a form of censorship to deny people the opportunity to criticise and to judge the actions of government. Fire in the past has been used as an agent to combat contrary opinions; men and books have been burned when their teachings have been distasteful to the prevailing authority. One of the Seven Wonders of the World-the Libraries of Alexandria-was destroyed by fire. Books were burnt during the Chin dynasty in China. There has been the recent example of the burning of books in nazi Germany. But today we have more subtle and more powerful means of supressing information-media controlled by a few and government secrecy.

When we talk about the public interest, what does it really mean and how do we define it? Is it in the people's interests for them to be ignorant of the things that are done in their name? Citizens should know what their government is doing and they should be free to criticise it and to add creative suggestions and contributions. Democracy can exist only as long as its citizens have the right to knowledge and the right to contribute their ideas and to participate in the shaping of the decisions that are made. Governments which, through secrecy, deprive people of that right already have the odour of decay, and it is a threat to our parliamentary system if that secrecy continues. I think the public cynicism at present shows a recognition of the fact that there are dangerous currents in this area. We must not belittle the input or the intelligence of the people of our country. There are at work in the world today forces which are opposing democracy-the forces of materialism, of economic power and of people who put pure gain as the measure of all things we do. We must be careful and we must encourage the community to be alert to those forces which, to their benefit, would instil apathy in the community. If we are to have in our society that equality which gives recognition to the human spirit and to those aims of mutual aid and human caring, we could perhaps remember the words of Milton when he said that the first freedom was the liberty to know and to argue freely according to conscience and human reason. He said:

We should be wary therefore what persecution we raise against the living labours of publick men, how we spill that season'd life of man preserv'd and stor'd up in Books; since we see a kind of homicide may be thus committed, sometimes a martyrdome; and if it extend to the whole impression, a kind of massacre, whereof the execution ends not in the slaying of an elementall life, but strikes at that ethereall and fift(h) essence, the breath of reason itselfe, slaies an immortality rather than a life.
We must remember too the words of John Stuart Mill, who said:

There is always hope when people are forced to listen to both sides. It is when they attend only one that errors harden into prejudices and truth itself ceases to have the effect of truth, by being exaggerated into falsehood.

I want simply to say to all honourable senators in this place that they should consider carefully how their decisions on this Bill will affect the dignity of our people and the development of those human capacities of reason, critical judgment and creative participation which can enhance the quality of democracy in our nation, which can give inspiration to our young people and which can give our country the opportunity to demonstrate what a democracy is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly not possible to cover the whole of the field of freedom of information in the time available to honourable senators this evening. There is certainly not the opportunity during the second reading stage to go into the complexities of this subject, which are best left to the Committee stage of the Bill. This Bill touches on certain fundamentals. It touches on the fundamental rights of at least four groups in our society as we know it. It touches, first, upon the rights of the public. It touches, secondly, upon the rights of politicians and members of parliament. It touches, thirdly, upon the rights of the Parliament as an institution itself; and it touches, fourthly, upon the rights of the Public Service.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the rights of the public, it amazes me that anybody should seek to erect a system which finds some basis in legislation and which says: 'Here we are, servants of the public, responsible to the public, telling the public that we and not they will be the arbiters of what they ought to know'. I have yet to hear a persuasive argument from any member of the Ministry or of the Government which touches upon the question of from where we in the Parliament or the Ministry derive the right to deny the public access to information which is legitimately the property of the public. It cannot, I suppose, have passed unnoticed that from a speakers list consisting of the names of 10 senators, including three Government senators, there is not one member of this Senate prepared to defend this Bill as it currently stands. One would presume that if this Bill were in fact the nonpareil that it proposes to be, there would have been at least some eloquent champion on the Government side, or indeed some eloquent intervention from the Ministry, to defend it. But in 10 speeches that will be delivered on this Bill there will not be one speech that does not say that this Bill is not good enough.

This Bill has been a long time in coming. Its genesis goes back at least to 1972, to an election promise made by then Prime Minister Whitlam. In 1973 the then Attorney-General, Senator Murphy, took certain initiatives to start the debate on freedom of information. In 1974 there was an interdepartmental committee. In 1975 there was an election in which Prime Minister Fraser made clear his commitment to freedom of information legislation. In 1976 there was another interdepartmental committee. In 1978 there was a Bill. In 1979 there was a Senate committee report. In 1980 there was a Government response. In 1981 there is a new Bill, and presumably in 1982 somebody will start to do something about it-presumably.

There are two issues, and two issues only, to which I will confine my remarks this evening. The first is the question of the public's right to know and the definition of the term 'public interest'. The second is the meaning-indeed, the twisted meaning-that some people have given to the phrase 'the Westminster system'. The first of those, as I said, is the right of the public to know. This is largely a debate on the public versus the Public Service. It is quite clear that the Public Service-certainly at senior level; I certainly do not try to put it on the Public Service as a whole because those persons at a lower level of the Public Service who came before the Senate Committee gave every evidence of seeking to co-operate and of being willing to co-operate- suddenly announced that the public servants had derived somehow, mystically, by a process of constitutional osmosis, a right to deny the public access to information.

We have a record which is clear-Senator Ryan has mentioned it, others have mentioned it-of people attempting to get information in the teeth of a record of hostility, frustration and secrecy imposed by the bureaucracy. The fundamental premise which I put to the Senate is simply this: If we believe in a free and open democratic system of government, how do we believe that can be achieved if the public is not in possession of the facts and the evidence which will allow it to judge whether a government is a good government or a bad government, a corrupt government or an honest government, an efficient government or an inefficient government, a government which honours its commitments or which breaks its commitments or a government which trusts the people or a government which distrusts the people? This was drawn to attention as far back as 1822 when the American President, James Madison, wrote:

A popular Government, without popular information, or the means of acquiring it, is but a Prologue to a Farce or a Tragedy; or, perhaps, both. Knowledge will forever govern ignorance; and a people who mean to be their own Governors, must arm themselves with the power which knowledge gives.
In a more latter day expression of this philosophy, I quote as follows:

But just as fundamental are two further requirements. First, people and Parliament must have the knowledge required to pass judgment on the government. Secondly, the Ministers and government must themselves be in control of public policy so that those who the Parliament and people can call to account are indeed those responsible. To the extent that responsibility is diffused beyond that elected government-other than by legislative intent-to that extent is effective, popular control diminished. These two conditions for effective responsibility in government are complementary, but there are also areas where they compete.
The clearest area of competition is the appropriate extent of confidentiality in government. Too much secrecy inhibits people's capacity to judge the government's performance.

Those very wise and very learned words are to be found in an article published in the Australian Journal of Public Administration of March 1978, the Garran Oration, entitled 'Responsibility in Government', the author and speaker J. M. Fraser, Prime Minister. Those are the touch stones of what it is that we are supposed to be about. An editorial in one of the Sydney afternoon newspapers states:
Freedom of information is a vital core of any democracy.
Without it bureaucracy can run unbridled-complacent, corrupt and contemptuous of the rights of the individual.

I said that I think it is important to explore the concept 'public interest'. Therefore, let me give a couple of definitions which I think are useful in that sense. Stephen Bailey states that public interest is:

. . . the central concept of a civilised polity. Its genius lies not in its clarity but in its perverse and persistent moral intrusion upon the internal and external discourse of rulers and ruled alike.
It is that. It is a moral imperative. The right of people to know has a moral quality about it. It is not a matter of precise legal definition. Pendleton Herring writes:

The public interest is a concept that leads open the way to change, as general acceptance for new policies is won and officials remain accountable for their decisions. Since there are many ways for seeking public acceptance and for safeguarding administrative responsibility within a democratic polity, it is doubtful that anything would be gained by insisting upon a precise definition of the public interest.

The courts have turned their attention to this matter. Let me reflect on what the courts in the United Kingdom, the United States and Australia have said about the term 'public interest'. Viscount Simon, in the case Duncan v. Cammel Laird and Co. Ltd made a long statement on this. He said:
In this connection, I do not think it out of place to indicate the sort of grounds which would not afford to the Minister adequate justification for objecting to production.
That is, production of documents. He went on:

It is not a sufficient ground that the documents are 'state documents' or 'official' or are marked 'confidential'. It would not be a good ground that, if they were produced, the consequences might involve the department or the government in Parliamentary discussion or in public criticism, or might necessitate the attendance as witnesses or otherwise of officials who have pressing duties elsewhere.

Neither would it be a good ground that production might tend to expose a want of efficiency in the administration or tend to lay the department open to claims for compensation. In a word, it is not enough that the minister or the department does not want to have the documents produced.

The minister, in deciding whether it is his duty to object, should bear these considerations in mind, for he ought not to take the responsibility of withholding production except in cases where the public interest would otherwise be damnified, e.g., where disclosure would be injurious to national defence, or to good diplomatic relations, or where the practice of keeping a class of documents secret is necessary for the proper functioning of the public service.

In the famous Crossman diary cases, Lord Chief Justice Widgery, in ruling that the Government must allow the publication of the Crossman diary-that was the argument which the courts could not decide-said:

On the contrary, it must be for the court in every case to be satisfied that the public interest is involved, and that, after balancing all the factors which tell for or against publication, to decide whether suppression is necessary.
The United States faced up to this problem in the famous Supreme Court case of the United States v. Nixon, the famous Watergate tapes case. The Supreme Court said:
But this presumptive privilege--
That is, the executive privilege of the President-

must be considered in light of our historical commitment to the rule of law. This is nowhere more profoundly manifest than in our view that 'the twofold aim [of criminal justice] is that guilt shall not escape nor innocence suffer'.

Only recently the Court restated the ancient proposition of law, albiet in the context of a grand jury inquiry rather than a trial, '' 'that the public has a right to every man's evidence' except for those persons protected by a constitutional, common law, or statutory privilege'' . . .
In Australia the High Court has twice recently ruled on this matter. In the case of Sankey v. Whitlam the present Chief Justice, Mr Justice Gibbs, said:

It is in all cases the duty of the court, and not the privilege of the executive government, to decide whether a document will be produced or may be withheld. The court must decide which aspect of the public interest predominates, or in other words whether the public interest which requires that the document should not be produced outweighs the public interest that a court of justice in performing its function should not be denied access to relevant evidence.
His Honour summed up his views in these words:

For these reasons I consider that although there is a class of documents whose members are entitled to protection from disclosure irrespective of their contents the protection is not absolute, and it does not endure forever. The fundamental and governing principle is that documents in the class may be withheld from production only when this is necessary in the public interest.
Again, a High Court judge, Mr Justice Mason, in ruling in the Commonwealth v. John Fairfax and Sons Ltd, the defence papers case, came back to the same thing. He said:

The equitable principle has been fashioned to protect the personal, private and proprietary interests of the citizen, not to protect the very different interests of the executive Government. It acts, or is supposed to act, not according to standards of private interest, but in the public interest. This is not to say that Equity will not protect information in the hands of the Government, but it is to say that when Equity protects Government information it will look at the matter through different spectacles.
He went on:

The court will not prevent the publication of information which merely throws light on the past workings of government, even if it be not public property, so long as it does not prejudice the community in other respects. Then disclosure will itself serve the public interest in keeping the community informed and in promoting discussion of public affairs.

Finally, in terms of judicial authority in Australia, the Administative Appeals Tribunal in the case of Palmer v. the Minister for the Capital Territory dealt with the right of a person who has been disadvantaged by a bureaucratic or ministerial decision to know what evidence it was that was before the public servant or the Minister that caused him to come to the conclusion that he came to. The Tribunal said:
Furthermore the reasons which have actuated the mind of the expert in making his recommendation or giving his opinion, if material to the decision of the decision maker, should be included . . .
That is to say, included in the material given to the appellant. The Tribunal states:

If it was permissible for the decision maker merely to indicate that he had relied upon the advice of a named expert, the intention of the section could be by-passed. Additionally, the benefits to the citizen in the obtaining of reasons which in our view are fundamental to the whole scheme of administrative review embodied in the Act would be set at nought.

The Tribunal quoted Lord Denning and other authorities on that matter. The Tribunal said that it was the right of people to know the information which was used by a public servant or a Minister in coming to a decision. Let me give the Senate a practical example of the sort of withholding of information. I happen to agree very strongly with the Government decision on the Fraser Island dispute. I happen to agree that the decision that was made to prohibit the mineral sands exports was a good one but the firm, Murphyores, was substantially disadvantaged and sought from this Government evidence as to what it was that had led the Government to make up its own mind. The then Treasurer, Mr Lynch as he then was, wrote to Mr Murphy of Murphyores indicating that evidence was before the Government other than Press statements and speculation and reports. Mr Lynch, in his letter of 25 March 1977, stated:
Indeed, that decision--
That is the decision to withhold the export licence-
was based on extensive advice and documentation and not, as you suggest, simply on the Commissioners' report.

Murphyores wrote to the Government and said: 'You say your decision was based on ''extensive advice and documentation and not just on the public report''. Can we have a look at that because we think it may have been in error?' The then Minister for Finance, Mr Robinson, wrote to Murphyores and said: 'No, you cannot have the information'. In a letter on 9 January 1981 this was repeated by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, who wrote to Murphyores and said:

However, as far as advice and reports provided by Ministers and government departments are concerned, I can only reiterate my predecessor's response when you previously sought access to the information, that such advice and reports, and the relevant background work, have long been held by successive governments to be confidential to government.
In the circumstances I regret I am also unable to agree to your request for access to the information you seek.

Although that company was substantially prejudiced in its economic operations it was being told by the Government that the decision was based not just on public reports but on reports and advice made available to the Government. The company wrote to the Government and said: 'Can we have a look at the evidence upon which you have based your decision?' The Government wrote back to the company and said: 'No. The basis upon which your economic situation will be severely prejudiced is not a matter that we can allow you to have a look at so that you can make any comment or see whether the facts that were put to us were in fact facts or fantasy'.

From where does any government derive its right to deny its sovereign masters, the people, information necessary for their own well-being or for them to make a decision about government? Surely the only answer that can be given is that such material can be withheld if it is genuinely in the public interest to do so. If that is correct, the question arises as to who should decide what the public interest is and who should balance the competing claims of the public interest. The answer surely cannot be that that decision is to be left in the hands of the people who are already resisting giving out that information. Surely the answer must be that there is an independent tribunal somewhere. In the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs we have talked about the role of the Ombudsman and the role of a presidential member of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, that is, a judge. The Government surely cannot be saying to us that those people are not competent to balance competing public interests, that those people are not competent to determine what the public interest is in the release or otherwise of a document. But that in fact is what the Government is saying-that the judges are not competent to do this; that the Ombudsman is not competent to do this; but that some clerk three parts of the way down the Department of the Treasury is competent to do it. The Government is saying that he can go around with the knee jerk reaction and stamp 'Confidential' on any piece of paper that comes across his desk and he can say, if he happens to be the officer handling the appeal: 'Here am I, a clerk in the Third Division and I say this is an internal working document and I say you cannot have a look at it and I will be blowed if I am going to defer to some old judge or ombudsman to second-guess the opinion that I as a third grade clerk have decided to put on this matter'. If Mr President, you think that attitude is simply an overstatement let me quote to you from the transcript of evidence given by the Chairman of the Public Service Board to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. At page 886 of the transcript a question was put to him as to the views of Mr Justice Mason on public interest. Mr Cole, as he then was, stated:
I have seen statements including Mr Justice Mason's and I wondered at the time how they would know. I think one really has to have lived in the system.

After all, Mr Justice Mason was only the Solicitor-General. Mr Justice Mason is only a judge of the High Court of Australia. 'What the hell would he know about it?' said Mr Cole. That is precisely the same sort of attitude that comes through all of the evidence given by senior public servants from departments other, I would say, than the Department of the Attorney-General. The evidence given by that Department, I think, was of a far more liberal and open nature. But the evidence from the Department of the Treasury, from the Public Service Board and from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet was characterised by the sort of obstructionism to which I have referred. Mr Stone was asked a question by me about freedom of information in Sweden. Mr Stone said:

We are aware of some information on that and the experience is not encouraging but we do not necessarily translate that experience into our own experience because the mores of the Australian people may prove to be different in this regard from those of their counterparts in the United States, but I do not know.
I then asked Mr Stone:
What do you mean when you say that the experience is not encouraging? Not encouraging to whom?
Mr Stone said:
To the efficient working of the departments concerned.

It is not that it was not encouraging to the public of Australia; not that it was not encouraging to the Parliament of Austraia; not that it was not encouraging to the public interest in Australia; but that it was not encouraging to the Department of the Treasury.

The Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee has analysed this whole question of public interest at length. I refer only to paragraph 5.25, in which we discussed public versus private interests; paragraph 5.26, in which we discussed the contemporary relevance that a public interest test brings on board; paragraph 15.24, in which we discussed the proof of public interest; paragraph 19.23, in which we discussed the criteria for public interest; paragraph 19.24, in which we looked for the skilled application of the test of public interest. In paragraph 19.24 we referred to the role of the courts and others. We said:

'Public interest' is, as we indicated in Chapters 5 and 15, not a phrase which should be applied conclusively by a person who has administrative experience only, but one which should be susceptible to application in any individual case by an adjudicator, skilled at weighing and balancing competing interests, who had presented to him differing views as to what result the public interest requires in any given case.
In paragraph 19.29 the Committee said that these rules should not become fixed and rigid.

I think Senator Hamer mentioned the way in which people do not have access to files about themselves to see whether the information on them is correct or needed correction. I have mentioned the Murphyores example. The latest report given to the Government by an independent inquiry came from the Holcroft inquiry. Recommendation 31 states:

Disclosure to the regulatory authority and to the public be required, preferably on a uniform basis, of data concerning technical and financial performance of the airlines sufficient to monitor costs, pricing and performance.

The latest report we have says that in the airline industry there ought to be disclosure of the sorts of data that we are seeking. As Senator Missen has said-I will not repeat the conclusion of that chapter of our report which deals with the Westminister model-we are seeking not to subvert, not to undermine, but indeed to strengthen the principles of Westminster government. The remarks of Lord Croham, a former head of the Civil Service in Great Britain, was reported in the Times of 17 August 1978. The article was headed:
Less Secrecy in Whitehall will lead to a strengthening of Parliament.

The Canadians have found, by allowing their freedom of information Bill to have widespread appeals to administrative review, to the courts and to ombudsmen, that there is nothing prejudicial to the Westminster system in Canada. The Globe and Mail, a Toronto newspaper, reported on 18 July 1980:
Secretary of State Francis Fox surprised and silenced his Opposition critics yesterday by introducing a freedom of information bill which is in many ways more progressive than its Tory predecessor.
The bill reverses the Liberal Party's long-standing opposition to judicial review by establishing a process which gives the courts the ultimate say over what information should be made public.

The Canadians are not frightened about the possibility of subversion of the Westminster system by freedom of information. In New Zealand, the Committee on Official Information under Sir Alan Danks reported on the whole issue only recently. It stated:

We propose that the Ombudsman should deal with individual complaints about the disclosure and non-disclosure of information, including those arising in respect of a wider range of Government agencies.
It also stated:

We have already made plain our view that decisions about disclosure of information taken by departments and agencies must be subject to test by an independent arbiter. The next element in the system we are proposing is therefore a mechanism for reviewing these decisions and for receiving and investigating complaints from the public.

The proposal is also compatible with the principle of ministerial responsibility. Procedure would be informal rather than formal. As at present the Ombudsmen would not have powers of decision; they would investigate, and, if appropriate, recommend a different decision or practice.

That report indicates that the New Zealanders are not afraid that freedom of information is subversive to the Westminister system. As long ago as 1954 when the House of Commons was looking at the question of ministerial responsibility in the famous Crichel Down case, Mr Herbert Morrison, a former Minister in the Labour Administration, said:

There can be no question whatever that Ministers are responsible for everything that their officers do, but if civil servants make errors or commit failures the House has a right to be assured that the Minister has dealt with the errors or failures adequately and properly, or that he will do so. That is a duty that falls on Ministers as well, and it would be wrong for a Minister automatically to defend every act of his officers or servants merely because they belong to his Department. Therefore, the House has to be satisfied that he is dealing with the matter adequately.

How can a house of parliament be satisfied that a Minister is dealing adequately if it has no information upon which to base its judgments. We will come back to all of these matters and many others in the Committee stage of the Bill.

I believe the fundamental points to make at this stage are as follows: No government can demonstrate comprehensively or effectively that it has the right to withhold information from citizens unless it can prove that there is a real public interest in withholding that information. If there is a dispute between the right of the public to know and the right of the government to withhold, and the test of whether a document should be withheld is whether the withholding of that document is in the public interest, that is not a matter for governments alone to decide. The fundamental principle that we have operated under in parliamentary democracies is that judge and jury are separate, that it is not the right of the Government to receive the appeal, nor to decide whether the appeal should be granted and then to adjudicate on appeal against a request. If the court system in this country means anything and if the status of judges in this country means anything, surely they are trusted sufficiently to balance competing public interest.

The final thing to be said is this: The Westminster system rests with the base of the pyramid at the top. One can almost look at it upside down. The people have the right to judge governments and parliamentarians, and the system of democratic government cannot work in a community which is ignorant of the facts. An attempt to maintain the sovereign public, vox populi, in ignorance is a denial of the fundamental principles which we have been elected to this place to preserve and defend and for which people for the last thousand years have been prepared to lay down their lives. I would not be prepared to see it set at nought by some bureaucratic conspiracy to make freedom of information a meaningless term.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Freedom of Information Bill. I have little to add to the comments which have been made by members of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs which considered the predecessor of this Bill in very great detail and made a number of recommendations which go to its fundamentals. I wish to contribute to the extent of supporting the amendment moved by Senator Evans, the shadow Attorney-General, and particularly the remarks made by Senator Hamer, Senator Missen and Senator Puplick who are members of that Committee.
