I think Senator Puplick summed up the principle very well in the final stages of his remarks when he said that no government can withhold information from the public unless there are demonstrable public interest reasons for its so doing, and in that circumstance it should be a judge who decides whether there are such demonstrable reasons. I would have thought that that was a principle that the Government accepted in part, even in relation to the Australian security legislation and in respect of appeals, for example, under that legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: A couple of months ago the Swedish Press Ombudsman was in Australia. I was fortunate enough to attend a luncheon at the Melbourne Press Club which he addressed. He was asked a number of questions about the operation of freedom of information legislation in Sweden, which goes back to 1976. He was asked in particular: What was the effect of the legislation on public servants in the day to day carrying out of their work? The Swedish Press Ombudsman said that he had been a public servant for a number of years and that no advice which he had given or documents of advice which he had prepared had in fact been called on under the legislation. He said that public servants in the preparation of advice were constantly conscious of the existence of the freedom of information legislation. It certainly affected their work. It made them much more careful and much more conscientious in preparing advice. Perhaps that is the nub of the situation as it concerns Australia. Perhaps that is one of the fundamental concerns. All sorts of criticisms have been made of the level of operation of the Australian Public Service and the level of advice which it gives in various matters. Many of them are unjustified, but perhaps that is one of the major areas of concern.

As other speakers have pointed out, many countries have freedom of information legislation which goes far wider than the legislation which is now before the Senate. I cite the examples of Norway, Denmark, Sweden, Finland, France, New Zealand and the United States of America. I cite also the example of two Canadian provinces and the fact that the Canadian Parliament is currently dealing with legislation which is much more liberal than the legislation which is before the Senate. I refer to the United States. It is strange that many senators, who for reasons which will probably not be revealed in the course of this debate will probably vote against the amendments to this legislation and against similar amendments to other legislation, are very keen to tell us how much they admire the quality of democracy in the United States. I do too.

Often one reads American newspapers, watches on television and listens to American programs of one kind or another which relate to current events in which the United States as a society is embarrassed by actions which have been taken by its officials or politicians. But the discussion about those national events in the United States always comes back to people who are even very critical of the United States. They say: 'My God you have to admire them because in no other society or in very few other societies would those sorts of matters be public knowledge'. What has been unearthed regarding the Central Intelligence Agency operations would not, by the wildest stretch of the imagination, be unearthed under this legislation. In a sense one admires the vitality of American society in that it is prepared to take even the most controversial issues on board and make them available for public discussion. One wonders what is so important about decisions of the Australian Public Service and Australian governments which distinguishes them from those of the Government of what is sometimes regarded-rightly or wrongly-by many people as the greatest democracy in the world. What is so important here that distinguishes us in this situation? The situation can have its ridiculous manifestations. For example, I refer to the operation of secrecy in government in Australia compared with that in the United States. I quote from an article in the Melbourne Age of 7 January this year. It states:
. . . that United States military documents are readily accessible to Australians even though the comparable material is not available from our government.
It goes on to say:
One US document arising from that rethinking was a manual on land battles titled 'operations FW100-5'. Australia prepared a similar document adjusted for local needs.

Dr Keith Suter, a defence expert and a prominent member of the United Nations Association of Australia (New South Wales) disarmament committee attempted to obtain a copy of the Australian manual. He was told it would not be made available because it was a classified document.
Dr Suter then wrote to the Pentagon asking for a copy of the US version of the manual. The Pentagon replied saying that of course Dr Suter could have a copy. It would cost $8.
Dr Suter sent a cheque for $8 and received a copy of the manual plus 50c change due to exchange rate differences.

That relates to a document which perhaps falls in a quasi-defence category. I am not disposed to argue here as to whether it is an area which, in a general sense, should be exempt from the provisions of freedom of information legislation. But it is an interesting example of the sort of situation which exists in the United States compared with the situation which exists here. I do not want to approach this debate in a partisan spirit. Not to put too fine a point on it, the present Government is quite obsessed with secrecy. There have been many ludicrous examples of that fact. Let me state again, as Senator Puplick and others have done with such eloquence, that the right to know is a vital part of any democracy and is increasingly so as the so-called information revolution proceeds apace.

In that process the role of Parliament, the right of parliamentarians and the right to know of members of the Press-the so-called Fourth Estate-is a vital part of any democracy. According to one survey 82 per cent of the Australian people regard this Government as being too secretive. Not only is it secretive towards the people of this country but also it is secretive towards the Parliament of this country. This comes back to discussions that we have had in this Senate over the years about the role of Parliament as the watchdog of democracy and the role of the Press, the Fourth Estate, as the watchdog of democracy. We are pleased to call it the free Press even though it is owned by about half a dozen people in this country. We have discussed the right of the Parliament and the Press to have information.

Senators on the Government side, who may for some reason which has not yet been revealed vote against the amendments which will be moved to this legislation, on the recommendation of members of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, often talk here about the writings of Professor Gordon Reid and his warnings about the excessive secrecy of government and the role of the executive in totally dominating Parliament. Again and again he has warned about that.

I know that Senator Chaney and others have expressed concern about that fact in this Parliament-of course before they became Ministers in the present Government. Suddenly that concern, which they expressed about the domination of Parliament by the Executive, seems to have become limp or lukewarm. That is one of the unfortunate characteristics of the way in which this place operates. Parliament is denied much information. Question Time in this place is a farce in terms of obtaining information on behalf of constituents and members of the public. The process of government dissemination of information is a farce in terms of the process of obtaining information on behalf of citizens in this country. The role of the Executive is totally dominant in the operations of this Parliament. That is undesirable whichever party is in power. A Senate committee, one of the watchdog committees of this Senate, one of the committees which would strengthen, according to Professor Gordon Reid and others, the function and role of this Senate in performing its duties as a House of review, unanimously agreed that the freedom of information legislation proposed in 1978 was totally inadequate for a modern democracy. It recommended many amendments which will be discussed in the course of debate on this legislation. That is a sad situation. It is a pity that that is happening. All citizens ought to be concerned. As I said, survey material indicates that a very substantial majority of people are concerned.

Let us look at some of the information which has been kept back from the Australian people in the last few years. I again refer to what Senator Puplick said. It is the right of the public to know information unless it can be established by those who would refuse knowledge of the facts that a very substantial case exists for its not being released in the public interest. People who say that they have the right to refuse information and knowledge should put their decision to the test. It should be judged by somebody who is impartial, somebody who is a member of the judiciary. I refer to some of the information which has been withheld. The financial directive to Qantas Airways Ltd given in 1947 again and again has been asked for by journalists and others. Only a few months ago we had the dreadful situation arising from an industrial dispute in which Qantas's affairs were very much in the public limelight. The Chairman of Qantas came to Canberra. He said that government restrictions on that airline had prevented it from doing many of the things which it wanted to do. He then said that he would not say any more about it. The financial directive to that airline is the government limitation or restriction on the capacity of that airline to operate-in terms of such things as loans. This is essential to its economic viability. Why are not Australians, who are the shareholders in that company by virtue of its structure, entitled to know that information? Why are they not entitled to know? Why have governments consistently refused that information?

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirty-four years old.

—Thirty-four years old, as Senator Sibraa, with his usual perceptive interjection, has pointed out. It is not only that sort of information which is not available. Let me give some other examples, such as the case of a film on the effects of uranium mining in the Northern Territory which was made by the Government Information Unit and suppressed by the Government because it was thought to be unsuitable for the people of Australia to see. That is absurd. That is absurd, not only in terms of the sort of schoolmasterly attitude which is adopted by government towards citizens in this country; it is absurd also in terms of the fact that many citizens who are concerned about these things read overseas newspapers and sometimes see films from overseas dealing with these subject matters. Why should Australians be denied that right? How can we have a mature society capable of discussing these issues in a rational and balanced way when that sort of information is denied by government? What is the justification for that sort of denial?

SPEECH.PARA: What is the justification for denying journalists, parliamentarians, and Australian citizens the right to see a health manual on medical standards for selection of migrants? What is the justification for that refusal by government? It is probably embarrassing to some public servants; I do not know. I am not here in the business of not embarrassing public servants, I assure the Senate, but it may be embarrassing to some public servant, so that information is denied.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only upper public servants, higher public servants.

—Yes, higher public servants, I am sorry. What is the justification for that denial in terms of the operation of a free society, as Malcolm Fraser put it on 5 December in that seminal speech made in Adelaide on his behalf by Senator Chaney? What is the justification for that under cover of either umbrella-the democratic society, the free society, as Malcolm Fraser talks about it, or alternatively, the conservative society, about which he also talks? There is no conservative society with any conserving in any sense of decent traditions-the decent traditions of 18th century liberalism, for example-which would deny that sort of information to the citizens of a country. In more recent terms, what is the justification for denying access to documents on Australian defence and foreign policy and going through that absurdly embarrassing farce at the High Court over those documents? What is the justification for that in terms of discussion in a vital democracy, in terms of a free society and the free flow of information upon which any such society is dependent? As the United Nations General Assembly Declaration of 1945 put it:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . freedom of information is a fundamental human right and is the touchstone of all the freedoms to which the United Nations is consecrated.

That sort of freedom, that sort of fundamental human right, just does not appear to be available in Australia for all sorts of quite silly reasons, for all sorts of quite patrician reasons, for all sorts of reasons which, as I have said on previous occasions, suggest that governments have some particular God-given right to determine what the people of this country will know, even what they will know about things they pay for through their taxes, about things such as government instrumentalities and services which they allegedly own. Other things have been refused to the Australian Consumers Association; for example, things such as the right to look at product tests of the National Acoustic Laboratories, the Department of Transport, and the Materials Research Laboratories. Why should not Australians know the results of product tests made by government instrumentalities such as the Acoustic Laboratories? Is that some additional concession the Government makes to private enterprise? If the Acoustic Laboratories say that a particular hearing aid or piece of equipment is no good, are the people to be denied that knowledge and allowed to go ahead and buy it, perhaps because the manufacturer gave a sling to the Liberal Party at the last election, or something like that? Is that sort of information to be denied?

Those are the sorts of things which were denied Australian citizens in the past and are still being denied Australian citizens on a day by day basis. They result from petty, narrow-minded, patrician attitudes by politicians, who take themselves too seriously in terms of what they feel they have the capacity to decide about the rights of the Australian people, and by senior bureaucrats who also put themselves in very much the same category. That is not the sort of society which matches the rhetoric of anybody in this place on a day by day basis. It is not the sort of society which lives up to the concerns of commentators on the way government operates in Australia-that the Senate, for example, should be a watchdog on the Executive Government. How can the Senate be a watchdog on the Executive Government if the Executive Government produces freedom of information legislation of the quality of this document now before the Parliament?

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be trying, Senator.

—Senator Chipp will be trying. He is a great trier, and I should like to pay that personal tribute as we say farewell to Senator Chipp. He will be trying. Of course we will try, but there is no reason why these obstructions should be put in our way. There is no reason why these obstructions should be put in the way of journalists. There is no reason why these obstructions should be put in the way of the Australian people. A society grows in vitality and richness by its capacity to exchange what is becoming the most important piece of wealth it can have, that is, information. We are now living in a period of history in which even economists talk about the information rich and the information poor. This country and this Parliament will be information poor if this legislation is adopted in its present form, in the mealy-mouthed, weak-kneed form in which it comes before the Parliament, and if the amendments to the legislation which the Senate Committee will be recommending are not adopted. If those recommendations are not adopted then this Parliament will be information poor rather than information rich, and so will the Press of this country and the people of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I join with my colleague Senator Evans in supporting the amendment he moved to the motion for the second reading of the Bill. We are concerned at the failure of the Executive, the Government, to explain why it has rejected the arguments put by a unanimous decision of a committee of this Senate, the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. That Committee recommended that Australia should come into the ivy league, into the second half of the 20th century, and join those other countries which are numbered amongst the vital democracies of this world, and there are not too many of them. It has recommended that this Parliament should adopt legislation consistent with the standards of freedom of information legislation adopted in all those other countries to which I have referred.

The amendment moved by Senator Evans to the motion for the Senate second reading of the Bill regrets the excessive deference to bureaucratic influence that appears to have been involved in the rejection by the Government of significant Senate Committee recommendations. It refers to the incorporation of new limitations on the scope and operation of the original 1978 Bill. In the third paragraph it expresses the hope that the Government will adopt a little more imagination on this. When we talk, as the Prime Minister does, about the better society we are trying to create, we should ensure as one of the linchpins of that better society the right of every Australian to have such information as is available and should be available to all citizens, unless there is some fundamental public interest objection. That is not so with this legislation. We also, of course, reaffirm the continuing commitment to freedom of information legislation and the belief that it is indispensible to proper administrative justice and the national interest in Australia.

I certainly join with the other speakers who have spoken in support of the amendment, in commending it to the Senate and to those honourable senators who perhaps have not thought very much about the legislation. What we are saying in relation to this matter is consistent with all the rhetoric day after day in this chamber about the sort of society in which we would like to live. I ask Government senators to examine this legislation closely and to tell us in debate what is wrong with the legislation and what is wrong with it in terms of what they believe a democratic society should be like and in terms of their beliefs on the importance of parliamentary control or checks on the power of executive government. I hope that honourable senators supporting the Government's view will be forthcoming in telling us what they feel about those matters if they are going to vote for the legislation in its present form because we should not just sit here like highly paid dummies putting up our hands at the right moment. If we really believe the legislation is dangerous to the public interest we should say so. I would be fascinated to hear what sorts of arguments might be advanced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President:

SPEECH.PARA: It is now eight years since Australians were promised a freedom of information law. In that time the Public Service bureaucrats with the endorsement of the Cabinet, have fought a hard and successful series of battles to ensure that no such legislation is ever enacted. No excuse, no matter how fanciful, was overlooked to discredit the concept of the legislation . . . yesterday-
I will explain in a moment why the word 'yesterday' is used.
saw the triumph of this campaign with the introduction of a freedom of information bill into the Federal Parliament which is nothing more than a cosmetic fake.

Honourable senators will realise that I am quoting from a newspaper which is not noted for its radical impact on Australia's social and political life. I am quoting from the editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald of 3 April 1981. It is quite clear that that newspaper and that editorialist, as did almost every editorial I had access to at the time of the introduction of this Bill, perceived that over some eight years we had a process-it will not be too fanciful to call it a deliberate process-of frustration such that, as we waited for the Bill to emerge, at the end of each period of delay we were merely presented with a proposal for a Bill which, far from streamlining or making access to information more assured and cheaper, has indeed made access to government information less assured to the general Australian community.

The process of delay is the first point to which I wish to draw attention. This is the amazing feature: Given the necessary consultative processes and necessary deliberations within government and the fact that that might have been expected to entail some two or three years of debate within the Australian community, one would have thought the least the Government could do on the introduction of this Bill-in the Government's view, in its final and acceptable form-would be to have a provision permitting access to documents at least from the time at which the Bill was first put into the public arena. One of the grave defects of the Bill which will be taken up no doubt at the Committee stage is that it does not grant access to documents-except in one minor instance-created before the passage of this legislation into law. That means, indeed, that every week, every month and every year of delay and frustration by the bureaucracy has had the effect in the main that another week, another month and another year of information has been denied to the Australian public. I think that in itself would give cause for concern and would perhaps encourage honourable senators to come to the conclusion that in fact the Government is not fair dinkum in the series of deliberations and consultations which preceded the introduction of the Bill.

Of course the Bill is flawed by far more than the process of deliberation which has brought it into the chamber tonight. In the view of very many honourable senators the Bill does not capture the true spirit of freedom of information that has emerged in representative democracies particularly since the Second World War. It is not for me to go over the matters so eloquently expressed by Senator Evans and Senator Missen and other honourable senators in the debate tonight, except to say that it is quite clearly crucial for the penetration of truly democratic ideals into our society, where the Government of this nation is concerned, that some Bill such as the one recommended by the State Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs be introduced in this country. Those democratic ideals of participation and of knowledge by the people in the society of what government records may hold about them or about policy options need to be guaranteed. I speak of government information which ought to be available in two different types of categories-for example, government information when government has carried out some surveillance or assessment of an individual to determine whether that individual ought to have access to certain, for example, social security rights. I believe my colleague the shadow Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, will elaborate when making his contribution to the debate. Surely where access to rights or where the imposition of liabilities by government is concerned, Australians should have access to such information. I do not deny that the Bill goes some part of the way to achieving that. I am saying that this is one of the ideals which ought to be achieved by the freedom of information legislation.

Perhaps more critically, it is the Government's formulation and execution of general political policies which create the whole society wherein we live as free people. It is the documentation which preceeds and embodies the making of those decisions which ought to be available to the general community, except in those instances in which it can be demonstrated to an impartial body that for reasons of national security, defence or commercial secrecy the supression of that document might be required. How free are we really as a society if documents containing assessments by government officials on individual applicants for benefits are not available to the individual? A deficit in the Bill which is a matter of concern to me is that the individual does not have the ability to seek to correct within a government document a misstatement of fact which concerns him and his access to a benefit or right or his being subjected to some sort of liability. Of course these are not minor matters, but they are matters which concern the livelihood of people. Their access to benefits may very well be crucial not only to themselves but to their families.

I think it is believed by honourable senators and by people in the community generally that a good freedom of information Bill would ensure that the individual Australian not only knows exactly what his Government has on file about him but also is able to correct misstatements of fact or so put the statements of fact in proper context that any misleading impression that might be gained by the bureaucracy concerning that individual can be corrected. In any case, that is one category where information ought to be as freely available as possible and access ought to be assured and cheap.

But the Bill is important in a far wider sense, as I said earlier. Does anyone in this chamber doubt that the power of knowledge is crucial whether it be in the industrial, commercial or trading sphere-that is well known-or, of course, in the social or political spheres? Those who have the knowledge tend to have access to power. Of course, they can disseminate, use and manipulate it in order to preserve their positions of power. In Australia we have our guardians of the knowledge-the bureaucrats and the Ministry-retaining to themselves as much as possible the facts and the policy options upon which government decisions are made. They jealously guard those internal working documents, those documents protected by conclusive ministerial certificates. They do so with all the language which creates the mystique of a bureaucracy which is so secretive and so unresponsive to the demands, as I have said, of a truly participatory democracy.

They talk of internal working documents with the emphasis on 'internal' as though they are not simply documents which are available to government and which ought to be equally available to the general community so that a proper assessment can be made of the validity of the facts and of the range of policy options open to government. They speak of a conclusive ministerial certificate with the emphasis on 'conclusive'. One would not object to the fact that a Minister might claim that a matter is sensitive in the national security sphere or may have an impact on our defence readiness or preparedness. If he has such a claim it ought to be weighted most carefully by an appointed tribunal that is competent to do that task.

We also have the mystique of the Westminister system which has been adequately dealt with by many of the speakers earlier in the debate. A mystique is conveyed by that phrase which I think needs to be very clearly rebutted. The essence of the Westminister system is, of course, simply that the Ministry is drawn from the elected representatives within the Parliament. That is in no way touched, impaired or hindered by the freedom of information legislation as conceived, for example, by the Senate Committee. In no way is access to information the enemy of representative democracy based on the Westminister model such as has evolved in Australia. One might think that because the Ministry is indeed drawn from the elected representatives and is not created by some sort of patronage system as it is in the United States, the Ministers would be keen to see that the other elected representatives-their fellows within the Parliament-and, indeed, the people whom they represent should have as much access to information within the possession of the Government as is compatible with our national security.

I will not go into the Bill in great detail. I simply emphasise, for the sake of honourable senators who may be wondering whether they should support the amendment to the second reading moved by Senator Evans, that the amendment is moved in order to give senators an opportunity to express their disappointment with the Bill as it has emerged from this deliberative process and to enable honourable senators to indicate to the Government that it would have been preferable had the Bill been more closely aligned with the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee inquiring into freedom of information. I believe that that Committee in many ways embodies the essence and the integrity of Senate standing committees. The report in its 500 pages, argues the matter, very exhaustively and tightly. The point is that it is an unanimous report.

Senator Alan Missen chaired the Committee most ably with a degree of knowledge of comparative and international law on this subject which was most invaluable. The contributions of Senators Hamer and Puplick were in the real traditions of liberalism in the English sense of that word. The contribution by Senator Evans was, of course, incisive, penetrating and comprehensive. It would not amaze other honourable senators to be told that his capacity for work was one of the factors which enabled this tremendous project to come to fruition. Senator Keeffe made his customary contribution and I was present on most occasions. That report, as I have said, concluded after the most exhaustive and fair-minded taking of evidence on a Bill of this nature to take place certainly within the Australian Parliament and very probably in any parliament throughout the world. The conclusions have been spoken of in detail, as I have said, by Senator Evans.

The fact is that while the Senate Committee, a committee of elected representatives, was coming to its conclusions that a much more elaborate, stringent Bill was required in order to enable assured and cheap access to government records, at the very same time as this perception of what was required within our democracy by elected representatives of the people was going on, in another forum-in many ways a much more powerful forum of non-elected persons who have the power, indeed, to hold void legislation which this Parliament passes-the non-elected justices of the High Court of Australia were coming to the same conclusion. I refer to the case of Sankey v. Whitlam.

I think it is most interesting and it should be of some help to honourable senators to realise that that case involved a situation very similar to that which is the concern of this Bill. On the one hand there were the claims that government documents, some of which were Federal Executive Council decisions and some of which were internal working documents, ought not to be disclosed even though they were required by a person in the course of litigation. There was a conflict. The whole case really boiled down to a conflict between the claim on the one side that the efficient working of government at the highest levels would be impaired by disclosure and the claim on the other side that for justice to be done disclosure had to be made. The point really is that the High Court of Australia, the non-elected Bench of justices, decided in the late 1970s that the Executive should not make the final decision on how those competing claims should be resolved, and it was proper for the High Court to make that decision, that the Executive should not be the final arbiter of what government documents ought to be withheld from public disclosure in the interests of not impairing some matter of public interest.

I have dwelt on that case for a few moments because I believe that the Court, like the Senate Standing Committee, reflected a mood within our democracy far removed from that prevailing during and at the end of the Second World War. One cannot but feel that perhaps many of the attitudes of the men in the later years of their lives at the heights of the Public Service within Australia are attitudes which were appropriate in the late 1940s and the early 1950s but which are totally inappropriate and out of tune with the demands for a truly participatory, representative democracy that are being made in Australia at the moment. Indeed, the acceptance by the Government of the decisions in the Sankey v. Whitlam case and the fact that it brought no legislation into this place in order to undo that decision or to make it impossible for it to recur in the future seems to my mind completely to undermine any continuing claim by the Government that where a conflict arises between the public interest in competent administration which may be served by some secrecy on the one hand and the public interest in disclosure to interested members of the public on the other hand the Government must be the final arbiter. The Government has accepted the High Court decision in the Sankey v. Whitlam case and I believe that in the spirit of that acceptance it should have gone much further in the Bill which it has presented to this chamber tonight.

The fact that it has not gone as far as it should in curtailing the use of conclusive ministerial certificates is of course mentioned by Senator Missen as one of the seven deadly sins of omission in the document which he has circulated. I think it is very important for honourable senators to note, in Senator Missen's words, this fact:

The Government refuses to abandon the provisions which deny any right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against refusals to disclose government documents in many important areas and the Bill provides that the Ministers certificate is to be final and unchallengeable. The major areas affected are: Documents relating to national security, defence, international relations, relations with States, cabinet and executive council documents and the determination of what is 'contrary to the public interest' in relation to 'internal working documents'.

To state the position shortly, and I hope not too crudely, it is not that the Senate Committee, nor indeed the High Court, would want to make available every document about which a claim can be properly made that its disclosure would imperil national security or defence. It is not our intention that such documents should willy-nilly be made available to those who request them. But it is our contention that the Executive and the bureaucracy behind the Executive should not be the final and conclusive arbiters of whether a document is in fact such as is described. Indeed, when one reads the Bill that has been presented one finds some amazing provisions. Proposed section 23 (2) reads:

An agency or Minister may refuse to grant access to documents in accordance with a request without having searched for or identified the documents if the nature of the documents, as described in the request, is such that any such document would be an exempt document.

If that is not a catch-22 clause, nothing is. The agency-that means some government department or the Minister; at least he could be held responsible in a forum such as this at Question Time, or in debate-can refuse to search for a document if it believes that the document would be exempt. But how is it to know the nature of the document if it has not searched for it, precisely delineated or ascertained its contents and put them up against some set of criteria? It is that sort of refusal to come to terms with the real spirit of providing the Australian community with access to government documents in an assured and cheap manner which is the reason that Senator Evans has moved the amendment in such mild terms as he has in this second reading debate.

I would not want to give the impression that the matter is of concern only to Senate committees which have 15 months in which to go around Australia exhaustively collating evidence and opinions from not only government departments but also a broad range of persons within the Australian community. Nor is this merely a matter of concern for a High Court which brought its judicial integrity and impartiality to bear on questions of the nature with which we are dealing tonight. But the editorial comment around Australia has been to express uniform disappointment, to put it at its very mildest, in the Bill which has been presented to this chamber this week.

TALK.START.PARA: —And unanimous.

—I would say unanimous on my reading. I thank Senator Missen. I have already quoted from the first paragraph of the editorial of the Sydney Morning Herald of 3 April 1981. I go on to quote from it in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: A draft bill, published by the Federal Government in 1978, was examined by a Senate committee and found to be so defective that over 90 changes to it were recommended. The legislation now before the Parliament makes a mockery of the Senate investigation.
That would be reason enough, I believe, for many honourable senators to support the second reading amendment moved by Senator Evans. The editorial continues:
About 20 of the recommendations have been grafted on to the new bill. But these are the most insubstantial on the list. The basic flaws of the draft bill have been retained.
It goes on to list some of those basic flaws. The editorial concludes:
As the legislation presently stands, it is a freedom from information rather than of information bill.
That is a cliche which has been repeated many times, but it is a cliche because it is appropriate and because it sums up in succinct form so much of the concern which has been mentioned here tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you really suggesting that that is a true statement?

—I am saying that it is a cliche because it expresses the widespread concern within the Australian community, a concern which I will go on to point out is expressed in the Advertiser of Monday, 6 April 1981. Once again, that is not a journal of radical opinion within this Commonwealth; it is a responsible, one might say, conservative newspaper published in Senator McLaren's home State of South Australia. The article is entitled 'Rationing information', which I think is the editorialists answer to Senator Durack's question. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: The so-called Freedom of Information Bill introduced by the Federal Attorney-General, Senator Durack, last week is a desperately disappointing document. Nor is the disappointment eased at all by the fact that it is by no means surprising. It had been widely and, as we now know, accurately conjectured for some time that the Government would decide to ignore most of the more important amendments recommended to the earlier 1978 Bill . . .
That the principles embodied in those amendments have been so firmly rejected suggests that the Government has no real commitment to the notion of making information more readily available.

It is because of that lack of real commitment that Senator Evans's amendment to the second reading has been moved in the terms in which it has. I commend that amendment to honourable senators. The editorial in the Advertiser concludes:
If it can do no better than this--
It is speaking of the Government's action in introducing this Bill-

in an area so closely concerned with democratic principles the Government might have been well advised to do nothing. Its critics now see it as being as much concerned with its own as with the public's welfare in the matter of freedom of information. It is to be hoped that the Senate will apply sufficient pressure to bring about much needed improvements in the proposed legislation.
I could go on to quote from the Age of 4 April. I will not quote at great length because time is so short. It makes this point:
. . . that our governments have grown so large and remote that they no longer understand their basic relationship to society.

It points out that the Federal Government and its senior bureaucrats seem to have failed to come to terms with that real relationship between government and society, namely, that the Government collects information at the expense of and on behalf of the public and that therefore, as a matter of sheer logic let alone democratic decency, that information should be available to the public unless very strong arguments can be mounted for its suppression. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise simply to seek information from the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson) in regard to the Government's intentions with regard to a survey entitled 'Appraisal and implications of a survey of Abbott's Booby on Christmas Island' by Professor Ovington, Professor Cullen and Dr Nelson. I took the trouble, as I did last night, to alert Senator Peter Baume to that fact that I expected him to be in the chamber when I made my submission. I even went to the extent of sending him a letter that I received from Mr Buckingham, who is the Chairman of the Australian National Section of the International Council for Bird Preservation. I hope that Senator Durack, who is at the table, will have a look at the document I sent to Senator Peter Baume. The document virtually speaks for itself.

SPEECH.PARA: On 15 September 1980 I raised in the Senate a question concerning what the Government contemplated doing to protect the habitat of the booby bird. As a result of that Professor Ovington and his colleagues were appointed to undertake a survey. Subsequently the results of the survey were published. Paragraph 3 on page 25 of the survey states:
We believe that with a revised mining plan, jungle clearing for phosphate mining can be compatible with the conservation of Abbott's Booby . . .

The important thing is that the survey indicates that there can be a spirit of co-existence. On pages 26, 27 and onwards it lays out the plan to be achieved whereby phosphate can be produced and at the same time the habitat of the booby bird can be protected. The Australian National Section of the International Council for Bird Preservation, in its communication to me, asked four questions. It stated:
We are most anxious to elicit a public statement on:
1. The findings of the study.
2. The appraisal of those findings.
3. The intended action by the Government in response to the study and its appraisal.
4. The degree of commitment by the Goverment to ensuring the survival of Abbott's Booby as a viable endemic breeding species on Christmas Island.
I seek leave for that communication to be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
THE INTERNATIONAL COUNCIL FOR BIRD PRESERVATION
Australian National Section
18/117 Caroline Street South Yarra, Victoria 3141
30 March 1981
Senator J. A. Mulvihill
Commonwealth Parliamentary Offices
Chifley Square,
Sydney, NSW 2000
Dear Senator
May I express the appreciation of members of this organisation for your concern over the fate of Abbott's Booby at Christmas Island. The threat to its continued existence is very real indeed.

I refer in particular to your question in the Senate to the Governent Leader, Senator Carrick, on 15 September 1980. In reply Senator Carrick advised that an expert panel would appraise a detailed survey of the size, distribution and viability of the population of Abbott's Booby and report its finding on 31 January 1981.
The report has been published and a copy sent to me in my capacity as Chairman, Australian National Section, ICBP.

It is clear from the report that some restraint to rain-forest clearing for mining is necessary if the Booby's survival is to be ensured. The report makes a number of very reasonable proposals and offers an optimal solution to otherwise conflicting mining and conservation interests. I do not have information on the appraisal of the study.
Would you please raise the matter again in the Senate at the earliest opportunity? We are most anxious to elicit a public statement on:
1. the findings of the study,
2. the appraisal of those findings,
3. the intended action by the Government in response to the study and its appraisal,
4. the degree of commitment by the Government to ensuring the survival of Abbott's Booby as a viable endemic breeding species on Christmas Island.

Hopefully, in view of Senator Carrick's comments in Hansard on the Prime Minister's practical attitudes towards the conservation of flora and fauna, we shall not see the Booby go the way of the Dodo or the other 180 or so species of oceanic island birds now no longer in existence.
I would much appreciate receiving from you a copy of the extract from Hansard when the matter is raised and answered.
I remain, yours faithfully,
R. BUCKINGHAM Chairman, ANS, ICBP

TALK.START.PARA: —We have all seen the recent posters dealing with Christmas Island and illustrating crabs and various bird varieties. The survey prepared by Professor Ovington and his colleagues was dated 23 January 1981. So I think it is time the Government, through the wisdom of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, indicated what the Government's plans are and whether they are an adequate response to the International Council for Bird Preservation in view of the very lucid communcation which I have had incorporated in Hansard and which bears the signature of Mr Buckingham, who of course is the Chairman of the Australian National Section of that organisation. I leave the matter in the hands of Senator Durack in the hope that I will get an early response with regard to the Government's intentions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret that I have not any information in relation to the matter raised by Senator Mulvihill. I was interested to read the document which he has had incorporated in Hansard. I am sure that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson) will also be interested and may indeed have some knowledge of the matter. I will ensure that Senator Mulvihill's remarks are brought to his attention and will ask him to give his early attention to the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 March 1981 (Hansard, page 488), Senator MacGibbon asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: In view of the Minister's statement on 9 March to the Conference of Combined Rural Traders that the Australian Government expects even heavier damage to the sugar export trade by the European Economic Community's continuing refusal to sign the International Sugar Agreement, what additional steps will the Government take to ensure that Australia's sugar producers are not harmed further by the Community's intransigent policies?
The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Australian Government intends to continue to seek to have the EEC adopt sugar export policies that do not disrupt the world sugar market. The Government will continue to pursue this matter through the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), and by other multilateral and bilateral means.

Australia is continuing to press the EEC in the GATT to modify its sugar regime. In 1979 a GATT Panel found that the EEC's system of sugar export subsidies had prejudiced Australian trade and constituted a threat of prejudice to world trade. Subsequently, Australia held bilateral consultations with the EEC on its sugar regime. As there was no progress in these consultations a GATT Working Party was established to consider ways by which the Community might change its system so as to place limits on its export subsidies. The EEC was not prepared, however, to make any changes to its system and the Working Party was forced to conclude that the Community's export subsidies would continue as a source of uncertainty in world markets and would continue to prejudice world sugar trade. The Working Party's report was adopted by the GATT Council which adopted a decision maintaining Australia's complaint and providing for a further review by the GATT of the new EEC sugar regulations and the 1981-82 sugar intervention price.
Australia will continue to bring maximum pressure to bear on the EEC at future GATT meetings in an effort to bring about meaningful changes to its damaging sugar regime.

Australia also continues to seek to persuade the EEC to enter negotiations for EEC membership of the International Sugar Agreement. It is important that the EEC accept its international responsibility along with other sugar importers and exporters and join the ISA under terms and conditions, including export quotas, comparable with those accepted by all other members.
Unfortunately, however, and despite pressure from Australia and other ISA members, the EEC has taken little action to join the current Agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 31 March 1981 (Hansard, page 877) Senator Evans asked a question concerning the Australian Legal Aid Office in Victoria. I said that I would investigate the matters raised by Senator Evans and that I would provide a detailed answer after I had an opportunity of doing that.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's budget for legal aid for the financial year 1980-81 allows the Australian Legal Aid Office to refer a certain number of matters to private practitioners. A proportion of that number is available to the Australian Legal Aid Office in Victoria.

There has been a high level of demand for legal aid in Victoria in this financial year. That demand has been met, but it is not possible to continue at that rate for the remainder of the year without exceeding the budget limit. However, a number of steps have been and are being taken within the Australian Legal Aid Office to meet, as far as possible, the continuing demand for legal aid in Victoria.

One means of doing this is to increase the capacity of salaried lawyers to provide the legal services directly, so as to compensate, as far as possible, for the limited number of referrals available in the last quarter of the year.

The arrangement under which a duty solicitor attends the Family Court each morning in Melbourne has not been axed but suspended only for a short period. The temporary suspension is to enable the office to utilise the duty solicitor to provide legal services within the Office. However, there will still be lawyers 'on call' to attend at the Family Court to help persons needing urgent legal representation in family law matters; in other cases, legal advice will be obtainable from the Melbourne Office, which is located close to the Family Court.

Before dealing with other matters raised in the question, I wish to repudiate the allegation that a policy of deception has been implemented in the Melbourne Office. The staff of the Melbourne Office have responded well to the high demand for legal aid, and I am sure that they will make even greater efforts to cope with it.

With regard to the rest of the question, I make the following observations and comments: No arrangements are in hand for increasing the contributions required of those granted legal aid; this course would not, in any case, increase the number of matters which could be referred to private practitioners. No arrangements are in hand to redefine the notion of merit to exclude applications which would otherwise be within the guidelines; the merits of applications, of course, have to be considered in accordance with the Office guidelines to ensure that matters without legal merit are not publicly funded and that available funds are allocated to those matters where the need for assistance is greatest. No arrangements are being made to reject outright any applicants who satisfy the guidelines. Late last month there was a period of six working days during which the referring of approved matters to private practitioners was deferred and a final decision on some other applications was also deferred. This was to enable the overall position to be reviewed. Urgent matters, however, were not deferred. The reference of matters to private practitioners has now been resumed subject to the annual limit applicable to Victoria under the Budget. In view of that limit, matters are being referred in an order of priority which takes account of need. Priorities are being re-assessed each week by the Office.

The administrative steps described above are necessary to ensure that the Australian Legal Aid Office operates within its budget for the financial year. I shall be monitoring the situation to see whether any further action becomes necessary.
